Without the private key the only way to access your data is if your instance is EBS-backed. Then you can Stop the instance and get access to the root volume by attaching it to another instance.
Thank you so much for the response.  Might it be possible to add EBS now and then proceed as you described?

Probably not.  You could add an EBS volume to the instance...but it would be an "empty" volume, and that won't help you much.  I recommend purchasing a support contract with Amazon and working directly with their support team to get this resolved.  I don't know if they can help you, but it sounds urgent and the forums are no place to get "urgent" things resolved.  Good luck!
I think I'll do that, and thank you so much for the help!!

Elastic Load Balancer: Empty reply from server I run a site on EC2 that has modest amounts of traffic.  It's all housed on one machine.  I want to make it less vulnerable to an instance outage, so I have been investigating the Elastic Load Balancer.  It's not really needed to balance any load, just so that I can have 2 (or more) instances running to reduce outage vulnerability.  This may not be exactly what ELB is intended for, but I've read a lot of posts about people using it for this purpose.  The alternative seems to be to set up something like HAProxy on yet another instance, but this is not really any less vulnerable to an instance outage (in case the HAProxy instance goes down).  I did a test where I had the ELB in front of 2 instances, while I was hitting the site from the command line on my desktop machine, using curl.  It seemed to be evenly distributing the hits between the 2 instances.  Then I stopped one of the instances, meanwhile still hitting the site with curl.  One of my curls had a long wait, and then got the message that curl received an empty reply from the server.  Subsequent requests worked fine.  I concluded from this that the ELB did not realize that one of my instances was down.  I understand there are configurable health checks, which I left at the default setting (30 second interval, 2 failures required).  I don't know if normal requests (not generated from the health check) count in terms of the ELB deciding that an instance is not healthy.  Is there a way that I can set things up to minimize the chance that someone gets an empty reply when/if one of my instances goes down?  I was hoping that the ELB would try another instance rather than returning an empty reply.

You're using ELB appropriately, don't worry.  You can choose a small health check period to minimize the time that an unhealthy instance would still get traffic. But ELB does not monitor the responses from an instance to determine health.

Thanks for answering the question about whether normal responses are taken into account when determining instance health.  Perhaps this is naive, but ... that seems strange to me.  I can understand why you'd want to have proactive health checks, but why wouldn't you also infer that an instance is down when it doesn't reply to a normal request?  If a site is receiving moderate traffic when an instance goes down, you're going to have a bunch of requests that get no reply before the 2 health checks are going to fail.  I realize that you can configure the health checks to be more frequent, and to require just one failure, but it just seems like you'd have to generate a lot of useless traffic that way, instead of getting information from the organic traffic that the ELB is already handling.

Hi paultoman,  How do I access an S3 bucket from within an AMI? I have found various third party tools (such as TntDrive, which I cannot get to work because I don't know the values of the keys it requires) but I had expected it would be simple to tranfer data between these two services. Is it?  I am one of the developers of TntDrive It allows you to map Amazon S3 Bucket as a network drive or removable drive under Windows.  Before adding new virtual drive you need to add at least one Amazon S3 account and specify your Amazon S3 credentials i.a. Access key ID and Secret Key  When new Amazon S3 account is defined, you can choose one of the available s3 buckets or specify new one and it will be created automatically.  You can find your Amazon S3 keys here:http://aws-portal.amazon.com/gp/aws/developer/account/index.html?action=access-key  Feel free to contact us via this form if you have any further questions regarding using TntDrive.  Regards, Ivan Moiseev, TntDrive Team.

Hi all:    I'm a newer to amazon ec2.I need your help.I can not login with the "root"  as user name to Basic 64-bit Amazon Linux AMI 1.0,then i tried use "ec2-user" as user name, it's succeed,but i cannot run several command such as: fdisk,mount..and so on.     In the aws console,there is a 10G volume, created automaticly. Hi,I believe the reason you are unable to run those commands is that they are not in your path as ec2-user.  Also, they require root privileges to run.To escalate to root, for individual commands, you can precede the command with the 'sudo' command.  For example:$ sudo /sbin/fdisk /dev/sdbHowever, if you wish to run as the root user with the full root environment, you can run the following command:$ sudo su -This will return a root prompt, as if you had logged in as root.
Thx for your helpful answer!My problem was solved!

Hi Sanja,I had the same problem as you, but managed to work around it! I don't know if this is helpful, but nevertheless, here goes! As I understand it, there's three ways to deal with it:1. Fork the AWS API, and replace StAX with the Android XML parser.2. Use JarJar Links as described in that Google Code article you've linked to.3. Force the use of --core-library.I picked the third as I didn't want to fork the AWS API. It was a bit of a pain to do this because the default ant rules template file fails with Android SDK r 7 (why on earth is it there in the first place? :P).I wrote down what I did here. I am now able to query AWS services (haven't tested exhaustively, but I've checked out a few EC2 API commands). Anyway, here's the link: http://code.google.com/p/elastic-droid/wiki/AWSonAndroid?ts=1287930548&updated=AWSonAndroidThis is pretty obviously a bit of a nasty kludge, but is the best I can think of for the mo. And hey, it seems to work!!! If any of you knows of a better way, please let me know. On second thoughts, don't; I'd +vely cry if there was a far simpler way to do it.;)Hope this helps!Cheers,Sid

Hi,Thanks a lot for complete explanation. And yes, for as much as I could have found - I agree with your three solutions.The --core library option is really not the best thing to use due to compatibility - but again, for proceeding with it and testing my application it seems I will use it.I was actually trying with this explanation on how to repackage stax-api.jar, but now it seems that then again I would have to fork AWS? I was not aware of that, but if it is so - then that is not a good solution, definitely. I asked the author of that explanation (using jar jar links) to make myself sure if that is true. Hope I will get some answer soon.Again - thanks a lot,and yes - if anyone else has better solution -please inform us.Best,

Hi,The reason I think you need to fork AWS to use jarjar links is because of the last two sections of the http://code.google.com/p/dalvik/wiki/JavaxPackages documentation: Factory Registration and Factory Class Loaders. In the first case, you need to tell calls to import "javax.xml.*" to use "com.sun.whatever", which requires changes to the AWS API. In the second case, you need to tell the SDK to use the application's class loader, which I think would additionally tie your SDK to Android implementations.I might talking through the proverbial hat here, but this is what I understood, and this is why I chose to go the --core-library route, and be prepared for some major effort come Gingerbread time.

CloudWatch Question Hi,I just started to take a look at CloudWatch to get some stats on my instances.However I'm a little confused about the stat's that it gives.Network stats in and out has a few possibilities Min / Max / Average, etc.What do these values mean?If my time interval is 1 minute, then:Min = Min bytes transferred in that minute.Max = Max bytes transferred in that minute.Average = Average bytes transferred in that minute.However shouldn't all these values be the same if that were the case? I must be reading it wrong. Some help would be appreciated.I'm used to seeing 95th percentile graphs, is anything like that possible?Many Thanks,Ady

Hi there,Your interpretation is correct. For a given requested period:Minimum = minimum collected value during the requested periodMaximum = maximum collected value during the requested periodAverage = average bytes transferred during the requested periodSO, lets say you asked for a 5 minute metric and the collected data points were1, 2, 3, 5, 4The min would be 1, the max would be 5 and the average would be 3Whether the values are the same will depend on how many samples are actually taken in the period - the statistic SampleCount will give you that information.In terms of percentiles - that is good feedback. We are looking at additional statistics that will be useful. Do you look at other statistics beyond 95th percentile?

Hi Chris,Thanks for the response, that makes more sense now (especially the SampleCount graph).I realise that the data is provided in bytes deivered, as that is how data billed. When I mentioned the 95th percentile, that is because in the past we were billed on the 95th percentile figure.However it would be nice to see the Mbps to be able to determine how "full" a server is with regards to their network utilsation (i.e. if using 800Mbps on a 1Gbps port, it might be time to launch a new instance).I understand we can get an approximte figure by multiplying the sum by 8 and dividing by the interval duration.Many Thanks,Ady
Yes -- would definitely be great to see some more typical measurements, such as MBps.  Also, it would be huge to use commas to deliniate thousands, as I spend a lot of time just counting the zeros!

Really booting an AMI from an existing EBS Volume (not an EBS Snapshot) Is it possible to create an EBS backed AMI where the boot device (e.g. /dev/sda1) is mapped to an existing EBS *volume* ? I've been researching this for a couple of days and trying all sorts of things. It seems like this question was getting at the same thing:http://developer.amazonwebservices.com/connect/thread.jspa?messageID=157958&#157958And I can get as far as starting my AMI (which is based on an EBS snapshot) and having it create a new EBS volume of any size. This new EBS volume (let's call it vol-123) is not deleted when the machine shuts down (i.e. deleteOnTermination=F). But what's next? How do I start new instance (from an AMI) and have it use the existing EBS Volume vol-123 as the boot device? I think I could create a snapshot after changing the root file system, then update my AMI definition to reflect the new snapshot. Then I could terminate and spin back up maintaining hard drive state. But I really wanted to avoid having to remember to snapshot and update the AMI. If I was able to really boot from the EBS volume then this would all be much smoother. I could take snapshots for backup, but I would not lose changes to the root file system if I failed to snapshot. Is this possible or is "boot from EBS" really a misnomer and it should be "boot from EBS Snapshot into an EBS volume?"-JD

An AMI can't be "updated" to refer to a different snapshot - or at all. You'd need to create a new AMI with the new snapshot.  It sounds like you can use the Stop / Start controls instead of Terminate / Launch. Stopping an EBS-backed instance leaves the volume intact, ready to be booted from when you Start it again. In the mmeantime you're only charged for the EBS volume, not any CPU hours.

Shlomo, thanks for replying so quickly on a Sunday! I clearly don't grok a few things. I was under the impression I could alter attributes of an existing AMI (e.g. which snapshot the AMI is associated with) which, it appears I can't. Thanks for clearing that up. It makes sense that I could halt an instance and then bring it back without losing state. However, the workflow I was hoping to accomplish is to have an AMI running, then if I needed more RAM or more CPUs then I could terminate the instance and bring it back up with a larger machine type while maintaining state.If I understand how EBS backed AMIs work, this workflow is really quite hard to do. To take an existing instance which is booting from EBS and move to a higher CPU machine type I would have to do the following:1) Take a snapshot of the existing EBS2) create a new AMI based on the new snapshot3) terminate the "too small" instance4) bring up new EC2 instance based on the snapshot created in step #1 but using larger machine typeThen if I want to go back to the smaller machine type, I'd have to do all of these steps again. And every time I did this round trip I'd end up with 2 new AMIs and 2 new snapshots.Ugh. Just keeping track of the AMIs and EBS snapshots sounds like a bear. Even if I do a series of scripts this sounds tedious at best. Surely I'm not the first to have desired this workflow of shutting down, booting to a larger machine type, then back to the smaller machine type without losing state. Is there a simpler way?-JD

j_d_l wrote:
It makes sense that I could halt an instance and then bring it back without losing state. However, the workflow I was hoping to accomplish is to have an AMI running, then if I needed more RAM or more CPUs then I could terminate the instance and bring it back up with a larger machine type while maintaining state.
You can do this, except you bring it up from a powered off state.  Simple stop the AMI, then use the ModifyInstance call to change the instance type.  Then start the AMI, and you will have what you want.Comparing EC2 to the world of physical machines, "stop" is the equivalent of power off, "start" is power on, "terminate" is stop + remove the machine from the rack, and "run" is rack a machine and start it.  Make sense?

Peter, that is VERY helpful. I didn't realize I could change the instance type without terminating the instance. I just tested this using the command line tools and it worked like a champ. After stopping the instance I just ran the following:ec2-modify-instance-attribute <myInstanceID> -t m1.xlargeWhat was throwing me off with the physical world analogy, is in the physical world I have to pull a machine from the rack to change its machine type. Thus I was hung up on terminating the instance before changing type. I can now easily write a script that stops an instance, changes the instance type, then restarts. EXACTLY what I need to do! Thanks for your help. -JD

ELB - HTTPS - Security Warning | This connection is untrusted (DigiCERT) I've modified my load balancer to support https traffic, and uploaded the certificate. Everything seems to work fine, but I get a security warning when browsing to the site.eu.sub.our_unique_domain.com is using an invalid security certificate.The certificate is only valid for the following domains:  *.our_unique_domain.com , our_unique_domain.com  (Errorcode: ssl_error_bad_cert_domain)This is the command I've issued, and it returned succesfullelb-create-lb my_lb --availability-zones ap-southeast-1a ap-southeast-1b --listener "protocol=http,lb-port=80,instance-port=80" --listener "protocol=https,lb-port=443,instance-port=80,cert-id=arn:aws:iam::xxxxxx:server-certificate/xxxxxxxxxxx"Isn't this possible with this new elb feature?Best regards  Message was edited by: hranum

Your certificate is a wildcard cert for *.our_unique_domain.com, but wildcard certs only match a single level of subdomains. So that cert would be valid for sub.our_unique_domain.com but not for eu.sub.our_unique_domain.com. This is how wildcard certs work.

Amazon LINUX AMI (64bit)Use of XFS for EBS volumes as recomended by Eric? All,I am using Amazon LINUX AMI(64 bit) to create my infrastructure. I was following steps as dictated by wonderful eric's article for "Running mySQL on EBS.I created a volume and attached to the instance( as can be seen in attached file) .A volume is attached to /dev/sdfBut when i execute command sudo mkfs.xfs /dev/sdfIt returns/dev/sdf : no such file or directory.Please help - Since i can see this volume attached to the instance. Why system is saying its not there?.Is it Amazon Linux AMI doesn't allow other volumes to attach to the instance.????

Due to a device name change in the newer kernels used by the Amazon Linux AMI, the block devices are now named /dev/xvdX instead of /dev/sdX. in your case, I think you would want to check whether the /dev/xvdf device appears. We're working on a way to make this simpler for Amazon Linux AMI users.
Thank you !. I will try reading with new device name.So does that mean while creating and attaching volume to my instance i should give/dev/xvd X instead of /dev/sd X as device name

Sadly, not yet. Older kernels on other AMIs will continue to see the attached devices as sdX while newer kernels will see them as xvdX. At attach time we have no real way of knowing how the kernel in the AMI will name the device. There are various ways to deal with the naming discrepancy, such as filesystem labels (using LABEL=xxx in fstab instead of the device name) or filesystem UUIDs (using UUID=xxx in fstab). We are working on a better and more deterministic solution for this though.

Thanks christian for your reply. But can we somehow via command line detect what the kernel in AMI named the device.  You mentioned "There are various ways to deal with the naming discrepancy, such as filesystem labels (using LABEL=xxx in fstab instead of the device name) or filesystem UUIDs (using UUID=xxx in fstab). We are working on a better and more deterministic solution for this though. "  How i can attach my volume to the instance using LABELS/UUID's. ? Can you provide me little detail with command if possible. Thanks Sumeer

To detect what block devices you end up with on the system, there are various places you can look at. You could look at /proc/partitions and infer from there which devices you end up with. You can also look at the /sys/block/ directory listing and see again which devices you have on the system after attaching a block device.Once you have found the device, you can put a filesystem on it (be it ext[234] or xfs) and label it accordingly using a flag like -L my_label_name. ie,mkfs.xfs -L my_label_name ... /dev/xvdformkfs.ext3 -L my_label_name ... /dev/xvdgOnce that is done, in /etc/fstab you can list the device for mounting like this:LABEL=my_label_name /data ext3 noauto 0 0Also, when a filesystem is created, a unique UUID is automatically assigned to it - you can also use that to mount using UUID=uuid syntax instead of LABEL=label syntax I showed above. Commands such as xfs_admin or tune2fs can be used to manipulate/extract the label and UUID data for filesystems already created.

more ram on 32bit? Hi,I am trying to use EC2 to run a Linux application that has some issues with running on a 64 bit system. However, I would want to use an instance with a RAM larger than 1.7GB (that's the max I see on 32bit Linux). Is there a way I can either get more RAM on 32 bit or use only 32bits on the 64 bit instance (if that's even possible)?Please let me know.Thanks!

I'm sure your refering to this http://aws.amazon.com/ec2/instance-types/for the list of instance types and its memory.It's not possible to  increase the memory on 32bit. Why not recompile your program on the 64bit to be able to run it?

The software I'm using is developed by someone else and some users have reported errors in certain functions when using on a 64bit machine. It also takes a long time to run, so I didn't want to start the run and let it go only to find out it didn't work at the end. Do you know if there is a way around for this?

We also have the same issue with being stuck with a 32-bit third party application on a 32-bit windows server instance with only 1.7G memory. It's constantly crashing due to out-of-memory errors. We will need 4G RAM at the very least for the server to function normally.Would someone at Amazon AWS take action on this problem please.

You should be able to set up a system using 32-bit libraries within a chroot on a 64-bit OS.  For example if you are using ubuntu, see (rather old, but it probably still mostly works if you update the distro names): http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=24575

Can I set up EC2 to allow several users to log in simultaneously Hi, I'd like to use EC2 to set up a test environment for some software. The software is normally installed on the desktop, so if it's on EC2 then the user will need to Remote Desktop or similar to the EC2 machine and then run the software. Is the number of concurrent users for Remote Desktop limited, and if so to how many? Is there some other straightforward and free way to allow multiple people to log on to an EC2 machine?Or if that's not possible, can I set up a single IP address they can use and it'd automatically send people to different EC2 instances? (I suspect that would be harder...)many thanks, Rory

You can't if it is a client windows install (xp/vista/7/etc).  Most Windows server OSes are configured with 2 "Remote Administration" sessions.    Not sure what the Amazon windows instances are licensed for user wise... I would assume at least 2 clients can login fine (Windows Server 2003 / Windows Server 2008).  -Roger

How to increase EC2 instance RAM size... HI,  I am using Amazon EC2 instance (small instance) with windows server 2008, 32 bit & 1.7 GB RAM .Now I need to increase my RAM size, can i update to 4 GB or higher..?Pls let me Know if there is any provision for this.Thanks
You have to start a new instance.  You should be able to migrate the EBS disk from your old instance over though.  Just make sure to make a snapshot first!
Thanks, but if i migrate my EBS disk will all my setting, data's, IIS congiguration, SQL database wont be affected...?

I have no idea, I don't do windows.  Try making an AMI from your current machine and booting up a new instance using it.  See what happens.  That's the beauty of EC2... you can try it out and if it doesn't work, just terminate it and delete the AMI.  No muss no fuss.

We also have the same dilemma where Amazon drop down choices for 32-bit windows instance only go as high as 5 virtual core cpu and 1.7G memory max. They don't have any options for higher memory resources.
Oh yeah, as long as you are on 32bit you have no options for more memory.  1.7GB is the max.

Security Group deleted I have a security group that I wanted to make a change of the name on and I managed to delete it.  The instance it was applied to, however, still shows it listed on the instance itself and the group is no longer listed as an available security group for me to edit.  Any way to fix this?  The instance is i-e621f78b  Thanks
You can't change an instance's security group once it is started. You'll have to terminate it and start a new one.
Thanks.  I don't really want to change it, just fix what I did.  The security group still shows up on the instance as applied to it but it doesn't show up in my list of security groups
You're out of luck.  You can't "undelete" a security group, and you can't change an instance's security group assignments without a terminate/relaunch.

Transfer data EC2 -> S3 Hi there  I have +- 4TB sitting on a posix-compliant distributed filesystem across 4 EC2 nodes with 1x1TB EBS volumes each.  I'd like to get all that data onto S3, but it's tremendously slow trying to do any sort of mass-transfer using the API.  I'm using Tim Kay's aws tool, and it takes +- 1 sec per file, and I have 2mil+ files.  Is there any facility to do bulk transfters from EC2 -> S3 within the same region?  Thank!

There isn't.  S3 is HTTP based and requires a discreet HTTP transaction per object.  One second sounds really bad, however.  Are you launching this tool once per object?  You might do better with a tool that can handle multiple files without relaunching.  I use s3cmd.  http://s3tools.org/s3cmd

HTPS proxy, migrating from mod_proxy to ELB Hello,I used to have my tomcat running HTTS using JKS keystore. Then i migrated to mod_proxy and for that i extracted the key and cert using openssl and a the process described here: http://conshell.net/wiki/index.php/Keytool_to_OpenSSL_Conversion_tipsNow, when i try to import the cert to ELB i get this error:400 MalformedCertificate Invalid Public Key Certificate.# iam-servercertupload -b exported-pem.crt  -c cabundle.pem -k exported-pkcs8.key -s govCert400 MalformedCertificate Invalid Private Key.The pk and cert are valid (ssl is running on apache). How can i debug this or get more details on the error?
Got the same exactt issue right now.

Hello,The IAM certificate upload process will only accept private keys in the SSLeay format and not PKCS#8 formatted keys. To proceed, you can convert the private key into the SSLeay format using the following command.$ openssl pkcs8 –nocrypt -in pkcs8-pri-key.pem -out ssleay-pri-key.pemWe'll be updating our documentation shortly to include this information.

Thanks a lot Eric,I am trying the command on my local machine and server, but it does not return. well, it is hanging for > 10 min here at least.Is it possible to print what openssl is doing? or this conversion really takes that long?
The command never returns
It seems the -nocrypt option is responsible for the hanging. Perhaps, trying without this option will do the trick.  HTH, ingenion

It seems that http://169.254.169.254/2008-02-01 and http://169.254.169.254/2008-02-01/meta-data are working fine, it is just http://169.254.169.254/2008-02-01/user-data actually that is throwing the error.

Hi raughan2,The application appears to be trying to access the instance metadata service, which is described in some detail in the User Guide:http://docs.amazonwebservices.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/AESDG-chapter-instancedata.htmlhttp://docs.amazonwebservices.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/instancedata-data-categories.htmlYou might see if you can change it to request http://169.254.169.254/latest/user-data instead; as the previous datestamp may be unavailable in this context.Regards,-Jason
http://169.254.169.254/latest/user-data also gives me a 404 error. I am trying to hit this from the Windows AMI image itself. So there shouldn't be anything blocking from my side.

From the documentation you provided, I found this:"Requests for a general metadata resource (i.e. an URI ending with a/) return a list of available resources or a 404HTTP error code if there is no such resource."So how do I get user-data to populate on the url? What data should be there?

You can make any sort of data available to your instance by setting the user-data instance attribute.  If you didn't provide any, you'll get a 404 at the latest/user-data URL.You can specify the data when you start an instance for the first time, and you can change it when the instance is stopped, but you can't change it while the instance is running.

Ok, so the Bamboo server must auto-populate these fields when it initiates an instance. Because I am starting it via the EC2 console, they must not be being created. Does that sound possible?So sounds like I need to go bang on their door some more.Thank you for the explanation.

Hi,J. Drukman is quite right: if you launch an instance with specifying user data you'll get a 404 when trying to retrieve the user data from within the instance.Judging from our records of the two instances you launched only 1 had user data specified.
OK, then it is Bamboo specifying the data.Thank you all very  much. I will focus my attention on the Bamboo side.-Dennis

Will EBS backed instances survive a failure/crash/reboot of its host? I started to experiment with EC2 micro instances and have been operating under the assumption that my instances are more or less "safe" from being lost since they are able to be shutdown and rebooted. After playing with UEC I am now wondering if that assumption is actually incorrect.  If for some reason the host for my EBS backed instances goes down will the instance be lost? Or will it come back after the host has come back online? I would ask the same question for whatever other magical components are involved in keeping my instances alive.  I realize that there is always the possibility that a drive will crash or fail and that even if it was a dedicated physical server I could lose the system. However, servers do go down for not fatal reasons... hopefully more often than they actually crash hard. In the case that there is a non fatal interruption of service, I need to know if I should be prepared to rebuild my instance or if I can assume that it will come back online on its own.

Hi there    Your are right in your assumption that EBS backed instances are highly durable and can survive failure of underlying hardware, instance crashes and reboots. We would still suggest to customers to take appropriate measures to safe guard there data and instances . There is no substitute for a proper backup plan in place for any server be it a physical box in your office or an Amazon instance running in EC2. We have a number of tools available to customers to help you with this task AMI bundling- This allows you to take snap shots of Amazon instances that you have configured and turn them into AMI's that you can launch and have running in seconds should you have a failure. Snap Shots - You can take point in time snapshots of your EBS volumes allowing you to convert them into volumes for use on new instances or for backup purposes. I have included a link to the main EBS page that has lots of useful information on EBS for your to review.https://aws.amazon.com/ebs/
Instances do not come back from the dead by themselves.  If you want that behavior, you can use auto scaling.

make a bootable snapshot of your EBS volume. I must be missing something...how do you make an EBS snapshot into a bootable AMI?I know you can do this through the API's but there must be an easier way...
The command line tool ec2-register will do it.  (use the -s option to pass the snapshot id)

Are the prices of reserved instances inclusive of storage? Are the prices of reserved instances inclusive of storage?Say I use a micro-instance with the 15Gb of EBS storage that comes as standard, will the storage costs and the IO costs be added?I find the storage parts a bit rather confusing.
Reserved instances only affect the instance hourly rate.  Storage is always separate and always one price.

Cannot remote desktop to machine following reboot I stopped my windows machine earlier by going to shut down in windows. It then appeared stopped in the console. Later I restarted it via the console but I can no longer remote desktop do it. I have tried re downloading the RDP link from the console.Any ideas please??ThanksPaul
by the way. my instance ID is i-ab3467dc

Maximum number of entries with ec2-authorize Is there an a) enforced and/or b) practical limit on the number of separate IP ranges that can be authorised to access an instance using the ec2-authorize ?  Could I authorize 1,400 IP ranges?

I think that there used to be a limit of 100 rules per security group; however, the API reference has the following comment for AuthorizeSecurityGroupIngress.  This seems to indicate that there isn't an enforced limit.  "Adding hundreds of rules to a security group might cause problems when you access the instance. We recommend you condense your rules as much as possible."

ebs is not deleted on termination if detached before termination If I launch my instance with an EBS volume created from a snapshot, it will not automaticly delete on termination if the volume is detached before terminating. How can I solve this?
ec2-run-instances -b /dev/sdf=snap-xxxxx -t m1.small

Cannot add EC2 member to EC2 Domain Controller I cannot add an EC2 instance to a domain i created in EC2.WINS/DNS seems OK.Cannot find network pathAnyone come across how to setup an EC2 domainproperly please?I am following the "Citrix XenApp for AMazon EC2" document and it leaves a lot out...
Did you install the DNS roll on your DC? Have you configured your non-DC servers to go to your DC for DNS (one of the DNS servers in list)?

Your instance may be on a different subnet from your domain server. I am also looking for info on how to setup an AD Domain. Since you have no control over the internal IP and subnet, and they can change when restarting an instance I know of no way to get this to work.

By default, Instances are configured to use AWS's internal DNS servers via DHCP.Obviously, these DNS servers do not contain any record for your new domain's SOA.Did you add your DC as a DNS server in the machine you are trying to join?Jonathan@CloudStacking.com

The feedback I got from amazon was to assign an elastic ip to your DNS server then set the dns server in your instances to that address. I haven't made that work yet so I think I'm missing a step like setting up the elastic ip address in DNS.

Did you ever got this resolved?I am using Elastic IP address for my Domain Controller as well as for another machine. But when I try to join DC from this second machine, I got timeout error:The following error occurred when DNS was queried for the service location (SRV) resource record used to locate an Active Directory Domain Controller for domain XXXXXXXXXX:The error was: "This operation returned because the timeout period expired."(error code 0x000005B4 ERROR_TIMEOUT)The query was for the SRV record for _ldap._tcp.dc._msdcs.XXXXXXThe DNS servers used by this computer for name resolution are not responding. This computer is configured to use DNS servers with the following IP addresses:XXXXXXXXXIf you have any document/help on this, please share.Thanks!

I can't reach my http server I can't reach my http server. Locally it works fine (e.g telnet localhost 80 or telnet <private IP> 80).The security group is also set up correctly for port 80. The ports 22 work fine. I disable  selinuxIs there anyone from Amazon that can help please?Many thanks

Hi there you have not posted your instance ID so I can't check out the status of you server. Common problems that could be effecting your ability to access your instance from another machine is your security groups in AWS console not configured correctly to allow traffic on port 80 or a problem on the firewall inside your instance blocking traffic to port 80.If your still having problems please post the instance id and we will check it out for you.
EC2 Instance: i-87e2bff0Thank you

Sorry I can not fix the problem, EC2 Instance: i-87e2bff0There are no active firewall:iptables -Fiptables -Xiptables -Ziptables -P INPUT ACCEPTiptables -P OUTPUT ACCEPTiptables -P FORWARD ACCEPTI disabled selinuxI created a security group but I can not reach the server on port 80. Can someone help me?thank you

Hi there I have checked out your instance and I noticed in you security group in the aws console is only permitting SSH traffic. you will need to add a rule to permit port 80 in this security group and your instance will be accessible from the web.

Disitribution of Elastic Loadbalancer traffic Is it an expected behavior of the Elastic Loadbalancer to distribute traffic from all klients behind a single IP to the same instance?  A lot of our costumers are schools, big and small, and as I can see all traffic from one school will end up on the same instance? This means that you have to prepare the performance of every single instances to be able to take all the load from on of these single klilent locations.  Can this be correct?

Hi there I think you will need to have a look at the Elastic Load Balancer documentation. I have included a link at the bottom of this post.Typically your load balancer uses round robin method of selecting an instance to serve your request. unless you use sticky sessions. this is all covered in the documentation.If you do a google search for "Howto use Elastic Load balancing"there are multiple results that discusse how to use an ELBPlease let us know if you have any further questions when you have reviewed the ELB documentation.  http://aws.amazon.com/documentation/elasticloadbalancing/

Import Key Pair API I try to use the EC2 Query API for ImportKeyPair. After I generate the public key and pass it in the query (base64 encoded) I get the following error: "An internal error has occurred. Error code: InternalError". I tried importing the same key through the command API: ec2-import-keypair and it worked. I used (SSH2-RSA 1024, 2048, and 4096).Am I doing something wrong?<!--Session data-->

oostar,Please send me a private message with your query parameters, or the full HTTP request and I will investigate. I would recommend that you generate a new 'throw-away' key for this purpose.Are you using the GET or POST HTTP method? Large GET requests can cause issues with many HTTP proxies and clients - and Base64 encoded keys can lead to fairly large requests.RegardsMarc
extend memory on 64bit windows instance Is it possible to extend the memory on a 64bit windows instance without recreating a new instance (and re-install all the software)?  Thanks Marco
Hi Marco,It is not possible to grow the memory in the same instance size. You try to bundle your instance and then launch the AMI with a new instance size.Best regards,Mario
Ok, but you can create an image of the original instance and restore that instance into a bundle with more memory?  Thanks

ec2config fails to start Hi,  Has anyone else had an issue with ec2config failing to start?  I've been working on an EBS AMI for Windows 2003 and generally everything works.  The big exception is that seemingly randomly the ec2config service will fail to automatically start.  This causes a nasty popup to appear stating that a service or driver failed to start up properly and effectively brings my instance up in an inconsistent state.  Like I said though, it doesn't happen for every instance created from the AMI and it changes from reboot-to-reboot.  For what it's worth, these are micro instances that I'm testing with.  Does anyone know how to fix this?  Thanks, Kevin

I have definitely and am currently experiencing the same issue. There seems to be no rhyme or reason to it. It looks like windows doesn't even try to start the Ec2Config Service -- there is nothing in the ec2config log files or in the system event log. There service is set to start up automatically. This even happens on an AMI that is snapshot from instance that has no problems with starting the EC2Config service. There is also nothing in the console output for the machineAlso I have seem some randomness in the ability to RDP into instances, as if the Terminal Services service is not starting. This does not bode well for using windows instances in EC2.

INTRA INSTANCE COMMUNICATION Assuming a configuration with single DB server (SQL) + multiple IIS/App servers which start/stop according to the load. What is the best practice to establish  communication between the IIS/APP servers and the SQL server ?  Should I use Elastic IP attached to the  SQL server ? (Does this effect speed or charges?)Should I use Elastic IP attached to the SQL server  just to obtain it's internal IP?I don't really need an Elastic IP for public access to the SQL server, so... is there any other option for the IIS/APP servers to discover the SQL server ? In this configuration how should the SQL, exposing port 1433 be guarded against attacks from the INTERNET or the EC2 CLOUD, not knowing ahead the IP's of it's callers ? Should I consider "central  IP hub application", running off an instance with elastic IP (so anyone know where it is) to synchronise dynamically the IP's of the server and clients (for access and dynamic configuration of the server's firewall) ?Apologize, I'm not intimate with VPC (and have no need for VPN with the outside world) ...If I create a VPC with all those instances can I serve HTTP requests   using some public IP/DNS ? Thx

Hi there nl65 I think you are asking two different questions here one about elastic ip addresses and their application and your second  question is about VPC.As you are probably aware when you start a new instance or restart an existing instance you will get a dhcp address assigned at start-up time.Your first QuestionAn elastic ip allows you to have a effectively a static address that you can map to you instances giving you clients a static point to attach to. These clients could be your Windows Server IIS machines attaching to your SQl server or it could be web users hitting your domain name that is associated with your Elastic ip which then attached to your web server.Your second QuestionVPC is you own Virtual Private Cloud that is connected to your router extending your companies network securely into the cloud. In this case you are basically running EC2 computing resources inside your own network. If you need to grant internet access to your EC2 resources from inside your VPC you would need to direct traffic via your own internet gateway and firewall equipment. One other note you cannot use elastic IP's inside a VPC as you are using you own network address numbering scheme in a VPC.I have included links to the documentation guides for EC2 and and VPC you can find more comprehensive instructions inside these guides.EC2 Documentationhttp://aws.amazon.com/documentation/ec2/VPC Documentation http://aws.amazon.com/documentation/vpc/ I hope this answers your questions.

You can use Elastic IP for the SQL Server instance, then use its domain name from your clients.  They will get the private IP address.  You do NOT need to open 1433 to the outside world.  Just set up a security group on the SQL Server instance that allow only the clients in.
So using the public DNS name is doing the trick!Thx

Amazon Linux AMI Kernel Source Version Mismatch Hello,I am trying to build some kernel modules for the Linux kernel using the Amazon Linux AMI. I am using ami-38c33651 (x86_64) with a micro instance.When I use yum to get the kernel source (kernel-devel.x86_64), it doesn't match the version of the kernel given by uname -r. Specifically, uname -r gives 2.6.34.6-54.24.amzn1.x86_64, but the source code I get from yum is 2.6.34.7-56.36.amzn1.x86_64.My modules seem to build, but the kernel won't load them, and I think this is why.Does anyone know what I have to do to get kernel source that matches my running kernel (or a kernel that matches this source)?

Hi Edward,Sorry you had trouble getting the correct kernel-devel package installed. There have been updates to the YUM repository for the kernel that you're not currently running. We do keep the previous versions in the repository that can be installed explicitly.To install the correct version run:sudo yum erase kernel-develsudo yum install kernel-devel-$(uname -r)Let us know if you have any other problems.

CPU and Disc Read Bottleneck We have been investigating the feasibility of using the EC2 service to host servers for an upcoming game; however, during testing we have discovered that we are experiencing extreme bottlenecking on both processing time and disk read despite using an extra-large instance running Windows Server 2008.The bottlenecks do not appear to be an issue when evaluating other comparable physical and virtual solutions, so we’re assuming that the problem is with our configuration settings. Some of the problems we’re seeing include:•    Close to a 400% increase in load time compared to comparable services.•    Inability to connect a client to the server for more than a second at most.If you have any immediate advice that may help use rectify the situation, we would greatly appreciate it. Thank you.
can't reboot or connect to instance something went haywire in our instance i-e3d5788b.  we can't connect to it with ssh or reboot it. any ideas how we can that to reboot?THANKS! Brad

I tried to use the reboot instances, but that isn't working... it does not use an EBS root volume and we have to get some data off the root of that machine if we can't reboot it.  anyone have any ideas?Thanks, Brad

Hi Brad,The physical host under your instance is in a degraded state, which is causing your instance to be unresponsive.  Unfortunately, it's unlikely that the instance can be restored to running order, so I recommend that you launch a replacement instance and fail away from this one.  I'd recommend for the future that you store persistent data on EBS volumes, which will help prevent data loss in the event of an individual instance failure.Regards,-Jason
Even larger memory instance Dear all,is it possible to get an instance with about 400 GB RAM?best regards

Hi Martin,Our instance types are listed at:http://aws.amazon.com/ec2/instance-types/The most memory that you can currently get on a single instance is about 68GB on our m2.4xlarge instance type.  You might consider whether your use case allows you to distribute your load across multiple servers, in which case you could provision several of these instances and split the work across them.Regards,-Jason

ELB instance out of service with auto scaling PROBLEM I've been setting up autoscaling for my various client sites, and I keep running into a problem where the ELB thinks all the instances are out of service, even though I can see the healthchecks in the apache log going through just fine.ELB name: ford-924753981.us-west-1.elb.amazonaws.comIt has one registered instance, i-0b66d04fIf I look at the apache log on the instance I see:10.160.79.21 - - [20/Oct/2010:11:47:54 -0700] "GET /ping HTTP/1.1" 200 1135 "-" "ELB-HealthChecker/1.0"10.160.79.21 - - [20/Oct/2010:11:48:00 -0700] "GET /ping HTTP/1.1" 200 1135 "-" "ELB-HealthChecker/1.0"10.160.79.21 - - [20/Oct/2010:11:48:06 -0700] "GET /ping HTTP/1.1" 200 1135 "-" "ELB-HealthChecker/1.0"Yet the ELB continues to think the instance is down.% elb-describe-instance-health fordINSTANCE_ID  i-0b66d04f  OutOfService  Instance has failed at least the UnhealthyThreshold number of health checks consecutively.  InstanceHow do I get the ELB to recognize the instance?
Of course, as soon as I wrote that post, it started working again.  But it was out of service for a good 15 minutes or so.... That's not acceptable.

I think I have a recipe for this:Create an ELBManually register some instances with itSet up auto scaling to use the same ELBLet auto scaling bring up an instance and register itDe-register all the manually-registered instancesThe auto-scaled instance will go Out Of Service for a few minutes, even though health checks are happening normally.

Amazon Linux: su command not working properly. Hi there!!  I am starting to use Amazon Linux. I have installed a series of deamons that run as non-root users: apache, hudson, etc.  It is quite convenient for me to do, for instance:  su -l hudson  impersonating the user to make some maintenance work. Such as test PATHs, access to tools, filesystem permissions, etc.  However su -l is not working, and you are always stock as ec2-user. Even if I do "sudo bash" before, and try from root.  I am having also problems with deamons that use "su" during their init scripts, to run as another user.  Regards, R.

I am sorry to hear that you are having issues with the "su" command.  Do you get any sort of errors when you try to run "su -l hudson"?Most system users such as apache have a shell of /sbin/nologin which prevents you from logging in with an interactive shell.  You can get around this temporarily by running "su -l apache -s /bin/bash".  This will cause "su" to run /bin/bash rather than the default shell of "/sbin/nologin".

IP changed with no reason We have created a machine on EC2 and assigned an elastic IP for it. The AMI ID was ami-d28470bb, Elastic IP - 75.101.148.164.The details of the machine after the attachment of the IP were – public DNS ec2-75-101-148-164.compute-1.amazonaws.com, private DNS ip-10-120-15-34 Inside the machine, hostname command returned the private DNS and gethostip –d `hostname` returned the internal IP. A few hours later, something has changed on the machine, hostname suddenly returned ec2-75-101-148-135.compute-1.amazonaws.com which is actually another machine we have created the same time as this one. After noticing this change, "gethostip –d `hostname`" now returns the internal IP of that machine which is incorrect.Has someone noticed such a behavior? What may cause this?

Kernel with high-res timer I need to have a kernel with CONFIG_HZ=1000 or higher. I can't find any info on the kernels available. Can I add my own kernels? Is there a list of all kernels with detailed specifications? Is there a kernel (more recent than 2.6.18) which have CONFIG_HZ=1000? I am currently on the 2.6.21 and it definitely does not have CONFIG_HZ=1000!Thank you

Update: I just tried kernel 2.6.18 which is supposed to have CONFIG_HZ=1000, however, testing the resolution of the timer revealed that it is most likely not the case:Linux domU-12-31-39-03-41-85 2.6.18-xenU-ec2-v1.0, usleep(100): Operation took 990 microseconds.usleep(100) taking 990us...Any help on that?
Anyone?

There hasn't been much said about AKIs by AWS in a long time.Some other threads related to the same question remain open:http://developer.amazonwebservices.com/connect/thread.jspa?threadID=30951http://developer.amazonwebservices.com/connect/thread.jspa?threadID=40872Canonical (publisher of Ubuntu) has been making more modern versions of the kernel, and - maybe - one of them is set to 1000Hz?

I feel like trying every single kernel isn't an quick task... anyone know a kernel that is compiled with CONFIG_HZ=1000?  As I mentioned, I tried the 2.6.18 and the results of my tests shows that it does not use High-res timers.
Maybe my test isnt really reliable. Using aki-9b00e5f2 gives better results, tho not perfect. There might be other factors.
The AKI mentioned seems to perform better.

You're on the right track with aki-9b00e5f2	  root@domU-12-31-39-14-20-C2:/etc# uname -a Linux aws3.voipmax 2.6.18-xenU-ec2-v1.0 #2 SMP Tue Feb 19 10:51:53 EST 2008 i686 GNU/Linux root@domU-12-31-39-14-20-C2:/etc# zgrep HZ /proc/config.gz  # CONFIG_HZ_100 is not set  CONFIG_HZ_250 is not set  CONFIG_HZ_1000=y CONFIG_HZ=1000 CONFIG_NO_IDLE_HZ=y  ami_id=ami-ce44a1a7 ami_manifest_path=alestic/ubuntu-8.04-hardy-base-20080430.manifest.xml aki_id=aki-9b00e5f2	 ari_id=ari-a51cf9cc  So far this is the only 1000Hz kernel I've found.

Have you considered providing your own kernel? In July, Amazon provided a number of PVGRUB AKI's that will allow you to boot custom kernels within EC2. There are a couple requirements and but in cases where you have a need for a specific kernel or kernel feature, PVGRUB is a logical choice. http://developer.amazonwebservices.com/connect/entry.jspa?externalID=3967&categoryID=174  Message was edited by: Ben@AWS

Root Partition on Instances Created from AMI are only 2 Gigs When I create an instance from my AMI, the root partition only has 2 gigs on it.  Why is this?  I thought standard disk size was 10 gigs.  Can anyone help me increase the size of the drive when I spin up a new image from the AMI?  I'm at a loss as to why it's starting up with only 2 gigs.  Here's what df shows:  /dev/sda1            2015824        1792540    120884          94% / /dev/sda2            350891748    219952      332847516   1% /mnt none                    894360            0                 894360          0% /dev/shm
Just run resize2fs on the partition.

Maximum time of instance running? Hi all,is there a way to set the maximum time you want an instance running?I mean, if the running time of an instance is bigger than X, terminate it automatically Thanks!!Victor
Not via the API.  You could just schedule a job on your system (if it's unix, use cron or at) to call the termination API at a specific time.

PCI Compliance - TCP reset and BGP Hi,  I'm struggling to find a solution to the following vulnerability flagged up by a PCI compliancy scan. Any help or pointers would be greatly appreciated.  Description: TCP reset using approximate sequence number Severity: Potential Problem CVE: CVE-2004-0230  Impact: A remote attacker could cause a denial of service on systems which rely upon persistent TCP connections. Background: The Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) is the protocol used by services such as telnet, ftp, and smtp to establish a connection between a client and a server. Every TCP packet includes a sequence number in the header to ensure that all packets are received at the destination and re-assembled in the correct order. The sequence numbering begins with an initial sequence number which is chosen by the server and sent to the client when the connection is established. Thus, sequence numbers also help to verify the identity of the client, since only the intended client has knowledge of the initial sequence number. The Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) is a TCP protocol used by routers to exchange routing information. It is primarily used by Internet service providers.  Resolution: To correct this problem on Cisco devices, apply one of the fixes referenced in the Cisco security advisories for [http://www.cisco.com/warp/public/707/cisco-sa-20040420-tcp-ios.shtml] IOS and [http://www.cisco.com/warp/public/707/cisco-sa-20040420-tcp-nonios.shtml] non-IOS operating systems. Refer to [http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/415294#systems] US-CERT Vulnerability Note VU#415294 and [http://www.uniras.gov.uk/niscc/docs/re-20040420-00391.pdf?lang=en] NISSC vulnerability advisory 236929 for other vendor fixes. If a fix is not available, this problem can be worked around by using a secure protocol such as [http://rfc.net/rfc2411.html] IPsec, or by filtering incoming connections to services such as BGP which rely on persistent TCP connections at the firewall, such that only allowed addresses may reach them.  Vulnerability Details: Service: tcp sent spoofed RST packet, received RST packet  The target IP is an instance with the Linux AMI.  Thanks
This came up earlier but no one from AWS commented on it:  http://developer.amazonwebservices.com/connect/thread.jspa?messageID=173732
Oh thanks for pointing this out. I did do a search before posting but this one didn't come up.  I will make sure I follow this post too.
That's the exact same error we have been getting trying to pass this security metrics test!I'm guessing that's who you are using as well?
Yep, spot on.  Come on, there must be someone who has run into the same issue and solved it or someone in the Amazon team that knows this...
Well we are facing the same issue with SecurityMetrics. I hope someone from Amazon can look into this as soon as possible!

Presuming that I'd get no quick joy from Amazon on this I sent off a query to SecurityMetrics directly.  Then I found this posting:http://forums.cpanel.net/f5/irresolvable-pci-scan-failure-167610.htmlwhich discusses SecurityMetrics and this failurel.  The post says a SM user received an email from SecurityMetrics stating that this may be a false positive scan.  He suggests contacting support at SecurityMetrics to get on some mailing list.So - suggest you do the same!
Thanks tdsproule, very helpful indeed. I asked my SM contact if this was a false positive and I'm still waiting for a reply. It's reassuring to know it may well be the case.

Well it turned out to be a bit of a red herring!  After speaking with Security Metrics technical support it looks like they had some issues around the threat level associated with vulnerability tests.   CVE-2004-0230 was incorrectly flagged at risk level '10'.  They simply re-ran a scan against our service and we returned to our normal passing status.  Suggest you simply manually re-run your scan.

The problem lies in the kernel configuration. The current beta version of the Amazon Linux AMI is using a newer pv_ops kernel. A new CONFIG_XEN_MAX_DOMAIN_MEMORY kernel configuration parameter was introduced in the upstream pv_ops kernel. An error in our configuration file merging reverted the value of this parameter to 32 when we were updating the kernel.This issue will be corrected with the next refresh of the AMI.
Ah, okay. Can you give me an ETA on the next refresh of the AMI? Are there docs anywhere for doing a kernel update on an existing instance so I can grab these changes for my AMIs?

AWS Linux AMI in Singapore doesn't ask for passphrase when login? I launched the Linux 32bit AMI in US-West and US-East. Using WinSCP to launch PuTTY, I am asked for the passphrase that matches my key. That looks OK. When launching the same type of AMI in the Singapore region no passphrase asked, that's what I get in the console:  Using username "ec2-user". Authenticating with public key "imported-openssh-key"         __|  __|_  )  Amazon Linux AMI        _|  (     /     Beta       ___|\___|___|  See /etc/image-release-notes for latest release notes.  [ec2-user@ip-10-128-147-45 ~]$  Am I missing something here? Is there a security step missing?  Thanks  Fred

Hi Fred,The passphrase handling for ssh is in the client. Perhaps the ssh key you're using in the Singapore region isn't protected by a passphrase?A quick way to check with the standard openssh tools is to ask for the fingerprint for the private key:# ssh-keygen -y -f your-key.pemIf you're not asked for a passphrase, then that private key is not protected.

Amazon loadbalancer and 
 I've come across a "problem" with an LB running HTTP connections. Badly written clients that only send http requests using 
 instead of 
 eventually get 503 errors after a long delay.  I quoted "problem" because its not really amazon's fault. We should be sending CRLF instead. But I discovered this happens only when using the load balancers. Other web servers or proxy servers I had handy seems to accept it no problems (apache, litespeed, varnish and squid). I guess its some sort of pseudo standard?  I immediately suspected the loadbalancer is just parsing the http request incorrectly. We have it in sticky mode: Stickiness: AppCookieStickinessPolicy, cookieName='PHPSESSID' But disabling the stickiness all together did not help. I guess it is still parsing the requests anyway.  The temporary solution was quite obvious. Ive setup a loadbalancer with TCP for port 80 instead. Which works just fine. (I like stickyness, but its not absolutely necessary for us).  My suggestion - accept 
 based http requests too.

how enable  https with ec2 instance as a  non tech  person  how do i guide my technical team on enabling https  set up etc   regards tech conceptual pete
Its not a question for amazon aws. Your technical team should be easily able to research this. If you are using IIS for example then just search about IIS and SSL in google.

If you have a web server like "apache" being used to serve the HTTPS requests, use openssh to generate your self-signed keys or use the keys signed by certificate authorities like Verisign, Thawte, Comodo etc.Once you have procured/generated your keys, configure your Apache web server with the keys.    SSLCertificateFile  <Public Certificate Path>    SSLCertificateKeyFile <Private Certificate Path>    SSLCACertificateFile <CA Certificate Path>

As Niall pointed out this is not a question about the EC2 platform. The configuration and setup of and SSL/HTTPS server on an EC2 instance is exactly the same as on any other computer, there are no special considerations. Your technical team should handle this exactly like they would any other server, and follow steps appropriate to whatever specific software platform you are running. The hardware platform is irrelevant.  Good luck...

Persistence & Idempotency for AMI's Dear All,We have been trying out EC2 possibilities. But the problems we face are Persistence, Scalability & Idempotency. Kindly suggest  measures to take care of these. Though this has been reiterated in forums time & again, still none of them can give concrete solutions.Do help please ...
Can you give a more detail on each of your requirements?  What exactly do you mean for each Persistence, Scalability and Idempotency?

Thanks, Peter for your prompt reply. By Persistence I mean how can I not lose data when my instance fails.By Scalability I mean whether I can scale up (or down) my RAM / CPU etc. as and when the need arises.By Omnipresence I mean how can I ensure that my instance is almost always up and running.Please help.

Elastic Block Storage offers persistence.  EBS volumes are stored independently of the instance and will continue to persist even if the instance itself fails.  You can even have the root storage device persist after the instance shuts down, so you can bring it back up on another instance.For scaling, you have two main options.  The primary scaling mechanism in EC2 is adding more instances; this is a scale out architecture.  So if your web server is getting overloaded, add a second on and load balance between them.  The other option is to run a larger instance size and move your volumes over; this does result in some downtime, but allows you to grow the CPU/RAM but use your existing EBS volumes.Lastly, Elastic Load Balancers can provide Omnipresence.  You can use ELB with autoscaling and CloudWatch to guarantee that you always have N identical machines running, and make sure requests go to to functional instances only.  If an instance fails, then ELB will stop sending it requests (in as little as 6 seconds) and autoscaling will automatically start a replacement instance.Does this help?
That's Great! Could you please refer me some links on how to load balance between multiple webserver instances as mentioned in your post. Thanks again.
Got an impression. Lets close this..

Hi,You should take a look at AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM), http://aws.amazon.com/iam. IAM allows you to create your own Users for each  individual that needs to access the AWS resources and services in your AWS Account. Each User will have its own unique set of credentials and can only access what you have given them permissions to.IAM will enable you to create a unique User for each of your clients and define exactly what they are allowed to access (thus limiting their access) and when they are done, then you can simply either delete the user or just delete the users access keys, or revoke their permissions....anders

swap partition on t1.micro Hello, friends!I have run new t1.micro instance with Ubuntu 10.10 (ami-508c7839). After it has been running for a while I detected, that there is no swap partition.I have investigated this issue and found this record at small version of other machine:/dev/sda3 none swap sw,comment=cloudconfig 0 0I have included this record in my fstab, but swap partition still is not available!What have I done wrong?Thanks in advance to your help!Dima

Dima,IMHO you cannot have local filesystem for micro instances. They only support EBS. So you had to create an EBS volume and use it as swap.I wonder if anybody is doing this? I guess it is easier to use a bigger instance with more RAM.kind regards,b.--http://www.munzandmore.com/tag/cloud-computing

In general, my application is quite well running with 512 Mb RAM, but sometimes I expect spikes in memory consumptions and want to be prepared for such cases!Swap will give me time to react without system's crash. I don't know what will happen when system will run out of RAM without swap.Regards,Dima

You can create a swap file without needing a dedicated swap partition:    SWAPFILE=/mnt/swapfile.swap   dd if=/dev/zero of=$SWAPFILE bs=1M count=512   mkswap $SWAPFILE   swapon $SWAPFILE   Adjust SWAPFILE and the size (count=?) as desired, and make sure that the swapon call gets called on boot by adding to rc.local or whatever.

Thanks! It looks like solution I was thinking about... But I was wandering, why it doesn't work with /sda3? I just can think about "money issue", when using /sda3 you don't pay "per I/O" as in case of small and large virtual machine. In case of t1.micro we pay less per hous, but pay more per additional features

I just promoted an instance of that AMI directly to a new DC in a new forest using on-host DNS role without issue.  Can you explain the exact steps you are taking?Also, it would be helpful if you include the instance ID of the instance you are having trouble with, especially since you mention a "hang" at the meta-data line.Keep in mind, you cannot set a static IP on the instance in our environment, or it will not be able to access the network.  Also, when you "stop" and ebs-backed instance using the EC2 tools, when it starts again, it will start with a different IP.  When you say "reboot", do you really mean "reboot" or are you fully stopping the instance?To approximate a "static IP", you must leave the instance as DHCP, but map an Elastic IP to that instance.  Other instances can refer to the "Static" instance with the Elastic IP, but, in the instance's TCP settings, it still needs to be set as DHCP.Again, the instance ID will help, but we should know the exact steps you are taking, first.

Thank you Ryan for your assistance.First and foremost its my ignorance based on your instruction; I've been tying static ips based on ipconfig. To provide you with my sequence: ( At the Windows GUI, after initial login.)1. Changed admin password2. Unchecked EC2Config Tool3. Changed computer name (Reboot OS)4. Login with new admin password ( Always worked)5. Placed static IPs and DNS: Machine's IP as primary, Your DNS IP Alternate (Mistake as you indicated)7. Run dcpromo (Reboot OS)8. Attempt log-in ( Would fail)9. Reboot the AMI instance ( Referenced; hang at meta-data line)Your explanation has provided great guidance. (I'm still digesting)So when I join a Win member server, the same Elastic IP proceedure applies?Anything specific with DNS?Again thank you
For anyone who runs into this. When you dcpromo a machine it locks out the machine login. you must login using the new domain name e.g. newdomainname/administrator

Fiddled with fstab now I can't access my instance, how do I overcome? /dev/sdf: The superblock could not be read or does not describe a correct ext2filesystem.  If the device is valid and it really contains an ext2filesystem (and not swap or ufs or something else), then the superblockis corrupt, and you might try running e2fsck with an alternate superblock:    e2fsck -b 8193 <device>[FAILED]*** An error occurred during the file system check.*** Dropping you to a shell; the system will reboot*** when you leave the shell.Give root password for maintenance(or type Control-D to continue):

If your instance is EBS-backed, then stop your instance, attach the volume to another instance, fix fstab, detach the volume, and start your instance.  If your instance is S3-backed, you're out of luck and have to start a new instance.

No they are under 20 different accounts. Each student has their own.   Any other solutions? Don, would your script help in this case?  Thanks!

You could whip up a script similar to Don's, but you'd have to have a list of all of the credentials (access key id + secret access key) for all of the accounts.  For a quick solution, you could hard-code them into the script, or if you want to get fancy, pull them from a database.  There are popular libraries for both PHP and ASP.NET that you could use.

correlation of location to region In documentation referencing ec2 images and s3 buckets, it is unclear whether or not there is expected to be a 1:1 mapping of regions to location.Currently more than 1 image provider has taken to the convention of creating buckets like:<bucketname>-us or <bucketname>-eubut also, some have a naming convention like:<bucketname>-us-east-1 or <bucketname>-eu-west-1Since buckets cannot be renamed, and ami's not moved between buckets without re-registration, it would surely be nice if amazon could indicate which (if either) is correct.Essentially, what I'd like to know, is if a new region 'us-west-1' were created, would it be able to launch instances from buckets with the location set to US?  Or, will there be a new location of 'us-west-1' or "US2" ?--[1] http://docs.amazonwebservices.com/AWSEC2/latest/CommandLineReference/index.html?ApiReference-cmd-MigrateImage.html

To paraphrase your question:Will a us-west-1 be a new region or a new availability zone?If it's a region then buckets are not visible outside their own region's endpoint.If it's an availability zone then buckets are visible in any availability zone inside the region.(I would guess the answer will be that us-west-1 will be a region).

Shlomo:  I don't think your paraphrase is an accurate representation of the question.  You are assuming that region=location which is one of the possible answers (and possibly the correct one).EC2 has the concepts of region and availability zones.  S3 has an additional concept of "location" which is used in an option like "--location US".In the document Scott pointed to above it says "Amazon EC2 attempts to determine the region from the location of the Amazon S3 bucket."  To me, "attempts" implies that there may be more than one EC2 region per S3 location.  I.e., S3 location "US" might eventually include EC2 regions "us-east-1" and "us-west-1".However, I had always assumed the opposite based on my mental picture of AWS.  I.e., EC2 region "us-west-1" would match up with an S3 location "US-WEST-1".  S3 location "US" would then only be usable for EC2 "us-east-1" and might eventually be given a location alias of "US-EAST-1" to make things convenient for those of us who like consistency.I think this is a question only Amazon can answer.  Hopefully they've thought this far ahead as some of us need to make decisions based on it today and don't want to have the naming schemes break if Amazon picks the opposite direction.

S3-US already spans the continent with data centers on the east and west coasts.  So I would guess that any future EC2 us-west region would have equal access to S3-US as the existing EC2 us-east region, and that AMI's stored on S3-US would be able to run on both EC2 us-west and us-east.  But I doubt Amazon is willing to commit to what this future architecture will be, if it is ever implemented.

And on second thought, it looks like I didn't quite accurately capture the true question.I think what we really need to know is whether a single S3 bucket in, say, the "US" location can contain AMIs which can be run in multiple EC2 regions, say, "us-east-1" and "us-west-1". I see a number of different possible designs:1. Any AMI in bucket-US can be run in all EC2 us-* regions (with the same AMI id).2. Any single AMI bundle/manifest in bucket-US can be registered to be run in multiple EC2 us-* regions (with different AMI ids in each region).3. Each AMI in bucket-US runs in a single EC2 region, but different AMIs in that bucket could target different us-* regions.4. Each S3 bucket can only contain AMIs targeted at a single EC2 region.Any clues about which of the above might or might not be possible in the future would be appreciated.

Like you said earlier, I think only Amazon can answer this.  S3 takes a fundamentally different approach than the other services and AWS will either have to continue to allow those differences between Location and Region to exist or make significant and probably incompatible changes in S3 to align it to Regions.As it stands now, I think if a "us-west-1" region were created for EC2, images stored anywhere in the US location in S3 would be accessible to both "us-west-1" and "us-east-1" and it would therefore be impossible to determine the Region strictly from the Location.Mitch

Well, just to close this thread, amazon answered this question with the creation of us-west-1.AMIs created in us-west-1 for instance-store must exist in a bucket in location "US-WEST-1".So, At the moment, location:region mapping is:US: us-east-1EU: eu-west-1us-west-1: us-west-1ap-southeast-1: ap-southeast-1Some time back, when this issue was resolved, I sent patch to s3cmd at http://sourceforge.net/mailarchive/forum.php?thread_name=alpine.DEB.2.00.0912101316040.31780%40brickies&forum_name=s3tools-general

help with bucket location Hi, I'm in need of some help.  I fear that it is not solveable without help fromamazon.A few months ago I created some buckets using s3cmd in anticipation of us-west-1 (and other regions being created).  Now that those regions exist, I wanted to publish some images to them.  However, attemps to    ec2-upload-bundle --location us-west-1results in:   ERROR: Bucket "ubuntu-kernels-testing-us-west-1" location does not match specified location.The following are empty buckets that I've created that I would like to appear in the us-west-1 location.   ubuntu-images-milestone-us-west-1   ubuntu-images-sandbox-us-west-1   ubuntu-images-testing-us-west-1   ubuntu-images-us-west-1   ubuntu-kernels-sandbox-us-west-1   ubuntu-kernels-testing-us-west-1   ubuntu-kernels-us-west-1I recall from previous cases that a delete and recreate takes quite a long time before the resource is actually freed.  Is there any way that I can get the above buckets with a location in us-west-1 ?

Well, in a scrambling effort, i've deleted many of the buckets, now, an upload-bundle fails like:$ ec2-upload-bundle --bucket ubuntu-kernels-testing-us-west-1 --location us-west-1 --manifest out/bogus.img.manifest.xml Creating bucket...Uploading bundled image parts to the S3 bucket ubuntu-kernels-testing-us-west-1 ...Failed to upload "out/bogus.img.part.0": Server.NoSuchBucket(404): The specified bucket does not existERROR: Failed to upload "out/bogus.img.part.0": Server.NoSuchBucket(404): The specified bucket does not existNote, it says "Creating bucket..." but apparently not.

+1Folks can't really use the new us-west-1 region announced by Amazon until their favorite AMIs are available in that region.  These official Ubuntu AMIs that Scott Moser is trying to migrate over are the ones I am now recommending, and there should be a lot of customers waiting to use them.If there is a way to get these buckets in the correct region, it would be nice to execute it quickly.  If there is going to be a delay in being able to create these buckets, then please let Scott know so that alternate bucket names can be considered (though these names are the most desired for long term consistency).
I ended up getting help from amazon on this topic.  They were able to manually expire the buckets to clean them up for me.

Now I used this new method ec2-create-image -n your_image_name instance_id and the new image I created at new instance work perfectly.  My new question now is:  Which are the differences between the two methods? ec2-create-snapshot ec2-register -n myname --root-device /dev/sda1 -b /dev/sda1=my_snap_id  and  ec2-create-image -n your_image_name instance_id      Anyone know this?

The differences between:ec2-create-snapshotec2-register -n myname --root-device /dev/sda1 -b /dev/sda1=my_snap_idandec2-create-image -n your_image_name instance_idIs in which kernel is selected.  The second command will run ec2-register with the same kernel that the reference instance was bootedwith.  The first will use the default kernel in EC2, which is some veryold Fedora based kernel.mainly, you need to add '--kernel <aki-.....>' where the value is the same kernel that is shown in describe-images for the instance you booted (kernel-id can also be obtained in the metadata service).
