Lost instance I'm testing EC2 and I was in a windows instance that was running for a couple of hours.  I created a VPN connection to our network and installed software.   Then I disconnected the VPN and at that time my RDP connection dropped, and I could not re-connect.  I then went to the AWS Management console and my instance was gone!  How to I ensure that my instance is not lost in the future, and is there a way to retrieve the lost instance? -Nathan  Message was edited by: Nathan Slemmer
Ok, now my instance is showing up again.  Is this normal for an instance to disappear?

firewall question We recently had a vulnerability assessment done against an instance we have on EC2 (cloud.lincware.com).  One of the results was shown below.  I'm no security expert but it seems this issue (if it is not a false-positive) is happening on Amazon's firewall and is not specific to our instance ... can anyone comment on whether or not this vulnerability is real?  Synopis/Description:	The remote host seems to generate Initial Sequence Numbers (ISN) in a weak manner which seems to solely depend on the source and dest port of the TCP packets. An attacker may exploit this flaw to establish spoofed connections to the remote host. The Raptor Firewall and Novell Netware are known to be vulnerable to this flaw, although other network devices may be vulnerable as well. (NOTE: This may prove to be a false positive.) Solution:	If you are using a Raptor Firewall, see http://www.symantec.com/techsupp/bulletin/archive/firewall/082002firewall.html Otherwise, contact your vendor for a patch. Reference : http://online.securityfocus.com/archive/1/285729

Perhaps someone with more detailed knowledge of the specific vulnerability can add to my comments below - I'm guessing here to the best of my knowledge.  It seems to me that the vulnerability described is only effective against stateful firewalls: that is, firewalls that can be used to selectively allow or disallow communications based on the state of the TCP connection. If an attacker can convince a stateful firewall that it already has an existing connection, it may be able to penetrate the firewall.  EC2's firewall is a stateless firewall, making its decisions solely on the basis of the packet's source address and target port. Manipulating the TCP connection state will not matter. Attempts to spoof a connection will still need to originate from the allowed source IP address, to the allowed target port - so the attack can only succeed from behind the same public IP address as the authorized clients.  One might try to subvert the routing infrastructure of the intervening network hops between the target and EC2 and spoof packet source addresses this way. But this vulnerability is different from the one reported by your assessment, and not one that is EC2-specific  As I said, it would be helpful for someone with experience in this particular vulnerability to chime in.
I'm not sure that the EC2 firewall is stateless, based on my experience (which you can try for yourself)http://developer.amazonwebservices.com/connect/thread.jspa?messageID=171252
Hmm... that's a good point. I wonder if that means the EC2 firewall is vulnerable. Might be worth a shot to test.
Can anyone inside Amazon comment here?

Still no input from the Amazon folks...?Found this link which confirms the firewall is stateful: http://developer.amazonwebservices.com/connect/entry!default.jspa?categoryID=152&externalID=1697&fromSearchPage=true
I would also be interested in an answer from Amazon on this.  Thanks
The resolution of my own thread may be of interest to you: http://developer.amazonwebservices.com/connect/thread.jspa?messageID=198899

Need some "backup" advice Hi,  I need some advise on how to survive a system failure. We have a single instance running Windows 2008 Server running from an EBS volume, and to that we have two volumes attached (data volumes). I would like to be able to spin up a new copy of our instance in case of failure, and for that I need to create an AMI.   1) What would be the right way to create a AMI. Should I shut show IIS on the server, detach the two datavolumes, stop the instance, create AMI, start the instance, attach the data volumes and restart IIS. Is that the right way to do it?  2) How does snapshots fit in to this - do I need snapshot of our root EBS and data volumes or can we delete them?  Thanks

SSH issue (public DNS access) Hi, I'm new to this AWS and cloud computing and not really from a very technical background. I've installed on Opensource apps thru AMI. Not able to access thru public DNS. It says Open SSH and locate private key file etc. Pls find the attachment and help to access the application.   Thanks for the help. Regards, SP

Sam, You must have stored private key via your elasticfox or AWS console when you initiated the instance. It stored the private key(.pem) in your local drive to the path you specified at the time of creation. Go to that directory and execute chmod 400 xyz.pem and then try to ssh to your instance. Volumes Stuck Attaching Hi, I have volumes that are stuck in an in-use, attaching state.  Even stranger, I have no instances running.I do not really know the events leading up to this because everything I do with EC2 is automated.  The only thing I have to go on are the logs I created for myself.  In the past four days or so, I've gotten tons of SSH errors like the following:ssh: connect to host ec2-174-129-49-199.compute-1.amazonaws.com port 22: Connection timed outlost connectionAmazon says that my region (VA) has been operating normally for the past week.Needless to say, I'm not thrilled at Amazon right now  .  So does anyone have any idea about 1) how to kill volumes stuck attaching?  2) how volumes could get stuck?  or 3) if anything has gone wrong with Amazon in the past few days?Thanks!

Hi amillsx,Usually, when volumes enter a seemingly "stuck" status, you can issue a forced detachment using either ElasticFox or the EC2 command line toolset (using the --force flag). Regarding the last two questions, I can't really speculate as to what happened to keep the volume states for these volumes in attaching, and am not aware of any issues within the past two or three days that would impact your volumes in this way. You can look at the Service Health Dashboard to check historic widespread issues:http://status.aws.amazon.com/If the forced detachment doesn't work, please let me know. Regards,Scott

Maybe my eyes just glossed over that status page previously, but upon further inspection, YES, apparently something weird did happen in my region when these volumes got screwed up.  Thank you!  The force option on the command line tools definitely gets the job done.

EC2 Redundancy and Acess Hi all,  I'm studying the AWS to start developing a big application.   There are two things I'd like to know  1)  The EC2 instance have redundancy ? If something happen with the physical machine  my virtual instance will be stopped? Or i have to order multiple instances to ensure that my application will be running if something bad happen?  2) If I have two instances, one for the applicaiton and another to database(that will be a SqlServer). Will be a network connection between the two instances? And theres any feature on AWS to ensure that only my instance that runs my application have access to the database instance (or i'll have to do that in the server)?    Thanks. []'s

zingui wrote:
1) The EC2 instance have redundancy ? If something happen with the physical machine my virtual instance will be stopped? Or i have to order multiple instances to ensure that my application will be running if something bad happen?
EC2 instances do not have built-in redundancy.  If the physical host fails, then your instance will also fail.  If you want to guarantee that your application will be resiliant in the face of host failure, then you need multiple instances.  You should also consider running the instances in different availability zones, so reduce the change of simultaneous failure.
2) If I have two instances, one for the applicaiton and another to database(that will be a SqlServer). Will be a network connection between the two instances? And theres any feature on AWS to ensure that only my instance that runs my application have access to the database instance (or i'll have to do that in the server)?
You can use security groups to restrict network access, specifically to allow only access to an instance from another type of instance (e.g. only allow inbound access to your database from your webservers)Thanks,Peter
Eu-West-1a Vs Eu-West-1b Hello,Is there any difference between Eu-West-1a and Eu-West-1b ?Are them both in Ireland?Kind Regards,Cearnau Dan

AWS has said that all availability zones in EU-West-1 are in Ireland. Availability zones are identical except for how they get network connectivity, power, etc.  The concept is that if a something fails (a construction crew cuts power, an air conditioning chiller fails etc) it will not impact both zones.  This allows for designing redundant systems by placing instances in different availability zones.

With an EBS boot instance you can stop the instance and restart it with a different instance type, but this involves shutting down and booting the os so memory is not preserved.

Thank you, but what I want to know is whether vm instances can move (with ram contents) between servers inside EC2. Hi Shamaruc You cannot move running instances (Inc RAM contents) to another host. when you stop and start an EBS backed instance this will start the instance on fresh hardware. If I understand your last question you are asking are there any circumstances where we would move you instances around. The answer to this is no, Your instances live on a underlying host until a customer stops or terminates them.

Support for elastic IPs for ELB and multiple ELBs for a single EC2 cluster? Here's what i'm trying to achieve:I have a number of domains that i want to dynamically route to different clusters of EC2 instances. To avoid DNS propagation issues, i want to be able to keep the domains pointing to a defined CNAME or IP and let me change what load balanced cluster that host ends up on.I can achieve this with an EC2 instance behind an elastic IP running haproxy, but I'd prefer to use ELP, especially with its https support now.But in order to achieve this with ELB, it'd need two things:1) Multiple elastic IPs pointing to a single ELB, and2) Multiple ELBs pointing to the same EC2 clusterWith this i can do the following:domainA-> ip1domainB -> ip2domainC -> ip3domainD -> ip4ip1 -> elb1 (w/ https)ip2 -> elb2ip3 -> elb2ip4 -> elb3elb1 -> ec2cluster1elb2 -> ec2cluster2elb3 -> ec2cluster1Now i can move domainX from between clusters by mapping its ip to the appropriate elb and support https for any domain by bringing up a dedicated elb which points to the appropriate cluster.Any plans for these two features, or alternative ways of achieving the same?thanks,arne

Elastic IPs on an ELB is one of the most oft-requested ELB features on these forums. It's not supported currently: http://developer.amazonwebservices.com/connect/thread.jspa?messageID=128764&#128764  You can already create multiple ELBs with the same instances in them, as I detail in this article: http://shlomoswidler.com/2009/07/ec2-instance-belonging-to-multiple-elbs.html  If you use AutoScaling then only one ELB will be "hooked in" to the cluster, so notifications of launched and terminated instances will only be supplied to one ELB. You would need to separately inform the other ELBs of any cluster membership changes.
Interesting. It would seem the instance belonging to multiple ELBs is just nerfed in the Management Console then, where i tried to do the same thing the article described.

I also changed the ServerName of my virtual host to demo.flashxml.net.After this, I was no longer able to access demo.flashxml.net via HTTP. What happens  is that I get a Request Timed Out from ec2-184-73-27-8.compute-1.amazonaws.com.Because of the name virtual host, accessing the IP directly does not work, of course.The really strange thing is that ping and FTP work with no problem for both the IP address and the demo.flashxml.net host name.In case it helps anyone, here's the telnet output:telnet 174.129.7.254 80Trying 174.129.7.254...Connected to 174.129.7.254.Escape character is '^]'.GET / HTTP/1.1host: 174.129.7.254HTTP/1.1 302 FoundDate: Wed, 13 Oct 2010 08:13:51 GMTServer: Apache/2.2.15 (Amazon)X-Powered-By: PHP/5.3.2Location: http://ec2-184-73-27-8.compute-1.amazonaws.com/Content-Length: 0Connection: closeContent-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8Connection closed by foreign host.telnet demo.flashxml.net 80Trying 174.129.7.254...Connected to demo.flashxml.net.Escape character is '^]'.GET / HTTP/1.1host: demo.flashxml.netHTTP/1.1 302 FoundDate: Wed, 13 Oct 2010 08:14:36 GMTServer: Apache/2.2.15 (Amazon)X-Powered-By: PHP/5.3.2Location: http://ec2-184-73-27-8.compute-1.amazonaws.com/Content-Length: 0Connection: closeContent-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8Connection closed by foreign host.Does anyone have any advice?

You've set the hostname to match the instance's public DNS name. But when you associate an Elastic IP the previous public DNS name changes to be the name corresponding with the Elastic IP.  If 174.129.7.254 is your Elastic IP then the corresponding DNS name is http://ec2-174-129-7-254.compute-1.amazonaws.com. Make sure you use URLs whose DNS point to the Elastic IP address.

Hello Shlomo,Thank you for your reply. I'm affraid I am not as expert as you are. Can you repeat what you said in a less technical language?What do you mean by "Make sure you use URLs whose DNS point to the Elastic IP address."?Do I need to change something on the server? Or in my DNS records?I've also tried http://ec2-174-129-7-254.compute-1.amazonaws.com and I get the same result:telnet ec2-174-129-7-254.compute-1.amazonaws.com 80Trying 10.202.205.96...Connected to ec2-174-129-7-254.compute-1.amazonaws.com.Escape character is '^]'.GET / HTTP/1.1host: ec2-174-129-7-254.compute-1.amazonaws.comHTTP/1.1 302 FoundDate: Wed, 13 Oct 2010 09:13:06 GMTServer: Apache/2.2.15 (Amazon)X-Powered-By: PHP/5.3.2Location: http://ec2-184-73-27-8.compute-1.amazonaws.com/Content-Length: 0Connection: closeContent-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8Connection closed by foreign host.

It looks like you need to change the virtual host's hostname, which is still set to its old value:  Location: http://ec2-184-73-27-8.compute-1.amazonaws.com/  You should specify your actual domain name, not the Public DNS name of the instance.

<VirtualHost *:80>         DocumentRoot /home/ec2-user/public_html/wordpress          ServerName demo.flashxml.net          ErrorLog logs/ec2-user-error_log          <Directory /home/ec2-user/public_html/wordpress>                 AllowOverride FileInfo                 Order Deny,Allow                 Allow from All         </Directory> </VirtualHost>  Here is my VirtualHost. I am pretty sure it's OK. Is there anyway I can check what is the host name used by Apache?

I figured it out, eventually. The server was accessible and all networking related settings were correct. What was wrong, was that I've installed Wordpress when my server had the initial hostname. This caused the 302 redirect to a hostname that didn't even exist anymore.

AWS team: For ELB - is SSL Termination in the roadmap? Question for AWS team:  For ELB - is SSL Termination in the roadmap? This is a very important missing feature, before we can start to use ELB in our production.  Reason is as follows: * We need HTTPS sticky sessions for our ELB. The alternative of re-architecting our app is too painful, relative to everything else on our roadmap.
Hi - Any comments from anyone in AWS team?
-removed message-

You can manage sticky sessions and SSL with aiCache AMI found here  http://developer.amazonwebservices.com/connect/entry.jspa?externalID=3381&categoryID=89  We have 2 hours of free setup if you require help with configuration More AWS specific detail here http://wiki.aicache.com  -support

SSL is a highly requested feature from our customers. We take customer requests very seriously and drive toward increasing customer satisfaction. It is AWS policy to not announce features before they are released, but if it is we will be sure to post an announcement in the forums. While we are talking about it, are there any particular features/configurations for SSL termination you would like to see in such a feature?

We would definitely make use of this if it were available.  Our need is to have the ability to load in an SSL certificate, and have sessions come to our application on a configurable port, unencrypted, with an X-Forwarded-For, as the regular ELB setup allows today.
I also would find this highly valuable if available
Add my vote to the tally. We would deploy this feature as soon as it's released.

Without this feature, it seems to be impossible to track the real IP of the client over HTTPS. I imagine this makes ELB unusable in many situations, including ours.   We would start using ELB immediately if SSL termination were supported.
We're happy to announce that today we released support for SSL termination. For more details see our forum announcement: http://developer.amazonwebservices.com/connect/ann.jspa?annID=788

How do I bundle an EBS-backed running instance into an AMI? I know you can login to the AWS Console and just hit 'bundle' to create an AMI out of your EBS-backed instance, but how do I do that from the command-line tools? Which commands would I execute on that running instance? For example, this is how I normally bundle a running instance into an S3-backed AMI:ec2-bundle-vol...then ec2-upload-bundle..thenec2-register..then I have an ami-id which I can use to launch instances or use in my autoscaling launch configurations. So any ideas what the sequence of commands would be to replicate the "EBS-backed Bundle" command in the AWS Console? Thanks in advance for any help.

Hi basitnyc,You can use the ec2-create-image call to do this via the API tools:http://docs.amazonwebservices.com/AWSEC2/latest/CommandLineReference/ApiReference-cmd-CreateImage.htmlYou would run this from a system with the EC2 API tools installed; you do not need to run it from the instance itself (as you do with the AMI tools).Regards,-Jason
Brilliant! Thanks so much for the help.-B

ELB sending Bad Requests Hi there,We have recently signed to EC2 service but not sure if it is valid for us. We've setup a Elastic Load Balancer with Health Check by HTTP. Every request from the ELB is considered by our IIS servers as a 400 bad request. See log:#Fields: date time c-ip c-port s-ip s-port cs-version cs-method cs-uri sc-status s-siteid s-reason s-queuename2010-02-01 13:31:47 10.227.111.147 34048 10.226.178.192 80 HTTP/1.1 GET /index.html 400 - Hostname -TCP check works fine but HTTP is necessary because we need user's IP (HTTP_X_Forwarded_For header).Any help is appreciated

I'll reply myself.Requests from the ELB are to the Default Web Site (empty Host Header). So there are 2 solutions:Either enable it (ours was disabled) orAdd to the desired Web Site an identity with empty Host Header.
The ping checks not including the host header is a major short coming.  The other option is to port translate. In IIS bind each site to a different port and port translate from 80.

ModifyInstanceAttribute returning InvalidParameterCombination Hi everyone,  Summary: I'm trying to set the EBS store of a t1.micro instance to not be deleted upon termination.  I have a stopped instance 'i-5e749033' and am trying to set the blockDeviceMapping attribute to /dev/sda1=::false. Unfortunately the documentation really doesn't go into the format of the value but that is what I have gathered from other sources. I have also tried the values 'vol-2ebf8147::false' and 'vol-2ebf8147:15:false' (where vol-2ebf8147 is the EBS volume).  Unfortunately EC2 is giving me an error: "InvalidParameterCombination - No attributes specified."  The complete output of my command line tool is here, and as you can see the attribute is sent correctly as is the value. Even if I'm doing something wrong, I think the error message is particularly bad.  * http://paste.dollyfish.net.nz/6d6456.txt  Anyone any suggestions?  Andy

You are right, the documentation is very poor on this.  You need to pass the BlockDeviceMapping parameters, which are identical to those documented in RunInstances.So something like (untested):BlockDeviceMapping.1.DeviceName=/dev/sda1&BlockDeviceMapping.1.Ebs.NoDevice=trueIt might be BlockDeviceMapping.1.NoDevice=true instead; try both and reply with which works.

From what I can tell, I am unable to modify this for a running instance. I had to set them when I called RunInstances. In the end I ended up specifying the following:  * BlockDeviceMapping.0.DeviceName /dev/sda1  BlockDeviceMapping.0.Ebs.DeleteOnTermination false   It all seems to work fine. When I terminate the instance, the EBS store is still there which I can then delete separately.  It was all a bit roundabout to figure it out, but I got there in the end  Shame it can't be done on a running instance but that's ok, I know now.

startup scripts on ebs boot instance Hi,   I am trying to cook a startup script to run on start  of EBS boot instance. Hi Roman,Based on the fact that you're mentioning "ec2-user," it seems like you're working with the Amazon Linux AMI. That user has sudo access, by default, so you should be able to edit the files you wish to edit. Alternatively, you could switch your login shell to the root user should you choose to do so. Hi Scott,   First of all you are right: I am working with Amazon Linux AMI for EBS. (root is pw protected)  Thanks for trying to help but it seams like I am still stuck.  Regards. Roman
Any progress on that one ? Thanks in advance.Roman.
login as ec2-usertype "sudo bash"do you have a root shell?if not, something is seriously screwy with your amazon linux instance... terminate and try again.
It worked thanks, really strange: why they obligate you to login with special user when you can simply switch.  Roman

Roman: it's not strange at all.  It's good security practice.  Most admins will tell you that you should log in as an unprivileged user and switch to root only when necessary to run specific commands.  This way you have less chance of destroying something by accident.
Good point, thanks.  Roman

Disk space discrepancy Hi  I am having a problem reconciling the space available on my EBS volume. According to the AWS console the volume is 50GB and is attached to an instance.  If I ssh to this instance and do a df -h, I get the following output:  Filesystem            Size  Used Avail Use% Mounted on /dev/sda1              15G   13G  3.0G  81% / udev                  858M   76K  858M   1% /dev none                  858M     0  858M   0% /dev/shm none                  858M   72K  858M   1% /var/run none                  858M     0  858M   0% /var/lock none                  858M     0  858M   0% /lib/init/rw  I am pretty new to AWS. I interpret this as "there is a device attached and it has 15GB capacity. Whats more, you're nearly out of space!"  Can anyone point out the cause of the apparent discrepancy between the space advertised in the console and what is displayed on the instance?  Many thanks in advance  S

You are looking at filesystem sizes, not device size.  So what this actually says is:There is a filesystem on a device that has a max size of 15GB and you are about 80% used.What the command output does not say (because df only handles filesystems) is:There is 35GB more free space on the device after the end of the filesystem.You need to use a tool to resize your root filesystem if you want to use more of the 50GB space.
OK thanks. What would you say is the easiest method of getting a 50GB drive attached to his instance? Resizing or another method?Thanks for your help.

the command "resize2fs" will extend the filesystem to use all the free space.  it can be run on a running mounted filesystem too.http://linux.die.net/man/8/resize2fsIMO that's the easiest way to go, it's pretty fast too.  Message was edited by: J. Drukman

How to "moth ball" a virutal server from Amazon Good day,A while back we experimented with virtual servers at Amazon and uploaded some operational data to the server. Now we are no longer certain that that is what we want to do, but we also don’t want to lose our data. Is it possible to “moth ball” the server so we don’t have to pay for it while we are still making a decision on it?RegardsGeorge  Message was edited by: georgefurnell

Hi George,For boot-from-EBS instances you could just 'stop' (not terminate) the instance. For boot-from-S3 instances (which use local ephemeral storage for the boot volume) you should move your application data to an EBS volume so you can terminate the instance.Thanks, -Philip

Hi Philip,when I "stop" an instance does that mean that I won’t pay until I "start" it again? Cause that’s why I want to do it, we are not sure that we want to continue with EC2, so while we are still making the decision we don’t need the server and also don’t want to pay.RegardsGeorge  Message was edited by: georgefurnell

Hi George,You are correct, there isn't any instance running time to pay for when an instance is stopped.You of course do pay for the instance's related EBS volume(s) storage allocation (which allocation enables a instance to be in a stopped state).Thanks, -Philip

How should I set up a private network with a static IP?What can I do if I’m locked out of Windows and forgot my password?How can I access the console? For example: win 2008 systemstate restoreWhat is the support’s email address? Is there a free email support?thx.Message was edited by: petybMessage was edited by: petyb

How should I set up a private network with a static IP?  Take a look at Virtual Private Cloud to see if it meets your needs.  Also read up on Elastic IPs.  What can  I do if I'm locked out of Windows and forgot my password?  You're out of luck for getting into the instance, so you'd have to start up a new instance.  However, if you are using EBS volumes, you can attach them to another instance to retrieve your data.  How can I access the console?  For example: win 2008 systemstate restore  You cannot get console access to Windows instances.  The AMI system should remove the need for the Windows system restore feature.  What is the support's email address? Is there a free email support?  Free support is only available through the forums.  Read up on premium support.

Hi,   When I read EC2's user guide I found this sentence "When you stop and restart the instance (EBS backed), it launches quickly, because the state is stored in an Amazon EBS volume. " . does this mean when stoping a vm EC2 store the memory contents of this into a volume or a vm image?Regards.

No, the memory (RAM) is not saved. Stopping an instance shuts it down and only the disk contents are preserved.  Starting the instance boots it up again from that disk.  It would be cool if somebody could figure out how to hibernate a Linux EC2 instance to disk before stopping it.  You'd have to use swap on an EBS volume (perhaps even through a file on the boot disk).  -- Eric Hammond

thank you Eric Hammond.Then there is not vm image wich contains RAM contents exist in EC2? if so, why?  Because It is difficult for implementing? or It is unsafe to to that? or It needn't to do so from the perspective of a cloud user?

Private DNS/IP Hi all !As instance doesnt keep it's internal ip address, nor his internal DNS name, i'm looking for a manner to communicate via the private network between two instance, without having to reconfigure all if the backend server is restarted. For example, if i have a database or a file server, and i want to connect several instance to them, i will configure connection string in order to do this.  But if the server is rebooted, these string will be invalid. How to solve that ?

I wrote this article which might help:  http://alestic.com/2009/06/ec2-elastic-ip-internal  Note: Simply rebooting an instance will not change its internal IP address.  It is changed if you stop and start the instance or terminate the instance and run a new one.  -- Eric Hammond

Enabling Multiple Users to Access the Same AWS Account I am one of the founders of our company and our new AWS account is under my name.  I'd like to enable another principal in the company to have access to, or be able to take over management of, our AWS account in the event something happens to me.  If we're going to put the vast majority of our infrastructure within EC2 and pay for them using my account, I would hate to think what would happen should I get hit by a bus.  Is there anyway I can delegate a co-owner or backup-owner for our account?  If not, what's the protocol when you need to transfer management of an account?  It would also be nice to enabled a co-owner to access our account invoices since, in my case, someone else takes care of the financials of the business.   Thanks.

If you give someone else the account login info (email address & password), they have full access to the account.  You might also consider using a generic company email address (aws@myco.com) and a company credit card with company billing address.

Thanks for the suggestion Allen.  Unfortunately a couple things come to mind which make sharing credentials a solution to this problem, a non-starter:  1. Sharing credentials inherently requires communicating passwords, and more often than not, leads to someone writing them down (which is the first step towards someone you don't want finding them).  For other types of accounts, accounts than I wasn't betting my business on and didn't hold the keys to all of our customer's medical data, that might be a risk worth mitigating.  In this case however, I'm less than enthusiastic about taking any security shortcuts.  2. Lack of accountability.  As soon credentials start getting shared, it becomes difficult, if not impossible, to determine who took a particular course of action.  If at some point, one of the people with access to the credentials decided to cancel all of our accounts, if they did it properly, we'd have no way to prove which one of us did it.  Again, I appreciate the input, and it's something we'll consider if Amazon doesn't consider this a common scenario.  That said, with the number of organizations who have bet their business on AWS, having to choose between a single point of failure for account management and credential sharing, isn't something I imagine many people are excited about.

Well, you can always do the old "write the login credentials down and put 'em in a sealed envelope" trick.  That should be enough to keep honest people--who share a common goal of your business's success--honest, no?Precisely how much do you distrust your business partners?

Jeez  It has nothing to do with distrusting his business partners, and that should be very obvious from the post.  Sharing passwords is bad security.At least billing should have access info different from technical if desired and tech needs to be able to see the billing as well.  Hard to believe this is ridiculed,

Thanks dchon, you're absolutely right.  This isn't about not trusting anyone, this is about doing the right thing by customers by protecting their data and their access to it.  Not to mention being prepared to be held accountable for it.    Imagine the following conversation:  Me: "Hi, I'd like to store your very personal and valuable information (could be your SSN, financial information, pictures of your kids, your complete medical history - whatever).  We use AWS so we scale terrifically and can offer you competitive prices."  Customer: "Oh yeah?  AWS only allows one person to manage the virtual keys to the candy shop.  What happens if that guy dies?"  Me: "Don't worry, we've written down that guy's password and the only other people who have access to it have promised not to look at it until pops is out on his date with the mortician."  Customer: "And what's to those people from jumping the gun and either destroying all of my data or simply wiping it out all together?  And if they did, how would you know who to hold accountable?"  Me: "Did I tell you about this great new UI feature we've added?  It's called a Ribbon..."  Would you utilize a service that had the "root" password written down somewhere that people promised not to look?  I take it from the lack of information I've seen online and the replies I've seen so far, this isn't something AWS supports.  It's not the end of the world - AWS, like the rest of us, has to prioritize.  If someone from AWS could confirm that this is not possible and it's not in the pipeline, that would be helpful.  If you have an interest in seeing AWS support something like this, please speak up.
Justin, those are very good points. We'd love to see this feature as well.

One way to minimize the amount that your production credentials have to be shared is to have a separate AWS account for development and production.  You can give developers your dev credentials so that they don't have access to production data.

This is absolutely something that we need. It is indeed hard to believe that Amazon has not yet implemented this feature.  We need to be able to allow access to multiple people without sharing the company billing info, and without sharing a common account.  Bizarre.

I am a new user of AWS and I am rather shocked that this has not been addressed, especially since it has been an issue since at least 2008 (judging by the dates on this thread).  Has anyone heard anything about this?
Does the consolidated accounting mechanism help with this problem ?  Surely by now there is a way to do this ?  --Hiram

I can't believe this basic feature isn't offered yet. Sharing one account across a company is a really bad idea.Can someone let us know if this is a feature that's coming soon? Is there an ETA on when this feature will be available?

AWS has actually launched the ability to have multiple users associated with the same account. The solution is called AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) and allows you to create your own Users, each on with unique security credentials. You can also control what a User can access in your account by defining permissions on a per users basis. A great starting point for learning more about IAM is:http://aws.amazon.com/iam...anders

creating multiple policies for ELB stickiness I was going through the ELB developer guide, and found that for both App and Load Balancer stickiness, the following note is mentioned"You can create a maximum of 20 policies per load balancer"What is meant by creating multiple policies for ELB Stickiness?In the Amazon EC2 console also, there is no provision for defining multiple policies.  Message was edited by: rameshaws

You can create multiple policies with the elb-create-app-cookie-stickiness-policy or elb-create-lb-cookie-stickiness-policy commands. Only one policy can be active on a load balancer at a time. You control the active policy with the elb-set-lb-policies-of-listener command.  I don't see a way to manage multiple stickiness policies from the AWS Management Console.

Auto Scaling uses the metrics reported by CloudWatch. What does CloudWatch report for the metric your trigger is configured to use (CPUUtilization) for that instance?  mon-get-stats CPUUtilization --end-time 2010-10-12T23:59:59 --start-time 2010-10-12T00:00:00 --period 60 --namespace "AWS/EC2" --statistics "Average" --dimensions  "InstanceId=i-XXXXX"   Note that you will likely not be able to produce 100% CPUUtilization by doing a single-threaded while loop from a client. You'll likely need to stress the instance from more than one thread, and maybe even from more than one client machine - depending on the relative network bandwidths of the machines.

Cloudwatch doesn't report CPUUtilization for load balancers, only instances.  So setting up a trigger for load balancer CPU won't ever do anything.

Looking at your trigger, you're specifying a Unit of "Seconds", which you aren't specifying in your corresponding calls to CloudWatch.  I imagine that mismatch is causing the NoData status for your trigger.Hope that helps,-Geoff

Unresponsive server - can you please restart i-86e107ee I am unable to restart my instance i-86e107ee. Can you please force a restart?Thanks.

Hi joaws,Your instance is on a physical host that may be experiencing some problems.  If this is a critical production server, I'd recommend that you launch a replacement instance and move your EBS volume to the new instance.  As an aside, you may want to consider using an Elastic IP to reduce the complexity of transitioning to replacement instances:http://docs.amazonwebservices.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/concepts-failure-resilient-apps.htmlRegards,-Jason

Imaging a running Ubuntu system w/o reboot The posts on these are everywhere and none seem to really be 'the one'.  With that, I have a few Ubuntu servers and I have a routine of late at night over the EC2 / instances website, right click and say Create Image (EBS AMI).  The problem is it takes the server down for a while as it does this.  I have read from the EC2 tools you can do this w/o the box taken out.So, I I have the dev tools, but a lot of 'how-to's' say to use the ec2-create-vol which is not in the bin folder.  I have a ec2-create-image as well as an ec2-bundle-instance, but a lot of posts are saying to use the create-vol which is part of the confiusion.What is the correct utility to do what I do via web page?  I basically want to weekly take an image of the server.  I need to read up a bit more on snapshot's which I think is different, but for now, would like a resolution to this procedure, then can move forward.Thank you

Hi xlancelotx,If your instance is EBS-backed, you can create your image using the EC2 API Tools using ec2-create-image:http://docs.amazonwebservices.com/AWSEC2/latest/CommandLineReference/ApiReference-cmd-CreateImage.htmlwhich provides a --no-reboot option that you can pass.  Alternately, you could create a snapshot of the root volume, then register that snapshot as an AMI using the ec2-register command:http://docs.amazonwebservices.com/AWSEC2/latest/CommandLineReference/ApiReference-cmd-RegisterImage.htmlRegards,-Jason

Hi, I do see this issue everyday. 50 to 100 requests going to port 80 out of a million requests per day. The requests show the IP address of the ELB (port 80 is blocked for the public and allowed only from the ELB. I can get the tcpdump but not sure if that will give us any clue.  thank you.

One other issue I have right now- ELB is doing a constant health check every 5 seconds to port 80.  10.xxx.xxx.xxx - - [01/Oct/2010:16:14:34 -0400] "GET /health_ping HTTP/1.1" 200 - "-" "-" 10.xxx.xxx.xxx - - [01/Oct/2010:16:14:39 -0400] "GET /health_ping HTTP/1.1" 200 - "-" "-" 10.xxx.xxx.xxx - - [01/Oct/2010:16:14:44 -0400] "GET /health_ping HTTP/1.1" 200 - "-" "-"  Though our "Health Check" is set for port 8080 every 30seconds.  This started to happen after the internal IP of ELB got changed.  Any clue?  thanks.

Can you explain what you mean "port 80 is blocked for the public and allowed only from the ELB"?  An ELB has a dynamically-changing set of IP addresses. If you allowed the IP address of the ELB as discovered by resolving its DNS name at a certain time, your instances will not receive any traffic once the ELB's IP address changes - which happens unpredictably, as your ELB experiences more or less traffic.  One possible explanation for the traffic you're seeing on port 80 is that the traffic is coming from an application that misused ELB and directed its traffic based on the ELB's IP address at the time. This IP address no longer belongs to his ELB - it belongs to yours. So that application's traffic is reaching your instances.

Can you explain what you mean "port 80 is blocked for the public and allowed only from the ELB"?  security group is setup to allow access to port 80 from a wide range of private IP address... so that any requests from the ELB (as src) to backend servers for p80 will be served.   I have port 80 open due to the traffic spilling intended for port 8080. wide private ip range was used to prevent issues due to ELB private IP changes.  For the ELB public address, we are using the cname record.  May be you are right... someone used the internal IP address for health checks (health_ping) and after the IP address change, I am getting those... How to prevent these type of issues?

wide private ip range was used to prevent issues due to ELB private IP changes  ELB internal IP addresses share an address range with EC2 instance internal IPs. So any EC2 instance can access your service directly.  However, this is not an issue than has a solution currently. The design of ELB  and EC2 security groups currently makes it impossible to limit the traffic on your back-end servers to originate only from the ELB. In other words: you can't limit the traffic the way you want to. Perhaps you should consider using an HAProxy or other software load balancer running on an EC2 instance.  There is also no way to prevent anyone from accessing the health check URL.

apparently the request to port 80 for health_ping is coming from 10.245.215.175. This IP was tied to some other instance for which the owner of that instance had some health checks. Since our ELB got that internal IP address, the requests are coming to our ELB.   I can use iptables to block traffic from this src ip but this is only a short term solution... who knows when our ELB internal ip would change again and there will be some other constant traffic from some other src.  I wish there is an option on Security groups to block traffic based on source IP.  AWS - anyways to resolve this issue permanently?  thanks.

After investigation a better title would be:Windows 2008 and SSL configuration makes an instance unusable:Here is the Repro:1. Launch a Windows 2008 Server Instance2. Import a key that has been exported from another Server3. Stop or Reboot the serverResultCannot connect to server via RDP or HTTP. Server logs are emptyWorkaroundCreate a new certificate request, re-key from the certificate provider, complete the certificate request on the server instance. Some posts have said that importing a key, exporting it, and then importing into the personal store is another workaround but several of us have failed to get that to work.It appears that this is unique to Windows 2008.Originally reported in February 2010: http://developer.amazonwebservices.com/connect/thread.jspa?messageID=196935𰅇It is not clear whether a properly functioning instance can be cloned. The root cause is unknown at this point and there is no evidence that AWS personnel have investigated. Message was edited by: donrule1107

I owe an apology to the AWS support folks. They were working this issue but I misread their response to mean that they had closed the case once I got it working. In summary the issue was that the intermediate certificates were not being installed when you simply exported and then re-imported the cert. A more complete discussion is here http://developer.amazonwebservices.com/connect/thread.jspa?threadID=52087  Message was edited by: donrule1107

Distributed/Load Balancing -- FileSystem Issue, NFS, PersistenFS, S3FS ??? Hello !  I have crawled this forums for a while now. We are trying to set up a Load Balanced Cloud website hosting architecture using Amazon AWS' EC2 (Using AutoScale and LoadBalancing).  Although the Database aspect seems a non-issue since we intend to use RDS which both is backup'd up and offers automatic fail-over using Multi-AZ deployment. We think the size of RDS instances would meet our needs until Amazon deploy the Read Replica feature is released.  The File System Aspect is, however, a totally different issue on its own and, afawk, does not seems solved yet. In the following are the solutions we found. It would be greatly appreciated if you could provide practical feedback on these solutions or on new ones.  Moreover, we need consistency between DB and FS: If a new DB entry link to a new file, we need the file to be available at the same time as the DB entry. Although we could abide by a few minutes delay between the user input and the actual propagation, DB and FS updates must be in sync (and obviously never fail). We prefer also this delay to be as short as possible.  1st: Distributed PersistenFS ( http://www.presistentfs.com ): One R/W host AND many R-O hosts simultaneously.  PersistentFS seems neither  to support this feature nor to intend to.   2nd: PersistentFS mounted R/W on a single EC2 instance and shared by NFS (either R-O or R/W).  This solution is not an option for us because of the NFS server which is a single point of failure. Moreover, this would imply Inter-AZ communication in the case of Multi-AZ deployment. Of course, that would be the case with the DB too but, as far as we understand, FS access generate much more data transfer than DB access (in term of data size).   3rd: S3FS ( http://code.google.com/p/s3fs/wiki/FuseOverAmazon ). Although it seems to be SID, they support Distributed Access (one R/W, many R-O simultaneously) and even Distributed R/W Access (many R/W simultaneously).  Did anyone ever tried it and would be able to provide feedback ? Any latency or desync issue ?   Afaiu, S3 does not provide neither Read-After-Update not Read-After-Delete consistency (only Eventual consistency overall and Read-After-Write consistency for us-east and eu-west regions). Does that mean that any Distributed FS solution based on S3 would imply possible desync issues ?  More importantly what is the delay implied in the "Eventual consistency", is it in the order of secondes ? minutes ? hours ?  Any feedback or help will help us and be greatly appreciated. Thanks in advance !

Forget about using anything S3-backed that pretends to be a filesystem. S3 does not present a POSIX-compliant service and so your app will have difficulty if it uses standard file access patterns for an S3-based filesystem.  The "eventual" in S3's eventual consistency is typically under 2 seconds.  Take a look at GlusterFS, which is a distributed filesystem, open source, and has support available.  http://www.gluster.org/

Tanks for your answer.I have read the documentation available on GlusterFS Website, but I fail to see how I would use it.Don't hesitate to correct me if I'm wrong, but afaiu, we would need "another" cluster to provide the filesystem. And this cluster has to be of fixed size (e.g., no possibility to have AutoScale going on) since GlusterFS does not support easy add of a server.Basically, that would mean setting up our "own version of S3".I am not sure that would be an suitable solution for our needs.Ooth, could you, please, develop on the possible difficulties for S3-based FS ?Eventual consistency of 2seconds seems quite acceptable.Our file access pattern would be an occasional "write" with many frequent "read", as usual for a webserver.If I have the assurance that the filesystem consistency is achieved within a few seconds, I don't see any reason why Apache ou PHP would complain about it.I understand that S3 is not posix-compliant (although I was not able to find the precise definition of this term) but the supported subset seems enough to reach practical usability.

Gluster has just released v 3.1 which allows adding nodes to the storage array without restarting the cluster. You could run Gluster on another cluster of servers, but I think it is also possible to run it within your web cluster. Gluster has pretty good read performance, but poor write performance for many small files relative to an EBS or ephemeral storage. As such I don't think it is very good for apps that generate lots of small cache files. I don't use it so I could be wrong.

You're a little vague in your requirements.  Do you really need a filesystem?  Or do you just need a shared file resource.  If the latter, then i'd say store your objects in S3 and then put pointers to the S3 objects in the RDS database.  If you really need a filesystem you could use (shudder) NFS.  With autoscaling it would be possible to keep an instance attached to some EBS volumes to serve as the NFS storage master.  If the instance dies for whatever reason, auto scaling will create a new one for you.  (In this case "scaling" is really a misnomer - you're only scaling to one instance!  But at least there is a guarantee that that instance will always be around.)Unless the software is really out of your control, I'd go the S3 route.  If you create your bucket in US West or EU region, you get read-after-write consistency, which might serve your needs better than the eventual consistency from the US Standard region.Without knowing more about your particular requirements it's hard to be precise but hopefully this gives you some ideas.

64bit EBS backed image on instance-type m1.small Hi,  I am new to EC2.  How can I create an EBS backed CentOS 5.4 64 bit AMI that can be instanciated as m1.small?  I've created images by 1. modifying a publically available EBS backed image, and 2. converting one of the S3 based AMI of ours into EBS based. neither works.  When I am trying web-console to launch an instance from these images -- the drop down to choose instance type does not show m1.small. It does show t1.micro, m1.large and others though.  When I try ec2-ami-tool, this is what I get [root@ip-10-170-61-12 ~]# ec2-run-instances ami-48d12521 -n 1 -t m1.small -K mykey.pem -C myCer.pem  Client.InvalidParameterValue: The requested instance type's architecture (i386) does not match the architecture in the manifest for ami-48d12521 (x86_64)  --------------- One of the main reason behind moving from S3 to EBS was availability of m1.small on EBS backed images for 64 bit machines. m1. large is too much for our requirement.   Can someone point me how to create an AMI for 64bit CentOS 5.4 that can be instanciated as an m1.small instance-type?

Best as I can tell, Amazon doesn't let you run anything 64-bit on a small image.  Which is a colossal pain in the ass, and means I have to maintain double the images so that I have a 32-bit image to run on m1.smalls and c1.mediums and a 64-bit one to run on everything bigger.  So if you need a shoulder to cry on, I'm here for you.

It is not possible.  m1.small and c1.medium are 32-bit only, for both EBS and S3.  t1.micro is the only instance type which supports both 64-bit and 32-bit; all other types are exclusively 32-bit or 64-bit.

EBS volume DOES NOT persist data after termination. Hello,I have created an windows 2008 server AMI. I started it and attached an EBS volume to it. Initially the volume did not show in the drive list, so i RESTARTED the instance and then it showed up. My app deployed on Windows 2008 server instance writes PDF reports to the attached volume. But when I terminate and start the instance, the PDF report disappear. According to amazon documentation, EBS volume should persist data after termination.Any pointers or info on this?When i terminate the instance and start it, i can see the volume but data is missing.ThanksAbhijit

Hi,First, if you are terminating your instance and launching a new one from the same AMI, your new instance will not be aware of the EBS volume that was attached to your previous instance.  If you are doing a stop (as opposed to a terminate), you should ensure that your volume remains attached to your instance (it should).  You should also make sure that Windows is properly mounting the volume to the anticipated drive letter.Finally, you should make sure that you are writing your output to the EBS volume, and not to the local ephemeral storage (which will not be retained across a stop/start).Regards,-Jason

AMI fstab borked wont boot Guys,  I am ashamed to admit defeat and turn to the forum for help.  I am developing an AMI from scratch. Everything seems to work except that I cannot get my fstab correct to mount the ephemeral0 storage and swap correctly.  I have been able to find various guides on the web (including Amazon sources) that provide "correct" fstab configurations, but each of these that I have tried results in needing to run fdisk on boot up and the boot process halting.  Here is my fstab for my AMI for small instances:  /dev/sda1		/		ext3	defaults 1 1 /dev/sda2		/mnt		ext3	defaults 1 2 /dev/sda3		swap		swap	defaults 0 0  When I ec2-bundle-image I have also attempted to pass the -B "ami=sda1,root=/dev/sda1,ephemeral0=sda2,swap=sda3" option. In all cases the boot process halts on when the machine looks to mount /dev/sda2 on /mnt.  A nudge in the right direction would be appreciated.  cheers, --Ben

If you're doing Boot From EBS, I found that you can't have the "/mnt" entry. I couldn't explain why exactly, but Amazon told me the ephemeral store isn't available to those instances in the normal way.  David
So how *do* you mount the ephemeral0 disk on the new instance?
I'm going through the same issue... Finally got a working EBS-bootable AMI, but no ephemeral storage.

Fixed my own problem.Turns out that you can still have the ephemeral storage, you just have to set it up yourself, either when you create your AMI, or when you start an instance. I bundled mine up into the AMI:ec2-register --snapshot snap-5555555 --description "AMI Description Goes Here" --name "ebs-centos54-x86_64-server-20100225" --architecture x86_64 --root-device-name /dev/sda1 -b /dev/sdb=ephemeral0-b /dev/sdb=ephemeral0  does the magic here. You'll still need a line in your /etc/fstab to have it mounted automatically at boot though.

Same problem. I manually mount an extra EBS volume (whether xfs or ext3, with data) at /vol and it works fine. However, I need to have it mounted automatically, so I add the following line to fstab:/dev/sdh /vol xfs noatime 0 0And then I create a new EBS image (all via the console).But when I run such image, it does not boot. It probably does not get through the fstab line.Any ideas how to change the fstab line so that it a) does not break the booting process and b) mounts the EBS volume.Thanks!

The problem must have been related to the mountall problem in Ubuntu Lucid 10.04. I've fixed mountall as described at http://alestic.com/2010/09/ec2-bug-mountall and now the fstab mount of an additional EBS volume works fine.

When I start one from AWS Management Console web interface and pick the Extra Large, I only get 30 Gig. Here is the command I used:ec2-run-instances ami-d9e40db0 --b "/dev/sda1=snap-289c2740:1290:true" -g ec2windows -t m1.xlargeThe command prompt returns pending. EBS volumes can be a maximum of 1TB (1024GB) in size. Your request is probably failing because it can't create a volume of 1290 GB in size.  To get beyond the 1TB limit on a single instance you can attach  multiple EBS volumes to the instance. I don't know about Windows, but Linux has tools that allow the OS to relate to multiple underlying EBS volumes as if they are a single logical volume (I'm thinking of LVM).

Helloooooo??? where is the support of AWS?José
ok I am going to kill the instance.Fail AWSJose

Jose,  Don't get too frustrated - the best way to handle an instance that seems to be misbehaving is to kill it and launch a replacement.   Cloud encourages you to view your CPU and memory as disposable. This view is one philosophical change that helps you write apps that can benefit from the elasticity and scalability promised by the cloud. There's little difference (architecturally) between an application that requires more instances because one of them is misbehaving, and between an application that requires more resources because the current resources are insufficient to meet the demand.  Cloud infrastructure is made from commodity hardware, which has reasonable - though not great - failure rates. Reliability beyond the AWS SLA requires that your application be written to accomodate cloud infrastructure failure.

The statement I run is: "ec2-bundle-vol -d /mnt -k pk-<MyPrivateKey>.pem --cert cert-<MyCert>.pem -u <MyAcctNumber> -p <MyPrefixName>"  The output for this that I get is: "Please specify a value for arch [i386]: i386 Copying / into the image file /mnt/<MyPrefixName>... Splitting /mnt/<MyPrefixName>.tar.gz.enc... Created <MyPrefixName>.part.000 Created <MyPrefixName>.part.001 Created <MyPrefixName>.part.002 . . . This all appears ok to me except not sure about the "unable to read instance meta-data" statements.  2.  Next I run the ec2-migrate-manifest statement as the research I've done on this has pointed me to running this statement to specify the region you want to run the image in.  The statement I run is: "ec2-migrate-manifest -m /mnt/<MyPrefixName>.manifest.xml -c cert-<MyCert>.pem -k pk-<MyPrivateKey>.pem -a <MyAccessKey> -s <MySecretAccessKey> --region us-west-1"  The output for this that I get is: "Backing up manifest... warning: peer certificate won't be verified in this SSL session warning: peer certificate won't be verified in this SSL session Successfully migrated /mnt/<MyPrefixName>.manifest.xml It is now suitable for use in us-west-1."  This also appears generally ok to me.  I'm assuming the warning statements are ok??  3.  Next I run the ec2-upload-bundle statement to upload this to my S3 bucket.  The statement I run is: "ec2-upload-bundle -b <MyS3BucketName> -m /mnt/<MyPrefixName>.manifest.xml -a <MyAccessKey> -s <MySecretAccessKey>"  The output for this that I get is: "You are bundling in one region, but uploading to another. If the kernel or ramdisk associated with this AMI are not in the target region, AMI registration will fail. You can use the ec2-migrate-manifest tool to update your manifest file with a kernel and ramdisk that exist in the target region. Are you sure you want to continue? [y/N]y Creating bucket... Uploading bundled image parts to the S3 bucket <MyS3BucketName> ... Uploaded <MyPrefixName>.part.000 Uploaded <MyPrefixName>.part.001 Uploaded <MyPrefixName>.part.002 . . . Uploaded <MyPrefixName>.part.136 Uploaded <MyPrefixName>.part.137 Uploaded <MyPrefixName>.part.138 Uploading manifest ... Uploaded manifest. Bundle upload completed."  Note the message about bundling in one region but uploading to another.  I don't know why I'm getting this message at this point as I did run the ec2-migrate statement which it suggests.  This is why I continue.  After that it appears to upload ok.  Fyi...My S3 is in North America, but I don't see any reference to a us-east vs. us-west region for S3's.  Are there?  If so, then maybe that is my problem.  4.  Finally I run the ec2-register statement to attempt to register this image so that I can use this to create new instances, etc.  The statement I run is: "ec2-register <MyS3BucketName>/<MyPrefixName>.manifest.xml -n <MyImageName> -K pk-<MyPrivateKey>.pem -C cert-<MyCert>.pem --region us-west-"  The output for this that I get is: "Client.InvalidManifest: HTTP 301 (Moved Permanently) response for URL http://<MyS3BucketName>.s3.amazonaws.com:80/<MyPrefixName>.manifest.xml: check your manifest path is correct and in the correct region." For anybody interested, I found my problem.  It turned out that I wasn't specifying the correct location in my upload-bundle statement.  I needed to specifically specify "us-west-1" instead of leaving it blank.  Once I did that, everything worked perfectly.

instance freezes when attaching elastic ip Hello, we have an instance-store instance i-a15524ca that freezes when attaching an allocated elastic ip.  What can I do to track down the problem?

If you mean that the instance "freezes up" because your SSH or Remote Desktop connection to the instance freezes, then that is expected behavior. Attaching an Elastic IP removes the prior public IP address from the instance, which is where the SSH or RDP session is connected to. You need to re-establish your SSH/RDP connection to the instance, using the Elastic IP address (either by DNS name or by actual numerical address) again after assigning the Elastic IP. Usually it takes around a minute for the new Elastic IP address to actually be associated with the instance - so there might be a slight delay in establishing the new session.

MOSS on EC2 Hi,I need to get work MOSS 2010 (Microsoft Office SharPoint Service)  on EC2 Windows Server instance. Can I use my MAPS (microsoft Action Pack Service) licence for sharepoint server and CAL? ThanksRamesh

Hi Ramesh,When you launch a Windows Instance - the Windows licensing costs are bundled into the hourly charge (hence the higher price between Windows and the free versions of Linux).Everything else is "bring your own" - and that includes MOSS.That means that you can (and must) use whatever licensing arrangements you would have use on your own, physical, servers.As a disclaimer, Microsoft licensing is always touchy issue - so it's probably a good idea to validate that with your Microsoft account representative or give a call to the Microsoft Licensing Center.Regards, Jonathan@CloudStacking.com

Thank you for asking about the kernel security vulnerability. The specific vulnerability was patched on 2010-09-18.We release kernel-2.6.34.6-54.24 to the Amazon Linux AMI repositories, as well as release Amazon Linux AMI 0.9.8-beta. For more information please see:http://aws.amazon.com/security/security-bulletins/

In addition to the existing fix for the Amazon Linux AMI we are also evaluating the impact of this vulnerability on existing AKIs that are available inside of EC2.  This post will be updated as more information is available.  Additional information will also be made available in the AWS Security Center here:  http://aws.amazon.com/security/security-bulletins/It is important to note that this vulnerability corresponds to a local privilege escalation within a running instance.  That means that a user or process must already have access to the system to escalate to root privileges. One immediate mitigation available to all AMI builders is the use of PV-GRUB to enable a kernel to be loaded directly from the AMI. With this method it is then possible to update the kernel in the AMI to a version that is not impacted by this vulnerability. AMI builders will have to check with the Linux distributor to ensure that the kernel they install through this method is not impacted by this vulnerability.  The process of using PV-GRUB inside of EC2 is described in more detail here:http://developer.amazonwebservices.com/connect/entry.jspa?externalID=3967&categoryID=174

Instance i-a99c92c3 completely unresponsive Our m2.4xlarge instance i-a99c92c3 is completely unresponsive to any IP connection, instance termination, or volume detachment. Hi there If your volumes are still in stuck in a detaching state you can use the EC2 command line tool "ec2-detach volume-id --force" to dismount them from your instance. If you do not have the EC2 tools installed you could alternatively install the ElasticFox (Firefox) plugin that will allow you to also to detach drives stuck in a detaching state.I had a look at your instance i-a99c92c3 and the underlying hard ware looks good. I think you must have had something go wrong at the application/OS level to effect your access to this instance.When you re-attach your drives to a replacement instance I would suggest examining any logs for a potential cause for your inaccessibility.

Thanks Jason,  The force option is definitely a good option for next time around. Thanks for pointing that out. Luckily, we were able to build a new master database from an up-to-date replicated slave.  I'm still a little confused as to why the instance took an hour to terminate. I suppose if there were something wrong at the OS/Kernel level, than the init process may not be able to shut down everything properly and could have been hanging on one of its child processes. Anyway, my speculation isn't helpful but I would like to know this: Is there a timeout on the termination process, whereby an instance is issued a "hard" shutdown regardless of the state of its guest OS?  Dan

Limit to AMI Snapshot? Hi all,   Is there a a limit to how big a snapshot can be? We have an AMI with a number of disks, one is 1TB partition. When we try a snapshot, it fails with a server error after an hour or so of running. Has anyone experienced something similar? Is there a limit to how big each partition can be?  Thanks in advance.   ISG
Hi there Can you confirm the instance, volume, snapshot id's so we can take a look for you.

Hi there, here's the information you requested.   Instance id:  i-85a0eaf2 AMI Id: ami-c26f5ab6 Volume:  vol-2625ea4f (currently attached to the above instance) Snapshot: snap-e206aa8b Volume: 1TB  Kindest regards,   Ming

Hi there can you confirm that you are still having problems. I have checked the history of the volume vol-2625ea4f I can see a succesful snapshot of this volume called snap-082a8361 which has since been deleted.Also one thing to note that EBS snapshots are done at a very low priority to minimise impact on EBS volumes so if you accidently launch multiple snapshot requests on a single volume this can cause problems.

Dear Jason,   I will find out and get back to you. I think we might be still experiencing problems.   Is there a limit to how big the volumes can be? The time it takes to take a snapshop (either of the volume or the instance) is dependent on the size but is there a risk of the process timing out?

AWS API/AMI CLI tools take way too much time to run Hello  I just started using AWS. I always preferred the command line interfaces (I reckon I'm old school  ) so my first logical step was to install the AWS API/AMI CLI tools. I did that and the tools work... kind of. Every time I launch a tool it just hangs for around 3 minutes doing absolutely nothing, then it does what it was supposed to do.   Regardless of which tool I launch it will just hang in a waitpid(-1,...) for some 3 minutes (I noticed this using strace), during which time there is no network activity whatsoever (I checked using wireshark on the same CentOS box). After the 3 minutes the waitpid return code is equal to the PID of the ec2-cmd process and the command finally does it's job in just a few more seconds. Thanks for your help! I should have mentioned this... I never liked Java Since I have practically no experience with it I had no clue about jstack.

So I searched for it now... it's not on my CentOS 5.5 system, I could not find a jstack package using the CentOS and rpmforge yum repositories, I couldn't find it as a individually downloadable file/package at Sun/Oracle... BUT I found a page ( http://blogs.sun.com/alanb/entry/jstack ) stating that "jstack isn't the only way to obtain a thread dump of a running application. Developers have long been accustomed to using Ctrl-\ (or Ctrl-Break if you are on Windows) to get a thread dump of an application that is running interactively. An alternative to the key sequence on Solaris (or Linux) is to send a QUIT signal to the target process. In that case the target processs prints a thread dump to its standard output (which can be pain if you don't know where the log file is)."

After reading this I sent the QUIT signal to the hung Java process running ec2-describe-instances and I captured the output hoping it might help troubleshoot the problem. Unfortunately the output is way over my Java knowledge level so I attach here 2 files: one was generated using openjdk-1.6.0.0.out (the stock jre on CentOS 5.5) and the other was generated using jre1.6.0_21 (just downloaded from java.com).

Please let me know if this helps or if I can provide any other information to help.

Thanks a lot!
Re: AWS API/AMI CLI tools take way too much time to run
Posted by: ingenion
Posted on: Oct 10, 2010 1:13 PM
in response to: angiospermalbastra
  Reply
Correct
it looks like you might be running on an ipv6 enabled system and hitting a jvm bug (1). There seems to be 3 approaches to solve this problem:
- tell the jvm to switch back to ipv4
  • allow ipv6 traffic from localhost to localhost
  • disable ipv6 altogether on the system

for the first approach you would need to set the environment variable $EC2_JVM_ARGS to

-Djava.net.preferIPv4Stack=true (no whitespace after -D)

and try the command again.

HTH,
ingenion

---
(1) http://bugs.sun.com/bugdatabase/view_bug.do?bug_id=6483406
Re: AWS API/AMI CLI tools take way too much time to run
Posted by: angiospermalbastra
Posted on: Oct 10, 2010 3:25 PM
in response to: ingenion
  Reply
YESSSSS!!!! Thanks a million!

The system is indeed IPv6 enabled, but I block all IPv6 connections using iptables -P INPUT DROP... never have any issues with this until now.

export EC2_JVM_ARGS=-Djava.net.preferIPv4Stack=true did the trick and you just reduced my execution time from 3'15" to 5"! Thank you so much!

Cheers!

Elastic Load Balancing sticky session Hi,I'd like to ask you a Elastic Load Balancing (ELB) question.Is it possible to make cookie by ELB ?I read following site. And I found "load balancer-generated cookie".http://docs.amazonwebservices.com/ElasticLoadBalancing/latest/DeveloperGuide/index.html?SvcIntro.htmlI think "load balancer-generated cookie" means that ELB makes cookie.If so, for example, it is not necessary to set jvmRoute in Tomcat server.xml.Is it correct ?Thanks and regards,Kenji

ELB relies on cookies only for sticky sessions. If you haven't set up sticky sessions then ELB does not use cookies.  The ELB session stickiness cookie controls the duration of the stickiness: after the cookie expires, the stickiness association will expire. There are two choices for controlling the session stickiness duration:  - set it to a specific timeout period. This is done using a cookie provided by the ELB.  set it to follow the lifetime of an application cookie.   If you set your ELB to have its own cookie then you do not need to use a cookie from your application for stickiness. However, your application's cookie is the only way your application can "remember" the browser session. You probably don't want to remove the application cookie.  Check out my article offerring an explanation of sticky sessions in general and EC2's ELB stickiness feature: http://www.shlomoswidler.com/2010/04/elastic-load-balancing-with-sticky-sessions.html

Thank you.I try to launch many Application (AP) servers by using same AMI.But when I use a load balancer, it is necessary to set jvmRoute into cookie by AP.It is inconvenient for autoscale.So if ELB has its own cookie, it is easy to launch and terminate AP instances.By the way, this function (LB has its own cookie), does only ELB have the function ?Because of other reasons, we try to use apache proxy balancer for LB on EC2.However, I cannot find the function of the apache proxy balancer.If you know, please let me know.Thanks and regards,Kenji

HAProxy is a much better load balancer than Apache. If you need SSL termination at the load balancer or load balancing a root domain then you can't use ELB and HAProxy is a great choice. The drawback of HAProxy is that you must take care of the HAProxy instance - HA, elasticity - by yourself.

What exactly does "as-terminate-instance-in-auto-scaling-group" do? I have been using EC2 for a long time but am a relative newcomer to the Auto Scaling system. After having read the docs carefully, I cannot see anything which the "as-terminate-instance-in-auto-scaling-group" does differently from the "old fashioned" way of terminating an instance (from the command line or from the EC2 console).Is there in fact any behavior at all in this utility (as-terminate....) which is unique to the tool and not something I can get from the standard console? Can anyone please explain why I would ever use it?Thank you.

Hey Bryan,Autoscaling manages two additional aspects in addition to what happens with standard RunInstances calls.1) If there is one or more Elastic Load Balancers configured for the group, Autoscaling takes care of adding and removing your instances from those load balancers for you.  In this case, TerminateInstanceInAutoScaling group cleans those instances out of the load balancer for you.2) The metrics coming from instances within an Autoscaling group get an addtional "AutoScalingGroup" metric dimension attached to them, that way you can ask "What is the aggregate CPU Utilization within this group".  When autoscaling terminates an instance, it cleans up this information as well.  However, since the instance would be shut down and not emitting metrics, you probably wouldn't notice.In addition to coordinating with other services, Autoscaling also maintains a detailed audit trail of all launches and terminates which occur within your group.  So calling TerminateInstanceInAutoScalingGroup will leave behind a long lived activity in your audit trail (available via the DescribeScalingActivities API).  A terminate via the normal TerminateInstances API does not leave behind an audit trail item.What probably confuses the matter is that Autoscaling monitors the state of instances contained within a group.  So if you called TerminateInstance on an Autoscaling managed instance, shortly after that instance terminates, Autoscaling will detect the "out of band" instance termination, and will create a new Terminate scaling activity which will go ahead and clean up the load balancer and monitoring configuration for you while also adding an item to your audit trail of when the system detected the terminated instance and cleaned up after it.I hope that helps, let us know if you have any other questions.-Geoff

Geoff,Thank you for the detailed reply. Your first two points make sense in terms of explaining the differences. However, your final paragraph throws it all together again, and makes me think there is no net difference at all. Thus your answer really isn't helpful, because, I still cannot complete the following sentence:"I need to terminate an instance in an auto-scaling group. I had better remember to use the tool as-terminate-instance-in-auto-scaling-group, because if I don't, then X will happen."Can you succinctly explain what "X" would be?Thank you,Bryan
If your auto-scaling group is also managing an ELB then using ec2-terminate-instance will see the ELB continue to send traffic to the shutting-down instance, until it fails the health check.

Just in case anyone else runs into this issue with the alestic EBS images the problem was with the cloud-init package. How can I set up ssh to work without key pair .pem file I am trying to set up a training server for my customers. They will need to be able to ssh in to the server to do some configuration. Is there any way I can set them up an account that doesn't need me to pass them the key pair pem file.I add the user account and set a password but then can not log in using ssh to it.[root@training1 ~]# adduser testuser[root@training1 ~]# passwd testuserChanging password for user testuser.New UNIX password: Retype new UNIX password: passwd: all authentication tokens updated successfully.[root@training1 ~]#I am using "Basic 64-bit Amazon Linux AMI 1.0 "

Managed to fix this myself by reversing the "Tips for Securing Your EC2 Instance"Log in to your instance as root and edit the ssh daemon configuration file:
vi /etc/ssh/sshd_config
Find the line
PasswordAuthentication no
and change it to
PasswordAuthentication yes
