How do you automate failover on EC2? Of the folks managing their own clusters (i.e. not using/paying for Amazon Autoscale, Rightscale, Scalr, etc.), how are you managing your instances on EC2 and handling (e.g.) failover? I'm wondering if most folks just end up writing their own boatloads of scripts against the EC2 API, as I suspect.  That's certainly our approach: whip up our own Python Boto-based monitoring/restarting daemon that runs off-site, listening for UDP keep-alives from our instances. On failure, we snapshot volumes, register images, start new instances, delete old volumes, and so on.  Every so often, when hacking on our scripts, I think there must be some open-source tools out there that deal with these issues already, and which don't have the constraints of (say) Scalr, but I always come back from Google empty-handed. (Things like Scalr have are pretty limited in the supported set/versions/configurations of software, and have specialized and IMO cumbersome ways of manipulating these setups.)  Also, the Linux-HA/Pacemaker ecosystem (Heartbeat, ldirectord, etc.) sounds like it isn't really suited for EC2 [1]. (But then I found [2] - though I'm not sure this is really a high-quality solution).  [1] http://serverfault.com/questions/186826/do-pacemaker-heartbeat-etc-make-sense-for-ec2 [2] http://developer.amazonwebservices.com/connect/thread.jspa?messageID=195373
The requirements here tend to be pretty custom which is probably why it's hard to find a pre-built solution. Let us know if you find something awesome

My question for you, Yang, would be - what is it that you want to do that AutoScaling/ELB can't do?  Perhaps submitting it as a feature request to AWS would let everybody reap the benefits.I'm using autoscaling/ELB and it's fine, but my needs are relatively simple.

I'm sure Autoscaling serves its purpose nicely and simply - controlling the number of instances based on various monitored signals. We have a relatively straightforward implementation of most of the same feature set implemented via a boto daemon. While our scripts are pretty specialized for our own use, they don't have to be - if we ever find the time we'd love to throw it up on github. This was just one of the simpler things that we surprisingly never found floating around.  For us, automating failover includes other things as well. When (for instance) our database primary goes down, we perform shared-disk failover, by reattaching the DB volume to another surviving instance, while we recover the terminated instance by building an image out of its EBS volume and instantiating it, while retaining snapshots for backup. We use replication, but since the major databases only support asynchronous replication, we avoid failing over to those to avoid losing data, and only use them for backup and spreading the read load.  Again, I think dafaleiting was basically right - a lot of the meatier, hairier things are probably simply too specialized to make general. And certain problems may be made easier via better underlying distributed systems. I just thought I'd solicit others' thoughts here.

Chef and Puppet are two open-source frameworks that provide the ability to do exactly that. There are even scripts/recipes/actions/verbs available for those frameworks to handle common operational scenarios (e.g. failover of a MySQL master).  http://www.opscode.com/chef/ http://www.puppetlabs.com/

My experiences with those tools have been less than stellar. The scripts may not work if I'm not using an expected version of the software - happens frequently. And for any automation operations that are not supported out of the box by one of their scripts (also frequent), you're on your own, except now you have to additionally deal with Puppet or Chef. Finally, for system configuration, I find it much easier to just go in and munge things by hand, then clone the VM.

Amazon Linux AMI Do you recommend Amazon AMI for mid-scale LAMP? Greetings,I am new to EC2 and ready to launch my application. I am expecting kinda mid-scale traffic with mid-scale read/write.And will scale it later if traffic is getting heavier.I am looking into various LINUX operating systems(64 BIT)Red HatCentosUbuntoAmazon AMI.Documentation for Amazon AMI says " The Amazon Linux AMI was designed to be small by default "Does that mean for small scale applications? And how well you will rate Amazon AMI compared to other available Linux operating systems?

Hi Sumeer,The documentation for the Amazon Linux AMI is referring to the number of packages installed by default, not the amount of traffic it is designed to handle or the scale of applications built with it. It's a great idea to evaluate a variety of base AMIs available in the catalog and find one that is best suited for your application.Of course, we'd be thrilled if you choose the Amazon Linux AMI.

I switched one of our instances from Debian to the Amazon Linux AMI and we are running a LAMP stack.  Presently, I don't see a great advantage in using the Amazon distro compared to the others you mentioned but I'm hoping that, as more people adopt it, you'll get a better support for their own fine-tuned OS.  If there is any distro you are already familiar with and can do the job, I recommend you use that. It's worth mentioning that the Amazon one is very similar to Red Hat or CentOS.  My only grief with this AMI is that it comes with its repository of vetted packages but I wish they were more up-to-date.  Good luck  Shariff

Connection limit on Cluster Compute Instances We are performing some load tests on an EC2 cluster made up of 3 Cluster Compute Quadruple Extra Large Instances.In our test scenario, 2 machines (clients) open TCP connections to the third machine (server).We hit a limit of 524,222 TCP connections, which we cannot exceed even after tuning the right Linux kernel parameters. So we guess there is a hard limit on the Amazon infrastructure. This is demonstrated by the fact that we can open further connections locally on the server machine. Furthermore, we can exclude any client-side limits, because in a preliminary test we were able to open 524k connections from a single client only, rather than 262k connections from each client.We had understood that Cluster Computer Instances do not suffer suchlimitations... What a disappointment!
Can anybody from Amazon please confirm this limit?We even submitted this to Amazon support but nobody has answered until now.Thanks

being billed for not running instances! We are only running one instance and terminated 1 in the first of October. Account activity shows we are running both and billing us for both.What is the issue? Plus we never had an option to stop instance only terminate why?

Check other regions in the AWS Management Console. Perhaps you're running an instance in a region you aren't looking at currently.  Only EBS-backed instances can be Stopped. You're probably running an instance-store instance, which cannot be Stopped, only Terminated.

two elb questions: TCP PING FINS?  and  2 ELB->1 INSTANCE? Hi folks, I have two questions about elb:1. If the health check is tcp, the load balancer opens a tcp socket to the ec2 instance at the port, and if it succeeds, then the instance is healthy (subject to threshholds of course). My question: if it succeeds in opening the tcp socket, it immediately closes it with the proper termination protocol, issuing FIN, waiting for ACK, etc to the instance side, right?2. From reading some other discussion threads, it seems like it is possible to have two load balancers that, for example, route to two different processes (different ports) that are running on the same ec2 instance. Is this true? The AWS Management Console doesn't seem to allow this when setting up an ELB - why is that?thanks!Colin  changed subject   Message was edited by: thecolinator

I don't know offhand about #1, but if you test it please share your results.  #2, it is possible to create a single ELB that has multiple listeners, as long as each listener port (the port facing the web) is different - the instance-ports (the port to which the traffic is sent on the instance) can be the same or different between the multiple listeners. It is also possible to create multiple ELBs with the same instances in them - in this case you can selectively split the traffic on a single incoming port into separate instance ports. You can do this with the command-line utilities. Here is an article showing how (and why it might be useful): http://shlomoswidler.com/2009/07/ec2-instance-belonging-to-multiple-elbs.html

Making an AMI available on another Region Hi,I have re-bundled an AMI on US-EAST Region, How can I launch a new instance on US-WEST using this private AMI. If it's not possible how can I copy this AMI to US-WEST Region.Please advice.Thanks,Anoop

Hi,I found the commands to do this. Let me post this if in case some one needs this.1. Use EC2 Migrate command to migrate the US-EAST AMI to US-WEST ec2-migrate-bundle -k your-key.epm -c your-cert.pem -a your-acesskey -s your-secret-key --bucket source-bucket(bucket on US EAST in my case) --manifest sourcemanifest.manifest.xml  --location us-west-1 --region us-west-1 --destination-bucket destination-bucket-name(no need to create a bucket, command will create a new bucket by given name in US WEST Region).2. Register the AMIec2-register --region us-west-1 --name "newly-created-bucket-name/ami name" newly-created-bucket-name/ami name-manifest.xml3. Verify it through Amazon Management console. You should change the region to "US-WEST" by clicking the drop down on top-left  side of the AWS Management console.You may mail me at anpl1980[at]gmail[dot]com, if you need any support on this.Thanks,Anoop
You might want to try this online-tool we wrote: https://cloudyscripts.com/tool/show/5Hope this helps!

Amazon EC2 Instance Type Storage Query Hi,I have started the m1.xlarge public instance. By default below is the configuration for the instance type i have chosen.Extra Large Instance15 GB memory 8 EC2 Compute Units (4 virtual cores with 2 EC2 Compute Units each)1,690 GB instance storage (4×420 GB plus 10 GB root partition)64-bit platformI/O Performance: HighAPI name: m1.xlarge But after initiating the boot i can see the storage is not there as shown in the configuration type. My current disk storage isFilesystem            Size   Used  Avail  Use%  Mounted on/dev/sda1              9.9G   2.8G   6.7G   30%       /tmpfs                    7.6G     0      7.6G   0%         /lib/init/rwudev                     7.6G   468K  7.6G   1%         /devtmpfs                    7.6G     0      7.6G   0%         /dev/shm/dev/sdb               414G  306G   88G    78%       /mnt1,690 GB instance storage (4×420 GB plus 10 GB root partition) is what given in the description of the instance but i cannot see the same in the instance, i can see and use only 1x420GB in /mnt folder. Can someone explain me why? it is really urgent...ThanksJoe

By default, only the 1st of the 4x 420 GB ephemeral volumes is formatted and mounted. The others should be available to your instance as /dev/sdc, /dev/sdd, and /dev/sde. Depending on how you plan to use those disks, you may need to create partitions and/or filesystems on them before using them.

Can I move a key pair to different region? Hi  We have a key pair in us-east. We would now like to run some servers in eu-west. Is it possible to import our us-east key pair to the eu-west or do we have to create and keep track of another aws credential?  Paul  Message was edited by: ec2bod

Hi,You should be able to take your public key (which you can retrieve from ~/.ssh/authorized_keys on your instance in us-east-1), and import it to the eu-west region using the ec2-import-keypair command:http://docs.amazonwebservices.com/AWSEC2/latest/CommandLineReference/ApiReference-cmd-ImportKeyPair.htmlYou will also need to pass --region eu-west-1 to the command to specify the correct region to import the key into.Regards,-Jason

volume incorrectly reporting full I started getting "no space left on device" when transferring files to my volume.  I assumed the volume was full (2 GB).  I created a snapshot and then created a 4GB volume from that snapshot.  Then mounted the new volume.  The new volume is giving me the same message.df command showsFilesystem           1K-blocks      Used Available Use% Mounted on/dev/sda1             10321208   2698652   7098268  28% //dev/sda2            153899044    192080 145889340   1% /mntnone                    870472         0    870472   0% /dev/shm/dev/sdf               2064208   2064208         0 100% /mnt/hzvolume/dev/sdg               2064208   2064208         0 100% /volsdf is the 2GB volumesdg is the 4GB volumeEC2 cloud shows them as 2 GB and 4GB.  So, i'm positive I created it as a 4 GB volume.  Any insights on what my problem is?

Your volume may be 4GB, but your filesystem is still 2GB. You need to resize your filesystem to use the full space.If your filesystem type is ext2 or ext3, then you should be able to use resize2fs to resize it. Other Linux filesystem types have their own commands for doing this. You need to unmount (umount) the filesystem before you do the resizing.
Thanks for your help.  resize2fs was my answer.

Very basic problem Hi  Stripping this down to  its basics.  I have signed up for EC2.  How do I log into it so that I can use it?  I don't have the administrator password to login from a windows computer.    Thanks  Trevor

Hi - actually EC2 is just the service name. You first need to let people know if you've started up a Windows or Linux machine image as the steps are OS dependent.From the way you asked the question, I'm guessing you're running a local Windows machine and want to get into your EC2 instance (either command line or desktop)Typical instructions for a Windows instance including getting the "Administrator" account password and logging in using remote desktop :http://www.michaelckennedy.net/blog/2010/01/31/BuildingWindowsMachinesInAmazonEC2.aspxFor a linux instance, you're not going to see any desktop in the images I've seen - command line access it de-rigeur, and 'm not aware of anything running X windows in a useful way.http://cloudcarpenters.com/blog/ec2_putty/ is one place to look, then run the Elasticfox firefox browser extension : http://developer.amazonwebservices.com/connect/entry.jspa?externalID=609Once Elasticfox is setup and you can see your running Ec2 machine, click Tools. On windows, SSH command should point to a program you'll download called "PuTTY" (ignore the schonky looing website, it does what it says on the tin) : http://www.chiark.greenend.org.uk/~sgtatham/putty/download.htmlWhen that's installed, first change the SSH Command line - in my case, that's C:\Applications\PuTTY\putty.exeYou then need the SSH Key / EC2 key pairs which will encrypt login between your PC and the remote instance (there's no need to login as "root" as the key pair negotiation takes care of that)This is where it gets a little fiddly - take a look at the cloudcarpenters blog above, and this video :http://developer.amazonwebservices.com/connect/entry.jspa?externalID=583&categoryID=100The first few times I did this it took a whlie to click so don't be put off and do a little more research if you get stuck.HTHCheers - Neil

HI  Thanks for replying.  Could you possibly give me a link for the tutorial?  (Information overload at the moment).  The problem is though, it is asking me to manually enter the key.  Trevor
Update:  You can open the file with any text editor.  I did and copied the key into the box for it to decrypt the password.  But when I click on the "decrypt password" nothing happens...  Trevor

Try this:   Log in to the AWS Management Console and click Instances. In the My Instances list, find your instance and make sure it is started. In the My Instances list, click your instance and examine the detailed information that appears below. Note or copy the name given for Public DNS. Right-click your instance and click Get Windows Password. In Notepad or a simple text editor, open the key pair file (.pem) that you specified when you created the instance. Select and copy the entire text of the file, then paste it into the Private Key input box. Click Decrypt Password and save or note the password in a secure place. Right-click your instance and click Get System Log. This page shows the status of your instance. You should not continue with the remaining steps until about 5 minutes after the message "Windows is ready to use" appears in this log.  Note the following about using the system log to look for "Windows is ready to use":      You may have to repeatedly open the log to check for this message.      The time it takes for this "ready" message to appear can vary based on the responsiveness of Amazon EC2. Factors affecting response time may include the time of day, your location, and the health of the Amazon EC2 zone and region you are using. Expect to wait at least 10 minutes.     If the message does not appear after a long period of time (for example, 30 minutes), Amazon is experiencing a problem starting the instance. Consider terminating the instance and launching a new one.  About 5 minutes after "Windows is ready to use" appears in the system log, open All Programs > Accessories > Remote Desktop Connection. In the Computer text box, enter the public DNS name that you copied or wrote down previously and click Connect. Choose to connect using the Administrator account. Type the administrator password you retrieved earlier in these steps.  from here: http://help.arcgis.com/en/arcgisserver/10.0/help/arcgis_server_on_amazon_ec2/index.html#//00rq0000000m000000.htm

Historical data on EC2 availability? Is there any historical data available on the nature of EC2's availability? Most of what's out there is anecdotal. I'd be interested in anything available (either from Amazon or collected by third parties), but some example high-level questions:  - What are the nature of EC2 instance failures, and how often do they occur? How independent or correlated are failures (e.g. mostly rack-level)? Does EC2 intentionally cluster together machines run by the same user or which communicate among each other onto the same rack? Are the failures mostly due to power failures, or Amazon maintenance, or something else?  - What kind of network partitions have occurred, and how frequently do they happen? Of the non-trivial network partitions (which include single node partitions), what shape do they take (including Internet reachability) and how long do they take to repair?  - How frequently do availability zone failures/outages occur?  - What about EC2 API availability? And how often are they inconsistent with the state of the actual instances?  I realize that I might not get answers to many of these questions, but anything would be super-useful in helping us plan and prioritize in developing a reliable application on EC2. Thanks.
+1. Pretty sure we are not going to get this from AWS, but would be wonderful if they provide at least some info.

Unfortunately the only historical data goes back about a month on the dashboard  http://status.aws.amazon.com/  I've been running a service on EC2 for over a year with a handful of instances, and only experienced once instance death in that time due to hardware failure in the underlying host. There have been two or three notable outages, power/network related, that have lasted on the order of a few hours and impacted single availability zones (my instances happened not to be affected by any of these outages).   There have also been two or three API outages of several hours that, while not interfering directly with the operation of existing resources, impact things like the ability to create EBS snapshots etc.  It is possible to dig up forum threads about these specific instances but not easy. I guess the summary answer is that I've never seen the entire service go down, but there are a few times a year that something affects a percentage of EC2 instances over a period of a couple hours. If you are able to distribute your service among zones and are quick at responding, you can probably minimize your exposure to these incidents.

From On-Demand to Reserved Hello, i know there are other threads like that but they don't fully answer my question.  I have an EBS AMI used as On-Demand. I've set up it with some stuff (lamp, mail server and so on).  I want to "convert" this into a Reserved instance, keeping at last all software and configurations as is.  1) Is this possible? or 2) I've to reserve a new (and do the work from scratch) EBS AMI?

As far as i know, reservation is a billing concept.  you buy a reservation for a particular availability zone/instance type. once the payment is processed any instance that matched that criteria (up to the number of reserves purchased) will be billed at the reservation price.

So, to be precise and correct me if I misunderstood, I reserve a certain type of instance  - ex. small - in a certain availability zone - ex. us-east-1a; if I have a running instance small in us-east-1a, this one will start to be paid with the price paid for reserved instances, no strange conversions needed.  If I start a second instance in the same az and of same size, it will be paid as usual (On-Demand).  I think this stuff can help someone:  http://aws.typepad.com/aws/2009/04/how-to-purchase-an-ec2-reserved-instance.html  Message was edited by: epistemetec

Thanks for sharing the link.  I didn't know it was that easy to "convert" an existing on-demand instance into a reserved instance.  I assumed that I would have to buy the reserved instance then launch an instance in some magical "reserved" fashion.  Nice to know there's none of that nonsense.  Now, I'm wondering just how much money I can save.

Strange Billing Discrepancy? We have an unusual discrepancy for EBS Storage Costs. Our invoice for last month says 75.871 GB-Mo for EBS storage costs in EU West but when we download the usage report and add up the 30 individual entries they only add up to 54.740 GB-Mo (if you use 1024 bytes to a kilobyte, etc., 58.776 if you use 1000).  All the other line items add up *exactly*. What's missing? (See screen caps in attached files.)

Hi, traffckr,I attempted to review your usage reports, but it appears the AWS account associated with your forum nickname is not the same account that uses EBS volumes in your attached screen captures.The short answer is that the missing part is the metering model used to calculate EBS storage charges.The entries on your usage report are listed in byte-hours, and that total needs to be converted to GB-Mo to match what appears on your Account Activity page:58776309534860 byte-hours / 1024^3 bytes/GB = 54739.7039 GB-hours54739.7039 GB-hours / 24 hours/day / 30 days/September = 76.027 GB-Mo.Unfortunately, without the AWS Account ID or the e-mail address associated with the account with this usage, I'm not able to investigate why this doesn't exactly match the amount on your billing statement: 75.871 GB-Mo.The discrepancy may be related to a rounding difference, but I'd like to look into this further. If you can send me a PM with the account ID for this account, I'll figure out what caused the difference.Also, let me know if you have additional questions.Best regards,Matthew P.

Matthew  Thank-you for your explanation, it accounts exactly for the discrepancy. I don't have the spreadsheet I took the screencap from earlier any more but when I add the values up manually they also come to exactly the right number too.  M.

Malcolm,  I am not an Amazon employee nor do I stand anything to gain by sticking up for them. However as a system administrator with many years of experience on many platforms including ephemeral EC2 instances I can say with quite a degree of confidence that your blaming Amazon for this issue is unfair. I suspect they have provided everything they have promised on their end, but your expectation is unreasonable.  EC2 gives you instances owned and managed at the root level by YOU. Amazon doesn't have some magic back door to login to your box and recover your data when you goof up your system. Ephemeral instances are just that: the data GOES AWAY, it is non permanent. The "necessary tools" you mention are contrary to the philosophy of the product. The tools exist, but they are tooled for a different part of the product. If you want to save data or configurations they offer non-ephemeral storage options. These storage options have alternate access methods. EBS can be snapshoted and attached to other instances. S3 storage can be read from anywhere. It is not Amazon's fault if you are not applying the technology properly.  Lastly, about your issue. Is SSH really down on your box or do you not have the firewall open so you can reach the port? Does the machine console output tell you anything about the state of the box? Did YOU enable any other services that might make it reachable ... a network file system or web control panel perhaps? Database port that you can do a dump from? These are things you are responsible for setting up, not Amazon. Maybe these suggestions will help you remember something else you have running.  Caleb

Yes Caleb, SSH was down, and it was my fault.What I asked was to confirm me that there was a tool to access my XEN virtual machine... and I was going to pay for that service. I just needed a confirmation from Amazon which never occured.

Who owns the instances launched from my account Pardon for the totally newbie question.   When I launch an AMI instance from my account, do I own that copy of the AMI? Can I then go ahead and setup users, change root passwords, install software? Does that instance become mine?  TIA

Yes, any instances that you launch become yours. They might be launched from a common shared AMI, but once it's running a copy is created unique to your account.  If it is an ephemoral instance, when you shut it down any changes will be lost. If it is an EBS backed instance, your changes will still be saved on a disk (that you are paying for the storage space to maintain).  Caleb
Caleb, Thank you very much for taking time to answer my question.

Just a clarification:  The original AMI remains owned by its original owner. Your running instances get a copy of the AMI's contents as their root filesystem, so if the AMI owner deletes the AMI after you launch an instance from it, that instance is not affected. However you will not be able to launch any more instances of a deleted AMI.  If you want to ensure you'll always be able to launch an AMI when you need to, you should burn your own copy of the AMI you use.
Shlomo Thanks for the clarification.   Can I launch an instance of AMI, install my software, setup users etc and then create an AMI out of it so I own that AMI?  TIA

Yes, absolutly! That is what "bundling" is about. Amazon has scripts for this that either you should install or will already be on most pre-prepared AMI's.  For Ephemoral backed instances, the scripts are something you run inside your running instance. They scan through the system collecting all the parts of the base system in whatever state you have modified them to, then package it all up together, upload it to your AWS account and allow you to make that into a new AMI, personalized for and only available to you.  For EBS backed instances this is even simpler. All you need to do is use the tools from inside or outside the instance to snapshot the instance, which basically just shuts it down, snapshots the ebs volume used as root and makes that root file system into a new ami for you, then fires your original instance back up.
Caleb Thanks again for the clear response.

What is us-east-1b for you may be us-east-1a for me.  Amazon states the following:

@barossa001,  Your request for desktop images is a popular one.  It will be added to the list.  The reason we do not make desktop images available as released is that currently we only support "Ubuntu Server" on EC2.  The server product does not include (by default) a gui of any sort.  However, nothing prevents you from adding one as you've done.

@Moser - I don't know if it's in your place, but I think Canonical should take issue with the fact that Amazon has released their own Linux AMIs instead of using Ubuntu.  Ubuntu is the obvious choice for Amazon to use for these AMIs.  Nobody's going to seriously use a custom Amazon AMI that can't be used anywhere else and has no community.  As for things that could be addressed at the AMI level, I'd like to see a push for more server-optimized variables like a higher number of file descriptors and higher maximum socket backlog.  The AMIs should be tweaked for the typical workloads of ec2 instances (web servers, memcached servers, nosql servers).  I don't know if it's smart to split up into many types of AMI - too much variability, but perhaps some changes could be agreed to by all server user types.

Amazon's Linux AMIs are based on CentOS/RedHat, which is what I and many other server admins are familiar with.  Obviously picking one distro to be the "official" amazon distro is going to make some group of users unhappy.  Personally, I'm thrilled they picked CentOS.  You aren't.  Such is life.

@stagingyipitThank you for your input.   I will add it to discussion points.  Regarding "server-optimized variables like a higher number of file descriptors and higher maximum socket backlog", Ubuntu Server on EC2 is basically just "Ubuntu Server" running on EC2.  Settings like you suggest are possibly useful, and if deemed so, would be applied to the Ubuntu Server product.Regarding Amazon's AMI's.  Amazon is obviously allowed to use whatever they would like for creating their own AMIs.  I believe that there are, and always will be, plenty of reasons to choose Ubuntu, both on EC2 and other platforms.

Clarifications needed on File Transfer Dear All,We have the following questions with Amazon EC2,1) Is it possible to transfer file between my physical server and the EC2 instances. If yes, what are the possible ways to do it ?2) I read in your site somewhere that if the EC2 instances run FTP/SFTP server, we can use that to transfer file. But I heard that only 5 (by default) instances of my account only will have internet facing IP Address, others won't have, In this case how can I use FTP to my instances for which IP Address in not known.3) Is there any other solution for file transfer between my physical server and my EC2 instances ? Is there any API provided by Amazon for file transfer ? where can I find it?4) Will there by any cost for file transfer, if yes, how much it would be ?5) Where can I find information(tech details, not financial) related to file transfer with Amazon EC2 ?Thanks & RegardsBharatha Selvan.

You can request more elastic IPs if you need them, but all instances will have public IPs.  Elastic IPs just make those IPs reserved so that you can re-use them with different instances.  There are several ways to copy files onto your instance.  For Linux instances, I use scp, and for Windows instances, I copy files through remote desktop.  You could also copy files onto S3 from your workstation and then from within your instance, download those files from S3.  The only charge for copying files around is bandwidth.

That is to say I never get the "1.7Ghz" CPU,but they promised.It's let me been cheated。

They never promised a physical 1.7GHz core. The promised one virtual core with certain general performance characteristics  http://aws.amazon.com/ec2/instance-types/  Amazon EC2 uses a variety of measures to provide each instance with a consistent and predictable amount of CPU capacity. In order to make it easy for developers to compare CPU capacity between different instance types, we have defined an Amazon EC2 Compute Unit. The amount of CPU that is allocated to a particular instance is expressed in terms of these EC2 Compute Units. We use several benchmarks and tests to manage the consistency and predictability of the performance of an EC2 Compute Unit. One EC2 Compute Unit provides the equivalent CPU capacity of a 1.0-1.2 GHz 2007 Opteron or 2007 Xeon processor. This is also the equivalent to an early-2006 1.7 GHz Xeon processor referenced in our original documentation. Over time, we may add or substitute measures that go into the definition of an EC2 Compute Unit, if we find metrics that will give you a clearer picture of compute capacity.

How are partial hours charged with reserved instances? Hi,  I know partial hours are billed as full hours, but how does that work with reserved instances.  E.g.: 00:00: (only) instance started 00:05: instance stopped 00:10: instance started 00:15: instance stopped.  Without having a reserved instance, I'd be charged for 2 normal instance-hours.  With a reserved instance, will I be charged:  - 1 instance-hour at a reduced price and 1 at normal price, or   - 2 instance-hours at a reduced price ?  Thanks!
The same thing as for an on-demand instance.  The only difference between a reserved instance and an on-demand instance is the hourly rate. The events that trigger the billing are the same.
So what does that mean, the former or the latter?
You'll be charged for 2 hours at the reduced price.

Unable to Kill Processes In this post:   http://developer.amazonwebservices.com/connect/thread.jspa?messageID=128427&#128427  Eric Hammond mentions a possible cause for this issue being a hung file system. I believe this is what we're experiencing. We use XFS on an EBS volume for a web server running apache. About once a month all processes on the server will hang and refuse to be killed. Our only option is to replace the instance because a reboot is impossible.   We run a snapshot once per hour using Eric Hammond's ec2-consistent-snapshot script that utilizes xfs_freeze. We are using the 2.6.18-xenU-ec2-v1.0 (aki-9b00e5f2) kernel running Debian Etch.   This has become an extremely painful problem because Apache becomes completely non-responsive (along with all other running processes) so the sites on the box are down. We are able to SSH into the instance and all other operations appear to be running smoothly. It is also impossible to detach the EBS volume when this occurs.  I am afraid to upgrade the kernel because of the reports of XFS issues with the 2.6.21 kernels, but I'm wondering if I should upgrade to the 2.6.18-xenU-ec2-v1.2 (aki-f5c1219c) kernel???  This is my first post, but I'm a long time reader and I've been using EC2 for almost 2 years very successfully. Any help is appreciated because this is becoming a serious issue for our business. We run a lot of servers and all are having these problems.

vstross:  My current recommendation for this is to add an unfreeze command like the following immediately after running ec2-consistent-snapshot in your cron job:  ec2-consistent-snapshot ...; xfs-freeze -u /mountpoint  I believe somebody may have submitted a patch to fix a situation where the  file system is not always freed up.  Look  for an update but try the above workaround in the meantime.

Hi Eric,  Thanks for the recommendation. I've updated our snapshot script to include this command after your script. I've marked this question as "answered" for now. Unfortunately I won't really know unless it never locks-up again.   Do you know of any way to tell if an XFS file system is currently frozen?   Vince

Vince:  Do you know of any way to tell if an XFS file system is currently frozen?   Sure, "xfs_freeze -u" gives an error if it's not   Speaking of which, I suppress the output in my cron jobs so I don't get emailed every hour with an error message that actually indicates success.  I also spelled the command with a dash instead of the correct underscore.  Here's a copy/paste from a cron job:  sudo ec2-consistent-snapshot --aws-credentials-file $HOME/.aws-credentials-snapshotter --mysql --xfs-filesystem $MOUNTPOINT $EBSVOLUME | logger -s -t $EBSVOLUME; sudo xfs_freeze -u $MOUNTPOINT 2>/dev/null  -- Eric Hammond

Sure, "xfs_freeze -u" gives an error if it's not   Maybe I have bigger problems then, because when I execute "xfs_freeze -u /ebs1" I don't get any error messages. I've tried running this command 10 times in a row with no result, even after a reboot!   I'll do some searching on this and see if it points to anything. Do you know if there's anything wrong with running XFS as the filesystem on an EBS volume with Debian Etch?  I appreciate your feedback, and I have a feeling that the "xfs_freeze -u" is going to do the trick... fingers-crossed.   Vince

Vince:  My xfs_freeze -u error comes from tests with xfsprogs 3.1.0ubuntu1 on Ubuntu 10.04 Lucid.  Your mileage may vary with older versions on Debian.  It's still safe to unfreeze an unfrozen file system and it hopefully will clear up your issues.  In my experience XFS is fine as a root file system, though I haven't done it on EC2 yet.  I'm a little hesitant to freeze the root file system when taking a snapshot because I have concerns that my snapshot cron job will try to log something to /var/log/syslog in the event of an error and hang everything.  I still take snapshots of the root EBS file system, but it is just to help improve the reliability of the EBS volume and I don't use XFS or freezing.  -- Eric Hammond

Hi, Eric.  We use instance storage for our system root. Then we have all of our Apache virtual hosts setup on the EBS volume, with a Multi-AZ RDS instance for databases. I've thought about switching to the new bootable EBS model, but we are still using the same instances we setup from before running a root partition on an EBS volume was available. I have been assuming that this would be a hassle to switch to without reconfiguring our Debian installs. Do you have any experience with this? Are there any benefits other than persistence?   FYI: So far so good, no lock-ups... Thank you again for the reply!!
A new version of ec2-consistent-snapshot has been released with a fix for the sporadic unfreeze bug:  http://alestic.com/2010/10/ec2-consistent-snapshot-035  -- Eric Hammond

What is a remap and how to calculate the costs hi everyone,i got the first report for my account activity. the costs for remapping the elastic ip are quite expensive in relation to the cpu hours.- my instance is running from 8 to 21 from monday to friday and from 8 to 9 on saturday and sunday.- the start script at 8 associates an elastic ip.could anyone please explain me how to calculate the total amount of remaps that are charged? i hope my explanation is sufficient if not pls ask.thank you

If you're starting it up and giving it an Elastic IP once a day, then you'd do 30 remaps a month.  Your first 100 are free each month, so there would be no charge.However, the hours you don't have an IP associated with an instance are $0.01 per hour, so that would be $0.11 per day Mon-Fri and $0.23 a day on the weekends.-- Don

Hi J,The first thing I would recommend is that you verify that you can create an AMI from the same instance using the CreateImage call (this is available via ec2-create-image).  If an AMI created via that method similarly fails, there may be a configuration issue with your instance that for some reason is not reflected in the original instance.You should also consider specifying a suitable kernel and ramdisk image when you call ec2-register.  I believe that if you do not specify one, the default kernel (which I believe is an older 2.6.16 kernel) will be used, which may not be appropriate for the version of Linux that you are using.Hope this helps!-Jason
Using CreateImage worked fine.  Thanks for the tip!

Security Group restricting access I have a Security Group setting that allows all port 22 requests access to my EC2 instance (SSH 22 0.0.0.0/0). I can connect to this instance from my work IP, but when access is attempted by another IP the connection stalls until it times out. The instance does not appear to have a firewall running on it.  How can I find out where the traffic is being stopped at? What is the best way to reset the rules in the Security Group?

Hello,Are you using ssh command?If you try "-v" option, it might give you more detailed output where your authentication process is stucked.Also, diagnostic purpose, you can try adding some specific rule to allow your access from another desktop like a"SSH 22 xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx/32".

I did try allowing specific IPs, but that did not help.  What ended up helping was to delete all of the rules pertaining to ssh, and add a custom rule.   I selected the custom option, chose tcp, selected my port range of 22-22, and chose the IP range 0.0.0.0/0. Doing this opened my port 22 to everything and allowed for normal work flow.  So it looks like there was an issue with the Security Group. Somewhere down the line it looks like the rules became stuck and were not properly updated when changed. I did not mess with any other ports, or predefined settings, but it looks like the predefined setting for SSH should be looked into to see why this would occur.

EBS Volume without corresponding snapshot? Somehow I have ended up with two EBS volumes which don't have corresponding snapshots.% ec2dvol vol-75a3cd1eVOLUME  vol-75a3cd1e    10      snap-b1cb34da   us-west-1b      available       2010-10-02T00:01:12+0000%ec2dsnap snap-b1cb34daClient.InvalidSnapshot.NotFound: The snapshot 'snap-b1cb34da' does not exist.I tried to create an instance and attach the snapshot to it using the block device mapping, but unsurprisingly, this did not work.  Am I screwed?  Is the data lost forever?  How does this happen?

Once a volume is created from a snapshot the snapshot can be deleted. This is likely what happened here.  It's not a problem at all. Simply make a new snapshot of these volumes.  Note that a snapshot is (as its name implies) an image of a volume taken at a specific point in time. You can (and should) take regular snapshots of your EBS volume to have multiple points in time to which you can restore.

Hi,Your instances seem to be Windows instance. Please check the Windows Firewall rules for ICMP protocol.So if you do not turn on the Server role of File and Printer Sharing, you need to add your own icmp rule or to enable "File and Printer Sharing (Echo Request - ICMPv4-In)" of the default Windows Firewall rules.I hope this helps you
Thanks for your reply. is that firewall setting on the windows box the reason why I cannot access one instance from another?

That may be one of the reason why the ping is not responding between your instances each other. Even if you open ICMP port in security group of EC2, eventually the fire wall of  the instance will drop the ping packet when it is not matched with the accept rule.

Windows Domain Server Stopped Working, Help So here is the issue.We have a Windows instance (ami-df4daab6) that has been a domain controller for sometime.  We basically only use it for password management.  In early July 2010 I successfully added a couple of new client computers to the domain.  At the end of August we moved offices, we made the appropriate updated to our security groups to reflect our new ip from our office.  Last week I needed to add another new computer to the domain, and have not been able to do so.  When trying to join the client to the domain, I get the 'The network path was not valid' error message and in the NetSetup log we are getting the following error:NetUseAdd to \\myDomain\IPC$ returned 53We have not made any changes to the DC.  It is setup as a DNS server and AD. and was running fine.  Looking at our existing clients, they are not reaching the domain either.  The event log also says that the network address is invalid.  This started on July 16.We have tried all sorts of things.  Opening ports.  Change network settings on both the client and the server.  DCDiag on the server does return a couple of error, The DNS Basic test fails because the network adapter has a dynamic ip and RReg fails because domain does not have an A record at the server ip.  I don't really know if these are the issue and if so how to fix.Any guidance would be appreciated.ThanksJake

Hi Jake, Often times, the Domain Controller changes its public IP address and/or name due to an instance reboot.I suggest validating that the computer name as defined in Windows hasn't changed from the installation and (more importantly) that it matches with the SRV record in your DNS and is configured to the current public IP address of the Instance.Let me know how it goes,Jonathan@CloudStacking.com

Jonathan, Thanks for the feedback, unfortunately everything seems to be correct in the dns but I do have more information. 1) When attempting to join the client computer to the domain, I do get the prompt for my domain admin account which has rights to join computers.  Only after a lengthly delay does the network path error returned. 2) All of the IP addresses are the same as they have been on the DC 3) In the past(successful join to the domain) I have always needed to add an entry in the client computer host file pointing to the elastic IP of the DC instance and the DC FQCN 4) When running the DCDiag DNS test I get a warning for my network adapter having a dynamic IP address and an error with RReg test.  The error states that I am "Missing A record at DNS server  'internal ip' :  'computerName'  for the network adapter itself. All clients point to the elastic IP address. Thoughts and thanks? Jake

Try joining a member server that is within EC2.Make sure that all of the ports between this instance and your DC are open in both ways for TCP and UDP.In addition, make sure that the DC has an SRV record in your DNS:Go into your DNS properties and expand Forward Lookup ZonesRight click   _tcpChoose > Add other recordType = SRVService = ldapport = 389host offering this service = your domain controller IP address.Good luck,Jonathan@CloudStacking.com

AWS Compute Clusters The Cluster Compute instance family currently contains a single instance type, the Cluster Compute Quadruple Extra Large .... When run as a cluster of instances, they provide low latency, full bisection 10 Gbps bandwidth between instances.  QUESTIONS:  1. Are there other instance types planned to be made available in compute cluster?   2. Is the 10GBPS bisection bandwidth guaranteed for the cluster, no matter how many machines one has in use? e.g., 100 machines.  3. For a cluster with m1.xlarge, is there any bisection bandwidth guarantee? e.g. guarantee of 1GBPS bisection bandwidth?  Thanks.

re: 10Gbps bisection bandwidthCorrect - all instances within a Placement Group experience "full bisection bandwidth" (a.k.a. Constant Bisectional Bandwidth, CBB) regardless of the number of instances in the Group.  If the instance limits on your account permit you to start 200 CC1.4XLarge instances, you will get CBB between all of them.For customers familiar with supercomputer architectures, we suggest they think about Placement Groups the same way as super-cluster "Connected Units" or "Scalable Units" and build Groups of comparable size  (e.g., 180 like LANL RoadRunner, 144-162 like LLNL Coastal/Sierra), and then use multiple Placement Groups for high scale-out.With CBB connectivity, instances can communicate in any pattern within the Placement Group and will not be impacted by each other or other customers during transit between instances. Communication outside of the Placement Group (e.g., EBS, S3, Internet) is not guaranteed to have this property and may be limited in other ways.re: m1.xlarge, other instance typesWe do not currently offer Placement Group assurances with other instance families, but are always looking for feedback on important use cases were it is required.

EBS backed instances pricing Hello,if I start an EBS backed instance the EBS volume shows up under volumes.Now if the instance is $0,025 for a micro instance will I have to pay for the EBSin addition?Does that mean I will always pay the instance + EBS instance volume then?Also does it mean S3 backed instances are cheaper then since don't have to pay for the EBS volume?thanks for clarifying this,kind regardsb.

Yes, you pay for EBS storage + EBS i/o + instance hourly.s3-backed instances are indeed cheaper, but obviously if you have important data on them, you can lose it if the instance terminates.so, consider the tradeoffs... price vs durability.
thank you for clarifying this!b.

Can I forward port 80 to 8080 using security groups I am running a single instance with only tomcat and want to hide the ":8080" portion of our url's for the end user.  I tried adding a rule to the default security group as follows: HTTP tcp 80 8080 0.0.0.0/0  However this did not seem to have any effect. Can't do this with security groups, but you can with iptables. Do a google search for "iptables port forward" or similar.  Also you can get tomcat to bind directly to port 80 without running as root by using authbind.

Create an ami from an "instance-store" instance There has got to be a better way. I've spent my morning trying to figure out how to create an ami from a running instance I created from an ami started from the instance-store. I've hunted on the internet and through the forums.#1 some of the similar requests like mine have been ignored#2 from the few solutions I found on the net you have to be a frackin Unix guru to make them work.There has to be an easy solution to this. If there's not then AWS needs to fix this. I want to save my instance so that I can restart it later. I have no need to keep it running 24-7. Thanks,Don

There is no 'one click' way to do it.  That said, it only takes two unix shell commands to do it.  See http://alestic.com/2009/06/ec2-ami-bundle for details.Here's the commands, roughly:ec2-bundle-vol -r i386 -d /mnt/bundle -p $MANIFESTNAME -u $ACCOUNTNUMBER -k pk.pem -c cert.pem -s 10240 -e /mnt,/root/.sshec2-upload-bundle--access-key=$S3_ACCESS_KEY --secret-key=$S3_SECRET --bucket=$S3_BUCKET_NAME --manifest=$MANIFESTNow you have to register the manifest.  If it's in mybucket/mynewami.manifest.xml, just go to the aws console and register that path.If you want to make it much simple on yourself, use an EBS-backed instance instead of instance-store.

Booting has failed. I took a perfectly good instance running in East-1c and created an AMI. The new AMI was launched in East-1b as instance i-837063e9The services do not appear to be running and I cannot connect.  The following snip was taken from the console output.WARNING: can't access (null)exec of init ((null)) failed!!!: Bad addressBooting has failed.Your suggestions are welcome.

Hi Michael,It sounds like the problem here may be related to the AMI creation process or the configuration of your new instance.  Based on the rest of your console output, your instance may be unable to find the /dev directory, which could cause it to fail to boot.Since this instance is EBS-backed, you have some options as far as debugging this issue:- If your original instance is still running, you should review your configuration there to ensure that the instance configuration is correct (one thing to help diagnose where the issue is occurring is to reboot the original instance, but if that is also improperly configured, you could render the instance unbootable).You may want to review the contents of your /etc/fstab file to make sure your filesystem mappings are correct.  You also may want to make sure that you are using an appropriate kernel and ramdisk for your instance.- You can also detach the root volume (vol-deb98bb7) from your failed instance ( i-837063e9) and review it for possible issues.Your diagnostics for i-837063e9 do show that you have several EBS volumes mounted, between sdb and sdd.  Those mount points are reserved for local storage, and attaching EBS volumes to devices outside the range /dev/sd[f-p][1-6] can have unpredictable results.  I suggest you try detaching those volumes, reboot to ensure that your instance comes up properly, then reattach the volumes to supported device ids.Regards,-Jason

Some of our visitors report "Server not found" with Elastic Load Balancing We've been using the elastic load balancers for quite a while now and since the first day we keep getting sporadic messages of our users that they get a "server not found" error when trying to get to our website. With one user we were able to do a little test and asked him to type in the current IP address of the load balancer instance instead of the domain name. Interestingly enough that worked absolutely fine! The big question here is what is the problem? We have a very reliable and big DNS hoster using 3 DNS servers which are always up. We've added the CNAME for the load balancer to our www. sub-domain and that works for most of our users and ourselves without any problems. Strangely enough our DNS hoster tells us regarding cnames: "If you use cnames people using BIND9 may get problems resolving your domain name". Is that a general problem and does it have anything to do with our problem?So what can we do to avoid people hitting a "Server not found" error. Is it something to do with our DNS hoster or is there a problem with the elastic load balancers? In case it's the DNS what can we do to avoid this? Is there something we might have done wrong?Thanks a lot in advance

It's possible that some DNS servers along the way to your clients do not like the long DNS packets that result from having a long CNAME entry.  You can try changing the name of your ELB to a single letter, which will generate a new DNS name that is likely shorter than what you currently use. This will require a DNS change, but the effect should be transparent as long as you add the same back-end instances to both ELBs. Once the DNS change propagates you can delete the old ELB.  Check out this thread for more details:  http://developer.amazonwebservices.com/connect/thread.jspa?threadID=42508&tstart=45

Hi,thanks a lot for your message. We gonna try this now with one-letter load balancer names and try to get another test done by one of our troubled customers. I'll let you know as soon as I know more.Cheers
Thanks a lot! This actually solved the problem for our customer.Cheers

Yes, I have encountered this issue too.  it's because the modal popup used to display the wizard is sized too big and the continue/next buttons are not visible.  The easy way to work around this problem is this:  Reduce the font-size of the browser window by doing clicking control -  (that ctrl key followed by minus key).  The font size of your browser window should reduce.  Then start up the wizard and you should be able to see the next/continue buttons.  - Bill

Windows Instance Wont Start Hi,  I've searched the forums and found people with similar problems but no solutions, so well I'm trying again with a detailed post on exactly what happened.  I have created a new instance from our windows 2008 64bit AMI as a replacement for one of our current instances (large instance). I took a snapshot of the current drives on the running instance and then swapped these drives into the new instance (the AMI contains default drives). I finished off configuring the instance and restarted to make sure everything worked. I then shut-down the instance overnight to save costs with the intention of switching the instances the next day. When I started up the instance the next day one of the drives did not appear in my computer, going into computer management I found it had some how become deactivated, so I reactivated the disk and carried on. I decided to do a final shut-down and start to make sure the machine would work as expected. Now starting up the machine never seems to complete, I get no system log output from the API. I left the machine for over 2 hours and still no system log (tried RDP and no luck either). So I shut-down the instance, put the original disks of the instance back and still no luck. Finally I tried removing both the additional disks and starting it up, again nothing. Finally started up a new instance and transferred the disks into there, they work perfectly and the instance starts up and shuts down without problems. I've run check disk on the drives and found no errors. Everything seems fine with them.  All the instances in this case use the following structure for the disks, all disks are EBS. 	C: System (windows, also has IIS7 and its configuration) (basic disk) 	D: Data (used to store the software and configuration) (dynamic disk with a single simple volume) 	E: Temp (used for transferring in various files, new releases etc.) (dynamic disk with a single simple volume)  Configuration of our AMI/Instance includes: IIS7 IIS6 (for SMTP) Filezilla (we are migrating away from FTP however some specific cases still require it) iBackup .Net 4.0 (running asp.net websites) Nod32 Antivirus with recommend server configuration Notepad++  Only other thing I should add is during set-up of the new server I attached and detached a few drives to copy over various files etc. I've been assuming this is a disk related issue and not an application related issue as I never get any system log output, is there anything other than the disks which could be causing this problem?  I've spent a number of hours trying to research this and come up blank. Does anyone know what went wrong with the server, and is there anything I can enable which would give me more information in the system log if the error occurred again?

Ok, after recreating the instance and restarting after almost every little change I have tracked down a possible cause, only after we added the SSL certificates to IIS7 did the server stop starting up correctly. This post at stack overflow suggests the issue is real - http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2373997/aws-ec2-instance-is-gone-after-reboot-when-ssl-certificate-is-bound-to-website but I cant find a solution.  Anyone got any suggestions as to why this occurs?

If nothing else, your post has helped me identify what's been going wrong with my AMI situation.  I'm experiencing the exact same issue, where once I import a domain cert, and bind it to a website the system will no longer boot correctly.  I've been going crazy trying to figure out what the issue is as EC2 just shows the instance as running with no console output and no indication as to what the issue is.  But this leaves me in a bit of a pickle... what do we do now?  Is this a new issue with AWS?  I can't imagine that no one has been using SSL on a windows server...

We finally solved the issue. This took quite a while but it was how we were importing the certificates from another server which was the issue. To get around this simply reissue the certificate(s) for the new machine and it should reboot fine (tested about 5-6 reboots with certificates bound).

Reserved instances are a billing feature.  If you launch a regular instance that matches the criteria of the reserved instance (OS type, instance type, availability zone), then the reduced rate will be automatically applied.
it stills say on demand.. there is no Reserved instance option

Mine appears to be working properly now.     For the first few days the 'Account Activity' page showed both my on-demand and reserved instance running side-by-side.    Now (~a week later, and a new month) only my reserved instance is showing up under 'Account Activity' while the machine I started as on-demand (which is now being treated as a reserved instance) continues to run under the EC2 control panel.  Message was edited by: Fulcanelli

Hi,Colin is correct. Reserved Instances aren't instances. Instead, they're reservations of capacity that guarantee that you'll always be able to launch an instance that matches your Reserved Instance criteria in the Availability Zone of the reservation for the term of the Reserved Instance.When you purchase Reserved Instances, the billing system checks each hour to see how many total instances you have running that match the same instance type and Availability Zone as your Reserved Instances. If it is less than the number of instances you have running in that Availability Zone, you will be charged the Reserved Instance Rate for each instance running that hour.If the number of instances running in that Availability Zone is greater than the number of ReservedInstances you have for that Availability Zone, you will be charged the On-Demand rate for the additional instances.More information is available on the Reserved Instances details page:http://aws.amazon.com/ec2/reserved-instances/Best regards,Matthew P.

Cannot Start NFS Server (rpc.mountd) on Amazon Linux AMI Hi Folks,Trying to get mountd running on a fresh Amazon Linux AMI (Beta) (ami-38c33651).  Several issues so far ...from base, i added nfs support via:yum install nfs-utils nfs-utils-lib portmap system-config-nfsall packages except system-config-nfs installed fine (it isn't in any repos)Issues I've had:1. Missing rpcinfo (not in any amazon supplied packages).  Any suggestions on what repos would be good? 2. service nfs start quietly failed.  Turned out that default /etc/sysconfig/network has NETWORKING=YES.  NFS startup script, /etc/rc.d/init.d/nfs requires lowercase "yes" -- NETWORKING=yes.3. rpc.mountd fails to start with error "unable to register (mountd, 1, udp)."  Tried via service nfs start as well as direct invocation.  Any thoughts on this one?other info ... empty /etc/hosts.allow and /etc/hosts.deny, but I don't think needed thus far (?).  Thanks for any advice.Bill
Bill,This appears to be a problem in the Amazon Linux AMI Beta image.  We are working on a fix now and will update this post as we progress.Nathan
Thx Nathan.  Appreciate quick response.  Let me know if you need further info or if I can help test.Bill
I have the same problem. Any time frame for the fix ?

We have update the repository to include rpcbind, which is a replacement for portmap.  This includes the rpcinfo command.  To install it you will need to run "sudo yum install rpcinfo".You will still need to modify the /etc/sysconfig/network file and change the following line: NETWORKING=YES toNETWORKING=yesThen you should be able to run "sudo /sbin/service rpcbind start; sudo /sbin/service/nfs start" to start the nfs server.  We will fix the /etc/sysconfig/network file bug with the next AMI push.  Please let us know if you have any other issues.
Thanks Nathan!  That did the trick.One correction --I think you meant:    yum install rpcbindinstead of:  yum install rpcinfobut other than that, worked great!  thanks for the help!

getting "special device /dev/sdh does not exist' on mount of EBS volume This is probably a question / issue for the Amazon'ians on the forum... I have a script running on an instance that attaches an EBS volume to the instance to /dev/sdb, waits one second at a time for the aws_attachment_status transtion to "attached" then mounts the device ala: mount /dev/sdh /data. If I charge right into the mount as soon as I the transtion to "attached" status, I am seeing "mount: special device /dev/sdh does not exist" failures on almost every case. If I retry the mount outside of the script after I see it fail, it works.This seems like a race condition of some sort where I would think there shouldn't be one. My assumption is once it says attached, I should be able to act on the device.Can someone help me on this? Thanks in advance...Chris

Hi Chris,It is possible that the device mapper inside your instance takes a short while to respond to the hotplugged device being attached.  So there is a small window during which the device is physically attached, but the device mapper hasn't yet created the /dev/ entry.I'd recommend adding an existance test for /dev/sdh to your polling loop so you know the device entry is also ready for mount.Andries

For what it's worth (I know this is an old thread), but had the same problem, and in our script, ended up adapting/writing a couple of bash functions to help with this.The magic one is:function do_then_wait_until() {  # $1 - do this  # $2 - then wait for this to evaluate to true  eval $1 # run command  local result=1 # run loop at least once  until [ $result -eq 0 ]  do    sleep 1    (eval $2)    result=$? # evaluate progress  done}And then you can just write functions to pass to it like these:function is_device_ready() {  # tests for the block level /dev/sdb to be ready  [ -b /dev/sdb ] && exit 0 || exit 1}function try_the_mount() {  # return true because mount may give warnings  mount -a || true }So you just call:do_then_wait_until "try_the_mount" "is_device_ready"and it will attempt the command until the case is met.  We use this in several places to wait for EC2 commands to come back with successful results.Hope this helps someone along....
You might want to take a look at EBSmount, which automatically mounts Amazon EC2 EBS devices when they are attached (via udev).  http://www.turnkeylinux.org/blog/ebsmount

Elastic Load Balancer terminates first created instances Hi all,  my ELB setup controls 2 webserver instances, web01 and web02.  When he needs to create another one, web03, does it fine, but when the load diminishes, it destroys the first created instance, web01 (instead last one, web03).  Is this the normal behaviour? Is there any form of prevent it?  Thanks in advance, Simon.
No one?

AutoScaling creates and destroys instances based on the trigger you set. It can be integrated into the ELB load balancer.  Which instance is chosen for termination is not subject to control: it is random. There's no way to change this.  Why do you care which instance is terminated? In order for your application to scale properly it needs to be completely unaware what machine it is running on.

Elastic IP vs. dynamic DNS: which propagates faster? In availability planning for our web app, I'm wondering which propagates faster - dynamic DNS (meaning a TTL of 20-60) or Elastic IP?  I thought for some time that Elastic IP would be faster, but then discovered that it can take minutes to propagate (with some forum postings claiming 10m!).  Just wondering what others are seeing, and whether it even makes sense to pay for Elastic IPs, if dynamic DNS is as fast or faster. Thanks.

Elastic IP changes tend to happen in under a minute.  DNS changes (Dynamic or "regular") propagate in an unpredictable timeframe (somewhere under 24 hours usually). TTL values are reliable only when the DNS lookup happens directly on the authoritative nameserver (the one hosting the domain's DNS entries) . DNS lookups that happen on non-authoritative nameservers are cached by those nameservers, and not all nameservers respect the TTL of the authoritative nameserver. So the propagation time is artificially increased, depending on the caching behavior of intervening nameservers between the client and the authoritative nameserver.  Also, some browsers and client-side programs (Java being a notable example) cache DNS lookups for longer than necessary (forever, in the default Java configuration).  I recommend the use of Elastic IPs for public-facing services. For internal services you can use Dynamic DNS, since you have tight control over the DNS lookup path in your own applications and you can ensure the authoritative nameservers are always used, guaranteeing you the TTL in the DNS entry.

How do I configure EC2 instance to not block ELB? For business reasons, I need to block all but a few IP address to access my EC2 instances. I have had to add the IP address of my ELB to my allow list several times as it changes occasionally. It seems to me that there probably is a way to configure the EC2 and ELB to talk to each other, so that I don't have to keep updating the security groups each time the ELB changes its IP. Could someone please let me know how to do this?

Unfortunately it's not currently possible to limit access based on IP address for a service that sits behind an ELB. ELB's design currently requires that all traffic on the instance-port be open to 0.0.0.0/0 in the security group.

I resolved this problem by doing the following1. Open a command prompt with Administrator permissions (right-click cmd.exe in the start menu, and choose Run as Administrator)2. Type cd \ProgramData (this changes the current folder to the ProgramData folder)3. Type rmdir "Application Data" (this removes the faulty junction point)4. Type mklink /j "Application Data" C:\ProgramData (this creates the new junction point)Based upon discussion from http://www.developpez.net/forums/d723091/php/outils/zend/impossible-dinstaller-zendserver-error-1622-a/http://forums.zend.com/viewtopic.php?f=44&t=391&p=2430#p2430
Thank you very much for this solution - you saved my sanity.

PV-Grub / custom kernel issue: error 21 selected disk does not exist I'm trying to setup some AMI's for a non standard linux distribution. I have done this many times with various kernels, but have not been able to get the new custom kernel option to work using pv-grub.  Basically, grub FINDS my menu file no problem, and iterates through the primary and fallback item. Both items, no matter what I put, throw the error "Error 21: Selected disk does not exist". I am using EBS backed AMI's, but I have tried many permutations of using:  * Raw volume as disk with filesystem  1 partition on volume with filesystem in that   * hd0 and hd00 AKI's (hd0 finds the menu file for the raw disk version, hd00 for the one partition version)  * using no root command from the grub menu,  using root(hd0) using root(hd0,0) using various rootnoverify()'s   I am using ext3 in all cases. And incorrect combination of partition layout and hd0/hd00 aki's does lead to a different error, but if I use the right one and it finds the menu file, it invariably throws the error above.  What am I missing?

Do you have a device.map in /boot/grub? Depending on the system that you are installing, especially if you copied the file system from a native install, the device.map could be point to a disk not on the system. If you have a device.map, simply remove it. Could you please post the full contents of you menu.lst?

Thanks for the help Ben.  I did have some System.map files that appear to have been generated by scripts along with my initrd. However I removed them and packaged things up and still get the same errors.  I've tried many iterations of the menu file, but here is the one I just tried followed by the console output that shows that it read the mean file already but grub is then throwing my favorite error: 21. In the past I have tried several things for the root(), the following tries it with root(hd0,0) and with nothing at all. ------------------------------- default 0 fallback 1 timeout 1  debug  title  linux-xenU root(hd0,0) kernel /boot/vmlinuz-xenU root=/dev/sda1 initrd /boot/initrd-xenU  title  linux kernel /boot/vmlinuz root=/dev/sda1 initrd /boot/initrd ------------------------------- The highlighted entry will be booted automatically in 1 seconds. Booting 'linux-xenU'  kernel /boot/vmlinuz-xenU root=/dev/sda1  Error 21: Selected disk does not exist   Booting 'linux'  kernel /boot/vmlinuz root=/dev/sda1  Error 21: Selected disk does not exist

This is embarrassing but after two days of bashing my head on this, I think I solved it myself.  My grub menu file had commands like root(hd0,0) instead of root (hd0,0). The space is essential, and all my attempts left it out! I found this out by discovering that leaving the root line off and specifying the full path like kernel (hd0,0)/boot/vmlinuz.... worked. The lack of space did not cause any kind of parsing error, but it seems to have just been ignored. As a result it really didn't matter what values I gave it, it was just going on defaults anyway, hence the same result with the line left out entirely.  I still don't have a booting system, but I'm past the problem with grub now and onto kernel woes. Hopefully anybody else who runs into the same problem will find this solution helpful!  Answer cross posted to: http://serverfault.com/questions/186892/ec2-issue-using-pv-grub-and-custom-kernel-error-21-selected-disk-does-not-exist

Convert Small to Micro Instance - SQL Server Express Issue I have a successfully running Small Instance and use SQL Server Express (included).  I've noticed, while I was initially experimenting, that the SQL Server Express Server Name changes if I take the instance offline for any length of time, and then bring it back online.  This causes an issue with all of my connection strings, etc.  So, how do I convert a Small Instance to a Micro Instance?  Will the connection strings and/or local IP address change?

If you are connecting from an app running locally on the same instance you can create a connection string that used "(local)" or "./sqlexpress" in the connection string instead of the IP address or the machine name.  EC2 instances get a new IP address every time you launch them (there is nothing you can do about this, but you can assign them a static "Elastic IP" which you could use if you are connecting to SQL from other servers).  Windows EC2 instances also get a new dynamically generated machine name every time you launch them by default, BUT you can disable this feature and assign your own machine name if you like (note: this is NOT the same as the DNS name of the server).  Small vs. Micro vs. Medium instance size has nothing to do with any of this.

I have an Elastic IP address assigned, but found that the internal services could not use that address (probably a firewall issue), but they could use the internal address.  I did try to assign a machine name, but that didn't work either.  I must be missing something on that...  But the main issue I'm curious about is how to convert the server from a "Small" to a "Micro" even though I might have to change connection strings and recompile services to get things working again.

To convert from a small instance to another instance size you need to bundle the existing instance into a new AMI, and then you can boot that AMI on any compatible instance size (needs to be 32bit in this case).

Ok, I've changed all the connection strings and I think I'm ready to convert to the micro.  I thought I was making an AMI, but it appeared under "Shortcuts" and nothing appears under AMI.  Then, I was trying to create a Micro Instance and got completely lost on the options.  Could you give step-by-step instructions on how to convert from one instance type to another using the existing disk image?

Hi S. Mol,If you want to create an AMI from your SQL Server Express instance, I recommend that you review the steps listed in the User Guide:http://docs.amazonwebservices.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/creating-an-ami.htmlNote that t1.micro instances can only run EBS-backed AMIs, so if you are using an S3-backed instance, you will not be able to run it on a micro.  If this is indeed an EBS-backed instance, you can also switch it to a micro with a stop/start (however I strongly recommend that you create an AMI first).  Using the EC2 API Tools, you would run:$ ec2-stop-instances <instance-id>$ ec2-modify-instance-attribute -t t1.micro <instance-id>$ ec2-start-instances <instance-id>Finally, you may want to consider whether running SQL Server on a t1.micro will provide suitable performance for your use case.  For more on this, I recommend that you review the User Guide page about Micro instances:http://docs.amazonwebservices.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/concepts_micro_instances.htmlRegards,-Jason

how did you upload files to your EC2 instance? I have a windows instance and I am not able to upload any files into it?  I could run a filezilla and download it from my another server but in order to install filezilla I need to download it from the web but, when I go to a webpage it does not let me download anything?  What do I do?

By default, Internet Explorer on a Windows Server doesn't allow downloading executable files. You need to change the settings in IE to allow this:1. Connect to your Windows instance. 2. Open IE.3. Click Tools > Internet Options.4. Switch to the Security tab.5. Click the Internet icon.6. Click Custom Level.7. In the Security Settings dialog box, scroll down to the Downloads section.8. Change File Download from Disable to Enable.9. Click OK to close the Security Settings dialog box.10. Click OK to close the Internet Options dialog box.Now you should be able to download Filezilla to get files from your other server.I tried to set up the Filezilla FTP server using XAMPP on my Windows so that I could FTP stuff from my machine directly to my instance, but after a couple of hours of Googling and trying stuff, I finally gave up. It's easier to just FTP stuff to my shared hosting account (where my web sites are currently hosted) to move it over. *sigh*I hope this helped with the first of your two problems, though! Good luck!
