They say it doesn't have to be in the 'running' state, so it should be possible to assign even when the instance is still 'pending'.Actually, most often it works exactly as explained above. But it seems this behavior is not entirely reliable.I have been testing an automatic bootstrapping technique where new nodes are launched from another controlling node. Every now and then I'm getting the following error messages:EC2 Instance: i-abcdef01Associating the Elastic IP 12.34.56.78: Client.InvalidInstanceId: The instance 'i-abcdef01' is not in the 'running' state(The ID and IP have been changed.)Below is the part of the bash script that is producing these messages.So... should it or shouldn't it work? Is this officially supported, or is some other method of assigning Elastic IP's more recommendable? If I base my scripts on this technique, can I rely on them to be future compatible?Any opinions or pointers would be welcome!# Start the EC2 instance and discover its identity information.# This script is designed to start only one instance at a time.echo -e "Launching: \c"ec2run -k "$KEYPAIR" $EC2_OPTIONS -n 1 > "$RESPONSE_FILE"if [ "$?" -ne "0" ]; then        echo FAILED        exit 1else        echo OKfiINSTANCE_ID=$(grep "INSTANCE" "$RESPONSE_FILE" | awk '{ print $2 }')echo EC2 Instance: "$INSTANCE_ID"if [ -n "$ELASTIC_IP" ]; then    echo -e "Associating the Elastic IP $ELASTIC_IP: \c"    ec2assocaddr "$ELASTIC_IP" -i "$INSTANCE_ID" > /dev/null || exit $?    echo OKfi

Internal IP addresses I can't seem to locate this answer.  Are my instances accessible by other amazon EC2 customers via their private IPs? Or, are they nat'd somehow to keep my instances separate from other users?

They're accessible by whatever access you grant to the security groups they belong to. By default that is no access to anyone else. You can add access to allow specific other accounts to access your instances, but you have to configure that, it's off by default.

What is the easiest way to allow my internal instances to have full access to each other?  I dont want anyone else having that access, but I would like for the instances themselves to be able to communicate openly with each other.

Or, would it make sense to setup a VPC and set my own subnet (and then create one rule, versus a rule in every security group I have)?  If I don't have a VPN setup, it appears as though the VPC is free to use?
To achieve that you can just add the access group to itself.
After a quick search, I didnt find any instructions on how to do that through the interface.  Any direction would be greatly appreciated.

In the AWS console, set the various boxes to:Custom, tcp, 1, 65535, GROUPNAME"GROUPNAME" is the name of the current security group.  Hit Save.  Now all boxes in the GROUPNAME group have unlimited access to each other.
From the AWS console, it sets the dropdowns and values to null (blank) whenever I insert the group name.  any advice?
Nevermind - this might be a google chrome issue.

Actually, you're right, it does erase the dropdowns.  I guess they made it so if you type a group name, that group has full access no matter what.  Just type the group name and hit save.  Even easier!

For those whoever might be interested reading this thread in the future... Managed to get this running now at least. The process that worked for me is as follows:1) Install your server based on one of the AMIs available at http://uec-images.ubuntu.com/releases/karmic/release/2) Install all required tools with the following:sudo apt-get updatesudo apt-get upgradeexport DEBIAN_FRONTEND=noninteractiveecho "deb http://ppa.launchpad.net/ubuntu-on-ec2/ec2-tools/ubuntu karmic main" |  sudo tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/ubuntu-on-ec2-ec2-tools.list &&sudo apt-key adv --keyserver keyserver.ubuntu.com --recv-keys 9EE6D873 &&sudo apt-get update &&sudo -E apt-get upgrade -y &&sudo -E apt-get install -y   python-vm-builder ec2-ami-tools ec2-api-tools bzr &&bzr branch lp:vmbuildersudo apt-get install python-vm-builder-ec23) Then build your image using vmbuilder as described at https://wiki.ubuntu.com/EC2Vmbuilder. At the moment, vmbuilder seems to run ok but nothing appears in S3, so I still have somewhere to go with this, but at least managed to get the tools running finally!!

Ha ha, went around one more cicle with all this, but have now a working process. The key is to use the official Ubuntu images as a base and then your loop device will work fine. After that I installed the underlying software with:sudo sed -i.dist 's,universe$,universe multiverse,' /etc/apt/sources.listsudo apt-get updatesudo apt-get install ec2-api-tools ec2-ami-tools Created the bundle with:sudo ec2-bundle-vol -d /mnt/ami-my-instance/ -k /mnt/pk-key.pem -c /mnt/cert.pem -u YOUR_AWS_IDAnd then uploaded it to S3 with the following:sudo ec2-upload-bundle --bucket ami-my-instance --access-key YOUR_AWS_ACCESS_KEY --secret-key YOUR_AWS_SECRET_KEY --manifest /mnt/ami-my-instance/image.manifest.xmlHopefully this will help anyone other AMI newby in future

What file system Amazon Linux AMI support? Does Amazon Linux AMI support XFS and/or JFS filesystem?  Will Amazon officially support those file system?

The supported file system in the Amazon Linux AMI is currently ext3. Kernel modules are included in the AMI to access other file systems such as ext4, xfs and jfs. The YUM repository also includes tools to create and maintain xfs file systems.

Elastic Loadbalancer private IP address changes I read in many threads that the public IP of ELB changes and the recommendation is to use a CNAME record. We had an incident wherein the Private IP address of our ELB changed. Is this normal?  how do we work around this issue, especially when there is strict ACLs on the backend servers to accept connections only from the private IP address of ELB?  Thanks.

Hello,> We had an incident wherein the Private IP address of our ELB changed. Is this normal?Yes, this is an expected behavior. ELB increase/decrease the capacity based on the load. Private IP also changes depend on these changes of capacity.You can filter by some wide private IP range if you'd like to apply more strict rules for instances, however please keep it in your mind that the IP range also might be changed in the future and then causes sudden unavailability of your ELB and instances.Best Regards,Sachiko
Thanks. Is there a specific private IP range used by the ELBs?

ELB IP address change policy Hi,  We've recently run into problems when an ELB that was balancing traffic between 2 instances suddenly changed its IP address, and our website started displaying data from another site. We were accessing the ELB directly with its IP address, not DNS name.  We know that the ELB is guaranteed to being always accessible using its DNS name, but is there any official Amazon documentation that  covers this situation?

from http://docs.amazonwebservices.com/ElasticLoadBalancing/latest/DeveloperGuide/SvcIntro.html:
Because the set of IP addresses associated with a LoadBalancer can change over time, you should never create an "A" record with any specific IP address. If you want to use a friendly DNS name for your LoadBalancer instead of the name generated by the Elastic Load Balancing service, you should create a CNAME record for the LoadBalancer DNS name. For more information about CNAME records, see the CNAME Record Wikipedia article.

AMI is S3 or EBS? Hi -- would anyone be so kind as to tell me how I can tell if my AMI has been persisted to S3 (my preference) or EBS?Everyone says I should be able to see traces of my AMI in S3, but I went to the S3 browser and my S3 is empty!  (But that's very suspicious because I can store and retrieve things through boto just fine.)Are there any other ways I can definitely find out?And if it turns out that I have an EBS AMI instead of an S3 one, how can I convert it?  It is under 10 GiB, so it was my understanding that there should be no problems in having it be in S3.Thanks!

Hi thereThe easiest option I can suggest to you is that you login to the AWS web console select the instances tab on the left hand side of the page. This will bring up a list of all your running instances. On this list you will see one the Column marked "Root Device" if the device title is Instance-store then your instance is S3 backed otherwise it's going to be an EBS backed instance.If your instances are S3 backed there is no option to convert them to EBS backed AMI's you will need to startup a replacement EBS backed instance and transfer your data and settings to the new instance.I just want to make sure that you understand that the EBS backed instances are more resilient and have persistence when you start stop your instances. You can also make snapshots of EBS volumes of your server allowing you to keep multiple backups of your volumes which is not possible on S3 backed instances.S3 backed AMI's do not have persistence and if your instance should reboot or crash you will loose any data that's currently there. I hope this answers your question and thanks again for posting to our forums.

Hi, thank you very much.  There was a lot of good information in your answer.I recognize EBS is more flexible than S3, but it was my understanding that EBS had about three 9's of reliability and S3 had about six.  Having those six 9's of reliability would be awesome.  Especially since I'm only trying to save a small root drive with it.For each AMI I have, I see a snapshot.  I see on other Amazon pages that snapshots are always backed up by S3 ... correct?  But for each of my running instances based of my AMIs, the root device says EBS.  And when no instances are running, I don't see anything under the "Volumes" area of my EC2 dashboard.Does this mean my snapshot is actually saved in EBS instead of S3?  That's the only way I can reconcile all of these facts.Thanks!

S3 backed AMI's do not have persistence and if your instance should reboot or crash you will loose any data that's currently there.  Just a clarification: The only data that is lost when an instance reboots is the contents of memory. All disks - whether ephemeral or EBS - remain unaffected by a reboot. This is true for both instance-store instances and EBS-backed instances.  JasonM@AWS, perhaps you meant "terminate" instead of "reboot" ?

Wait -- how about this explanation.  The old style of doing things was to have an AMI stored on S3 and boot through that.  But that has a number of limitations.So the new style of doing things is to have your AMI stored on EBS and boot through that.  And you can still get six 9's of reliability by snapshotting your EBS to S3.Am I getting closer to understanding?Thanks!

amillsx,EBS-backed AMI's are launched from snapshots, which are stored on S3 and have six 9's of reliabibilty, just like an S3-backed AMI.  IMHO the real questions are:1) is fast launch time important (advantage EBS)2) do you require, or benefit from ability to "stop" an instance for period of time, and thus avoid hourly run-time charges? (advantage EBS)A use-case for #2 is a windows instance I run as a replacement for VMware on my Mac. VMware was a resource hog and I only needed it for a few specialty apps I used now an then. Now I have a windows EBS-backed instance that I start and stop when I need those apps. They actually startup faster than VMware could load my Windows VM, and it's cost me less than $5 a month so far in run-time and storage charges.Regarding snapshots- you need to be careful- you shouldn't be writing to disk when you snapshot, as some data is invariably in a memory cache somewhere at that moment and could be lost- or worse, corrupt the snapshot by its absense.I prefer S3-backed instances for full-time Linux servers. I make use of EBS volumes for data that changes often, and use snapshot scripts from alestic.com and techniques Shlomo has blogged about to make sure my EBS volumes are in a "frozen" state before snapshots are taken.

Change instance type when root partition is on EBS Hi all,I'm at the point where I have to choose which instance type I want to use.For now I should be fine with a m1.large instance (7.5GB). Although, I'm quite sure that I will be needing extra memory for that instance in about two months maybe.I'm planning on using EBS to store the root partition as that will be the easiest in case I need to apply changes to the OS.The question now is, can I change from instance type over time, without loosing my data, or  will I have to manually copy my data from the old EBS instance to the new one?Thank you for consideration

You can change instance type when the instance is stopped.  Note that you can only change to instance types of the same architecture as the original type (32-bit vs 64-bit).  http://docs.amazonwebservices.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/index.html?Using_ChangingAttributesWhileInstanceStopped.html
That's great!This must have changed in the last year or so, as my search on the forum only resulted in people saying that you need to create a new instance.Thanks a lot.
With S3-backed instances, you would need to create a new instance.  If you're using EBS-backed instances, you can change when stopped.

How exactly can you change the EBS backed instance types?  Can you do it within the AWS Management Console?I have an EBS backed instance I believe (the root device says "ebs", is that correct?)Thanks!

Currently you cannot do it from the AWS Management web site.  You have to use the API.  From the command line, it would be something like:ec2-stop-instances i-whateverec2-modify-instance-attribute -t c1.medium i-whateverec2-start-instances i-whatever
Thats great help, thank you.Is there something similar if I want to increase the size of the volume/ESB?  Is that possible?

mike,> Is there something similar if I want to increase the size of the volume/ESB?  Is that possible?Yes, this is possible, but whether it is going to be successful depends on your operating system setup. Instructions for a typical Linux setup using the ext3 filesystem can be found here:http://alestic.com/2010/02/ec2-resize-running-ebs-rootA similar technique can be used with typical Windows setups, and with some other Linux filesystems. Please try this on a test setup, rather than your production system, if you are in any doubt about the filesystem resizing step.RegardsMarc

High steal CPU utilization Hi,  We are using m1.small instance in EC2. While checking my CPU utilization, it showing more than 50% in steal column.   1. What is the reason for it? 2. How to reduce it?  Thank You  Message was edited by: kborah

"Steal time is the time that (1) the CPU had something runnable, but (2) the hypervisor chose to run something else instead." (from http://3spoken.wordpress.com/2006/12/10/cpu-steal-time-the-new-statistic/)  The m1.small is stated to have "1 EC2 Compute Unit (1 virtual core with 1 EC2 Compute Unit)" and "One EC2 Compute Unit provides the equivalent CPU capacity of a 1.0-1.2 GHz 2007 Opteron or 2007 Xeon processor." (both from http://aws.amazon.com/ec2/instance-types/)  If you look at /proc/cpuinfo, you will see that the real processor in use has much more capacity than the processor in the description.  So Amazon is sharing that processor between multiple instances.  The steal is when it is servicing other instances.  You cannot reduce the steal on a given instance type; if you need more processing power, you need to move to a larger instance type.

Hello,> 3) When I click to launch the instance I don't see that reserved instance is available as well.Reserved instance will not run automatically, either you can't see any special indication like a "This is Reserved instance".Launching a Reserved Instance is no different than launching anOn-Demand Instance. You simply use the RunInstances command or launchan instance via the AWS Management Console. Amazon EC2 will optimally apply the cheapest rate that you are eligible for in the backgroundFor more details, please visit this URL also:http://aws.amazon.com/ec2/faqs/#What_is_a_Reserved_InstanceBest Regards,Sachiko

ELB health checks do not always occur in a timely fashion (I'm re-posting this as a question, since I didn't get a response last time, and we're having this issue again today)Hello,We have a group of testing servers sitting behind an ELB that are almost always in a stopped state (only the ELB runs full-time). Our automated testing framework occasionally starts these servers and watches the ELB for 10 minutes (to ensure that the web servers are running) before deploying the latest code and starting its tests. This process usually works fine, but every once in a while, the ELB seems to get into a state where health checks do not occur for 20 minutes or more. This means the load balancer continues to return 503s, even though the webservers are actually up and running.I've seen other posts where people had forgotten to allow access through their firewalls, but I don't think this is the case for us, since we don't run a local firewall on our instances. I can also see hits in the request logs when I access the servers directly from our office. What I'm not seeing are any recent requests from clients with a user-agent of "ELB-HealthChecker/1.0." Funny, just as I was about to post this, I noticed that the health check started occurring again, but nobody changed anything. Looking at the logs, I see a period from 19:59:05 to 20:25:57 GMT (2010-09-21) where the servers were up and running, but no health checks occurred, even though our ELB is configured to perform health checks every 60 seconds.- Michael Conigliaro

Hi Michael,If the instance is in Stopped state, the load balancer temporarily stops the health check. It then periodically checks to see when the instance is back into Running state.For the use case you described, it would be better to deregister the instance from the load balancer when it is not in use (before it is Stopped), and re-register it when it is in use again (after it is Running). In that case, the load balancer will put it into service right away.

OK, thanks for the reply. I have updated our scripts so that the instances are de-registered and re-registered with the ELB every time they are started/stopped. The problem now is that the instances tend to get stuck in an "out of service" state with a description of "instance registration is still in progress." The instances might sit in this state for an hour or two before they're actually in service behind the ELB.- Michael Conigliaro

I have a similar situation.  The node was stuck in an "out of service" state with a description of "instance registration is still in progress." for quite a bit.  I removed and re-added it from the load balancer and it was immediately in service.  Should the node be completely up before it is added into service?

It seems that if you wait until the instances are in a "running" state before adding them to the load balancer, you get much better results. This has been my experience for the last few days anyway,- Michael Conigliaro

How could you NOT have an Elastic IP? Silly question, but if you are running anything outside of a burstable instance, aren't static IPs pretty much required? You are correct.  If you have an instance that is serving requests to an external client, then its pretty much a no-brainer to use an elastic IP.  Cases when you don't need elastic IPs include load balanced and background worker instances (aka "burstable").

EC2 Security and Newbie Questions I've ready as much documentation as I can stand to read, but do have a few questions:  1) I will be creating Windows instances.  From what I can tell, those instances auto-create a EBS volume.  To that end, what would cause a volume to be terminated (outside of me clicking on the terminate button) that I need to be careful of?  Meaning, what ways could I lose the data (outside of a windows virus, etc) on that instance?  2) Can any of the EBS volumes be accessed from the outside world?  Translation - do I have to worry about my data being accessible through a AWS webservice that I'm not familiar with?  3) I've tried to find a guide for a recommend windows instance configuration for a basic environment.  For example, right now, I have a gogrid account that has a webserver, a database server, and then an f5 load balancer in front of it all to allow for scaling later.  Any have any good advice on how to create a solution that will scale easily in the future?  4) If I have an app that allows users to map CNAMES to the application, do the load balancers have IP addresses that I should setup now? (or, if I create an elastic ip, that will be the loadbalanced ip in the future) .. if that makes sense.  Thanks!
Hello,  I want to get answers to this questions.  I have the same doubts!  Regards, DD

1) I will be creating Windows instances.  From what I can tell, those instances auto-create a EBS volume. To that end, what would cause a volume to be terminated (outside of me clicking on the terminate button) that I need to be careful of?  Instances should only terminate due to API action (e.g. clicking on the terminate button) or hardware failure.   Meaning, what ways could I lose the data (outside of a windows  virus, etc) on that instance?  If you have the root (C:) volume set to persist after termination, then you should only loose data if the EBS storage has a massive failure.  2) Can any of the EBS volumes be accessed from the outside world?  Translation - do I have to worry about my data being accessible through a AWS webservice that I'm not familiar with?  EBS volumes are only accessible to EC2 instances with the same owner as the EBS volume.  However, if you create a snapshot, then the snapshot can be shared with other EC2 users.  3) I've tried to find a guide for a recommend windows instance configuration for a basic environment.  For example, right now, I have a gogrid account that has a webserver, a database server, and then an f5 load balancer in front of it all to allow for scaling later.  Any have any good advice on how to create a solution that will scale easily in the future?  I would suggest looking at Elastic Load Balancers.  They offer similar functionality to the f5 load balancer in GoGrid.  4) If I have an app that allows users to map CNAMES to the application, do the load balancers have IP addresses that I should setup now? (or, if I create an elastic ip, that will be the loadbalanced ip in the future) .. if that makes sense.  Each Elastic Load Balancer you create has a dedicated hostname that should be the target of a CNAME.
Many thanks!  Quick follow-ups:  Do hardware or EBS failures happen a lot?  What can I do to protect myself from either of these?  Thanks!

The EC2 security groups only restrict inbound connections.  There is no restriction on connections from the instance to external hosts.

Amazon EC2 + AutoScaling + Load Balance... what best solution? Hi,  I have an instance where we have customer's websites, and regularly have the 503 or 404 error. When this problem go to accessing via RDP and could not access to the instance. This occurs if the server goes to the ~100% CPU use and/or ~100% RAM occupied.  Instance type - m1.small: - Small Instance (Default) 1.7 GB of memory, 1 EC2 Compute Unit (1 virtual core with 1 EC2 Compute Unit), 160 GB of local instance storage, 32-bit platform  We have in this instance:  - (AMI Id: ami-cf517bbb) - Microsoft Windows Server 2008 R1 SP2 Datacenter edition, 32-bit architecture, Microsoft SQLServer 2008 Express, Internet Information Services 7, ASP.NET 3.5.  Install SQLServer 2008 Standard PHP 5.2.x on IIS 7 with FastGCI MySQL 5.x   Websites: - 9 Websites in .NET 2.0 (.aspx), all use a SQL Server database  1 Website in PHP, use one MySQL database   Users access to all sites, average: 510 visitors/day RAM Average occupied: 1.17Gb  (~69%) CPU Usage Average: 55% (Máx: 90% one time on last 7 days) Network In Average (5 minutes): 260 Kbs Network Out Average (5 minutes): 229 Kbs  Have CloudWath Service running on this instance.  The Question:   To resolve this downtime on instance is best:  Option 1: Changing the server for an instance with more resources  ("Large Instance", etc), but what is the best option for websites on Windows IIS 7/.NET ?  Option 2: Have a "Load Balance" and "AutoScaling" on this type of instance (m1.small) and running this to prevent CPU/RAM usage problems ?  In your experience, what advise?  The "AWS Premium Support" allows help with this choice, they analyze the problem and advise the best solution? If the best solution was the Load Balance and Autoscaling, exist a way to do this from the Console (for example) or other application, without need to develop a application?  Can you send a message (PM) if can help find a solution to this problem.

The AWS Premium Support Guidelines and FAQ describe the available offerings.  The support does not cover help with system design, architecture or code development.  However it does cover general how-to questions, and provide help with configuring the services and using the tools.http://aws.amazon.com/premiumsupport/guidelines/http://aws.amazon.com/premiumsupport/faqs/A  common architecture for web-applications such as the one you've described is to have a group of "frontend + application-server" instances, which in your case would run IIS, hosting identical copies of your ASP.NET and PHP code.  In such an architecture each frontend host connects to the same central database, that is running on a separate instance from any frontend instance (you may want to use the same instance for your SQLServer and MySQL, or they could go on separate instances).  In EC2 the frontend instances would belong to an AutoScaling group, with an Elastic Load Balancer distributing requests amongst them.  The separate backend database instance would not be AutoScaled.http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three-tier_%28computing%29#Web_development_usageSome advantages of migrating to such an architecture instead of moving everything to a larger instance are:* Sometimes computers fail.  If you're running everything on one instance and it fails, your applications are completely "down".  However if you have multiple copies of the frontend and one goes down, the Elastic Load Balancer will stop sending traffic to it, reducing the impact on your customers.  Unhealthy instances in a group can be automatically replaced by AutoScaling.* If your traffic continues to increase or you begin hosting new applications and you are still running on only one instance, you will eventually have to migrate everything to an even larger host.  With the multi-tiered architecture you simply increase the size of your frontend fleet.  AutoScaling can do this for you automatically.* You may find that different EC2 instance-types "fit" better for the frontend vs. the database.  You may find that the database performs better with more memory that isn't needed on each of the the frontend instances.  Some downsides to this architecture:* There are more components to configure and maintain.  However the EC2 facilities such as AutoScaling automate much of this once it's configured.* The central database is still a single-point of failure.  However both SQLServer and MySQL allow deployments on multiple instances.  For MySQL, the Relational Database Service (RDS) can manage this for you.Moving to this architecture does require the ASP.NET and PHP code be constructed for such a deployment.  Any shared state in the application (such as user-sessions) must be kept in the central database, and not on an individual frontend server (since individual web requests can go to random frontend servers, and AutoScaling may start up or shut down instances depending on the load).  If these are 3rd-party applications you are hosting, you will need to consult their documentation to see if they support this style of deployment.http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shared_nothing_architecture-Eric

Really dumb question: Where do I find the EC2_PRIVATE_KEY? I'm trying to get the EC2 API command-line tools set up.  I believe I have the EC2_CERT, but I cannot for the life of me figure out where to download the file for the EC2_PRIVATE_KEY environment variable.  Where exactly in the web interface do I locate this?  There seem to be so many different types of credential, I'm confused by which one I need here.

The private key and certificate are in Access (Security) Credentials section of the your account settings, under the X.509 certificates tab.  Note that the key is displayed when you create a certificate and AWS does not retain it, so you have to create a new certificate if you do not have the key.

Hi againIt looks like the instance i-dcd253b5 to which this volume is attached may have rebooted a few times.Are you sure you are remounting the EBS volume(s) again after each reboot. Lost administrator password in Windows Hi,Yesterday I created a Windows instance (i-b608ccc1 from AMI ID ami-c1ebc0b5).I connected with remote desktop, logged in and changed the Administrator password.Today I can't log in. The password isn't correct.If I try to log in with the original password, that doesn't work neither.If I do a "Get Windows Admin password" i recieve the original password from yesterday.What to do?

The Get Password API call does not return the "current" password of the instance.  It only returns the random password which was assigned when the instance was started.Your only recourse if you've lost your admin password is to launch a new instance, as Amazon does not have any way to set it or retrieve the existing password.In the future, it is good practice, both operationally and security standpoint to create an administrative account (in addition to Administrator) on the instance with a password known only to you.  You will run less risk of being totally locked out and it also allows you the opportunity to set a much more complex password on your Administrator account to prevent it from being compromised.

This might help others:I had a similar situation. I figured out when I restarted the instance, it got another ID, hence the shortcut was created initially was pointing to a - then - non-existing instance, so the password could not be checked by the instance and got the error message.From the Management Console I chose Connect and recreated the shortcut.Voila, I was able to login with the password I set earlier.Good luck!

Simply stop the instance (DO NOT terminate it). Detach the EBS volume. Start up a Linux instance and attach the Windows EBS volume to it. Download the "Offline NT Password & Registry Editor" utility and reset the password. Unmount the EBS volume and start your Windows instance again.

Virtual IPs for a instance Hi Amazon,      Is it possible to create virtual private ips in my instance. Any private IP would be fine. We need 5 IPs. We will use this internally in our application. Can you throw some light here.  --raj

EC2 does not have Virtual IPs, it has Elastic IPs. Unlike virtual IPs, Elastic IPs cannot be integrated into the OS's network layer, since they are NATted.  For more info:  http://developer.amazonwebservices.com/connect/entry.jspa?externalID=1346
Hello,     What is the point in getting a PUBLIC IP address while I just need a private IP for my application. Am I missing something here?  Thanks Raj

Are you talking about private IP's on the EC2 internal network? Or just dummy IP's that "don't go anywhere"? Obviously the later is a matter of OS support and not EC2 support. There are lots of dummy adapters that you could use for this purpose under Windows and Linux.

Public IP address for ec2.amazonaws.com Our corporate firewall blocks all outbound connections, except the ones we whitelist.    I'm currently developing an application that would leverage the EC2 command line API to provision instances, monitor status etc.  I see that when using the API all of the outbound requests are hitting ec2.amazonaws.com, or 72.21.206.77.   Would we be safe to assume that the IP address for API calls is relatively stable? I'd like to avoid proxying all of the API calls to a machine in our DMZ if at all possible.  Thanks in advance, Ryan
Okay, so I just rechecked the DNS and its coming up 72.21.210.54, which leads me to believe that the API at ec2.amazonaws.com exists on a range of IP addresses.  Is this range listed somewhere?

Your company's firewall policy sounds crazily restrictive.  I don't think there is a predictable or published range for the EC2 API endpoints. You could try opening up the whole CIDR range but that's not a guarantee.

Fortunately I was incorrect about just how restrictive the policy is.  We actually allow outbound port 80/443.  Outbound port blocking imho is a really silly measure that adds false security to a system. Sure a rogue virus could go wild inside the corp firewall and disallowing outbound connections to unknown ports would slow or stop most of those, but haven't virus authors caught on by now and simply started using port 80/443 as a means to export their payload? Anyhow, it would be nice to restrict the outbound http requests to known hosts that our host is supposed to connect to in the unlikely event of compromise, but I guess we'll just have to wait for Amazon to publish what subnet's their api interface may exist on at any given time.

ec2-authorize - Maybe some simple help or advice needed We've got EJB instances in group-A that register their address on a memcached instance (group-C) so that webtier instances can auto discover them. In testing we've allowed world access to 11211 on group-C instances, but now need to tighten that up.I've used this and remove world access:ec2-authorize group-C -P tcp -p 11211 -u {user-code} -o group-Aec2-authorize group-C -P tcp -p 11211 -u {user-code} -o group-BAnd get this from ec2-describe-group:PERMISSION      {user-code} group-C       ALLOWS  tcp     11211   11211   FROM      USER    {user-code} GRPNAME group-APERMISSION      {user-code} group-C       ALLOWS  tcp     11211   11211   FROM      USER    {user-code} GRPNAME group-BNow, no other instances can communicate with memcached. I can't even telnet to it from the webtier or EJB instances. The webtier and EJB instances are defintely in the correct security group. I cannot see why this very simple step is failing.Any ideas where I'm going wrong, or what steps I should be taking to try to track down the error?Thanks.

InsufficientInstanceCapacity in a us-east zone I occasionally run an instance in a particular availability zone (us-east-1a for me) and make use of an EBS volume in that zone.  In the past few days I have not been able to launch a new instance in the zone.  I seem to be able to launch in other zones without a problem.  Is there a problem that is known and being addressed here?  Should I think about moving my EBS volume into a different zone (us-east-1b) and run instances there until I have start having problems there too?Is there a way to determine which zone is least near maximum capacity?
I haven't been able to launch an instance (m1.small) in my us-east-1a zone since my post.  The service health dashboard displays everything as normal.Is that supposed to be considered normal?

Still no answers?  What is going on?  I haven't been able to launch in us-east-1a for a long time.  Can't you just buy more drives, nodes or whatever it is there isn't enough of?  Come on... make it cloudier!

Still a problem.  I still CAN'T launch instances in us-east-1a.  I CAN launch in other zones.Also, my spot instance request that I set up last week has still not launched.  Is there any sort official or semi-official answer available?  Is this zone going to be perpetually over capacity?It has been a month since I first posted this question.
Still a problem.

Hi,  we got the same issue as you a few weeks ago.  I directly asked the support. They told me that us-east-1a and us-east1b were quite full.  The best is to use us-east-1c and us-east-1d. We regularly launch new instances in both of them without problem.  Vermeer

I wish they could tell you the "health" and availability of the various zones.  Your us-east-1a may not be the same as mine.If I am going to move EBS volumes to another zone in order to use them I would like to know which zone is furthest from reaching maximum capacity.  There doesn't appear to be any way to do this.When they state, "Our system will be working on provisioning additional capacity.", it would be nice to know whether or not this will be so long one should bother moving EBS volumes to another zone.
Still a problem and still no official answer.

Here's an enlightening (although not in a good way) bit of discourse I had with a support person:I said:
I'm particularly concerned about this kind of scenario:Let's say us-east-1a fails completely, leaving b, c, and d online.All the well architected applications will attempt to re-launch in oneof the three remaining zones.Given that Amazon is struggling to meet capacity demands when allzones are online, how will they be able to meet the demand with only75% of the normal capacity available?I'd appreciate your thoughts on this scenario. In my mind, it somewhatdefeats the purpose of building a properly redundant EC2 deployment.
They said:
 ... if an entire zone goes down, then it makes complete sense to have instances in other zones. However, reserved instances is the best way to ensure that you are guaranteed capacity because reserved instances get a commitment of capacity from our side and will ensure you have instances in other zones if one zone goes down.
To which I said:
Well, yes, we do use reserved instances.But if a zone containing our reserved instances fails entirely (as Irecall this actually has happened in the not too distant past) then weare left to look at other zones in which we do not have reservations.And in a major outage scenario there is unlikely to be non-reservedavailability.Are you suggesting that we buy a reserved instances in another zonethat will never be utilized unless an entire Amazon EC2 zone fails?Again, this seems to defeat the point of "elastic" cloud computing.
All I got back was:
Thanks for the feedback. I've escalated this internally.
None of this seems too 'elastic' to me!

Need more RAM and CPU size on this instances Hi ,I am having the instance of small size and it is not EBS based. its a normal instance. My applications are running on it now I need more RAM and CPU size on this instances.I heard that there is a form which we have to fill. Can you please tell me the location of that form so that i fill it and send it to Amazon.Regards,Suukhbir

Cannot rename Windows 2008 Server after launch Hi;I purchased a reserved instance and chose one of the amazon quick start AMI's for Windows Server 3008 and launched it. Once logged in to the server i try to rename it and it says it is going to get the new name after a reboot but when it comes back up it still has the old name. I am new to AWS. Am i missing something basic? Do i need to create an image first and then use that? Any help is appreciated.James

i figured it out. I had to go into C:\Program Files\Amazon\Ec2ConfigService and run Ec2ConfigServiceSettings.exe and remove the checkmark from "set computer name". Once i did this i was able to rename my server to what i wanted it to be and it persisted after a reboot.

It's been a while since this thread, but recently I had another go and things seemed to work smoothly. I think the only difference is that this time, I realized that the ramdisk should be left unspecified. Last time, I probably interpreted the output of ec2-describe-images as saying the ramdisk was ebs, whereas this time I noticed that in fact ec2-describe-images just doesn't show null values. See sample output to understand what I mean (using --debug here helps, since you see labels for all the values in the XML response):  $ ec2-describe-images ami-10164655 IMAGE   ami-10164655    923946715324/prod       923946715324    available      private          x86_64  machine aki-c397c686                    ebs BLOCKDEVICEMAPPING      /dev/sda1               snap-d92ae5b2   15  Message was edited by: Yang Zhang

Instance wouldn't reboot, now stuck in "stopping" state for > 1 hour We have an EBS-backed large instance (i-9562c2fe) in us-east-1b that is not responding to a stop request.  It has been in a "stopping" state for > 1 hour now. The initial stop command was issued via the web console, and I've repeated it a couple more times via the command line tools, but with no change in state.  We're actually trying to reboot the instance - but the initial reboot command didn't work either (although it did appear to complete and move back to a running state - but the instance was non-responsive).  This is our standby database for our production system so we really need to get this back on line ASAP!

In the absence of anyone replying or assisting, I thought I'd update people on what we did.  After 12 hours of being in a "stopping" state and numerous attempts to stop it, I re-ran the stop-instance command using the --force option.  This had no immediate effect, but by this morning it had finally stopped. Whether this was the --force, AWS catching up, or an admin doing something I'll never know.  However, to work around the issue while this was happening I snapshotted every volume and created a new image from the snapshots using the ec2-register command.   I then brought up the new instance without issue. Certainly reinforces the value of EBS backed AMI's.  This was clearly a problem with AWS - it would have been nice to have some acknowledgement of the problem.  I'm going to start the old instance back up to see if I can discern what might have gone wrong to cause the reboot in the first place.

rpmforge/rpmfusion on Linux AMI I need to get some trivial stuff working (davfs2/fusedav/...) that's not in the repos for the Official Linux AMI. Tried to add rpmfusion or rpmforge but not much luck.  I figure making a conscious decision to add those repos (as the Linux AMI are RH based, no?) should provide the flexibility you might expect from a cloud. In stead I am back in dependency tracking, configure/make/build.... and considering a ready-made Ubuntu server image or so - at least they have partner repos.  Anyway: has anybody found a way to extend the standard repos for the Linux AMIs to make them a bit more useable?

It looks like for davfs2 has a dependency on libneon.  We have upgraded the version of libneon in the existing repo.  We are working on getting a rhel5 compatible version of the neon library to include in the repo, as well.

Great, but wouldn't it be great if we can use rpmforge or rpmfusion? The linux amis are clearl RH based, so that might be an effe tive effort for people that want to step out of the aws repo realm.  As a comparison: I fired up the ubuntu 10.04 server image on EC2 and "it just works".
Thanks for the feedback.  We're looking into the best way to support rpmforge and/or rpmfusion now.  We will update this thread as the status changes.

Thank you for the feedback.  We are striving to support additional repositories as best as we can.  As for the original package in the thread, we have provided a neon0.25 package that fulfills the dependencies for the davfs2 package from rpmforge.  You should now be able to add the rpmforge repository and install the davfs2 package via yum.Please let us know if you run into any other issues.

Was this Windows 2003 or 2008?  If it occurs again, you might try perusing the Windows event log for any record of RDP service error, and also look at performance data via perfmon logs to see whether this is possibly caused by the instance being "overloaded" in some way or another.Other than that, you might try looking at a network trace on your client side to see whether the "freeze" is due to errors in the network transport, which may indicate problems in the routing path between your client and the instance.

We are having RDP problems to our instances. If we do restart, we cannot connect to that server again using RDP. We've been having this problems since May 17 2010. Some server will respond after 2 and on the 3rd restart, it will die. Please help. We are using Windows 2008 DataCenter 32bit.

Hi, I wish I could help, but I'm not. All I can do is tell you what I'm doing, but the truth is I'm not sure I'm doing the right thing, since the problem keep coming back.  I usually try those solution in that order: 1. Wait for few minutes 2. Restart the instnace 3. Restart the instance again (and again). 4. Stop the instance, detach the EBS volume, create new instance and attach my volume to the new instance (sometime it helps, but it takes time so it can be that the problem just fix itself).  For example, yesterday I was able to RDP to my server but then the RDP session froze. When I disconnect and reconnect it just return to frozen session but disconnect and wait 3 minutes and reconnect again and it all works.  I'm in the same problem as you and I've start look for alternatives to ec2 since it scare me to put production server there and tell me clients "you have to wait an hour or a day because I can't reach you server".  Hope it help, Ido

To Ido,A couple of things:You mention instanceId i-db560ab0 and that you had issues right after you launched it, but that it was reproducible "every time" you connected over RDP.  Are you only experiencing the problem within the first few minutes after starting it?  Are you only trying to connect after the console says "Windows ready to use"?I ask because that instance appears to only be running for about 23 minuntes, and I am wondering if  you realize that, by default, the host reboots itself within a few minutes after a stop/start in order to change its name?  Depending on the software you have running on that host, that could be the heart of the problem with that instance (though you initial problem at the start of the thread may not be related).Also, When your instance stops responding, have you tried connecting over RDP (or http) from another running instance in order to test whether you are having some sort of issue from you particular site to that IP address?  The fact that you don't see any indications of a "crash" in the eventlogs, but everything "freezes" when you connect suggests a few things:1) There is some sort of problem from your location to the instance IP you are trying to connect to2) Some software on your instance is crashing or otherwise distrubing the network stack.Trying to connect to the unresponsive instance from another instance will help at least determine whether there's a problem from your location. Beyond that, you will have to experiement with enabling/disabling Windows 2008 tcp optimizations and see if there is an incompatibility with your application.  Using a network analyzer like Microsoft's NetMon (free) will allow you to monitor networking conditions.  You might also log performance data inside your instance and anaylze it for processes which may be using excessive CPU, etc.  I believe only more detailed forensics will get to the bottom of this.

Hi, First I'm glad to get an official response to this problem.  I didn't try to connect from another instance. I'll do that next time it happen (I'm afraid there will be a next time).  When I wrote the message, it was happen every time. The next day RDP worked but not perfectly. It got stuck and disconnecting and waiting for few minutes seem to resolve the issue.  I don't have anything that should take a lot of memory or CPU but I'll have perf-mon keep track of it.  The thing that scare me the most is that those problem mysteriously appear and mysteriously disappear which led me to believe it's not a problem of my instance. Also there are numerous people all complain about problem related to RDP/SSH problems.  You know you have the best cloud-server-service at the moment. I just wish you'll have closer support (and please don't advice to buy support for price higher than the price of the instances I use).  Thank you very much, Ido.
Hi Ryan,Can you please help me as well. My EC2 Instance is i-1755127c - i am not able to RD to this instance. Could you please help us in sorting this out.Thanks,Newt111

Ido:We appreciate your feedback.  Unfortunately, diagnosing one RDP/SSH connection to the next is not always straightforward as, being both an internet-accessible service and a hosting service which provides no restrictions on the software which you may install on the instance, there are many, many possible culprits to any given connection problem... some detectable only from within the instance, other within an ISP, etc...  Hopefully, some more detailed forensics and maybe application level diagnostics from within the instance can help narrow down the problem.Other things which may help narrow down the issue are to allow your instances to respond to ICMP and attempt various traceroute methods to your instance, and also disable any/all TCP optimizations (including ones which are turned on by default in Windows 2008), as not all applications  may respond well to these in the context of EC2. newt111:Are you still experiencing the problem?  I am able to get a network challenge from various access points when hitting the RDP port on your instance.

Hi Ryan,  Can you please explain how to disable TCP optimizations in Windows 2008? Are there any applications you can suggest to run on my instance to have more information about possible problems?  Thank you, Ido

Hi, The problem has happen again, I cannot RDP into my instance ( i-db560ab0) yet I have HTTP connection to it, although it is very slow.  I've launch another machine and I am able to RDP from the second instance (i-5399b338) into the first using the Private DNS address.  I understand it means that the instance itself is OK and there is a communication problem, can you help me understand what it is?  I did not change the security group.  Thank you, Ido.

Firstly, if you have both instances set up to allow them to respond to pings, you should do a traceroute to both hosts to help you determine whether there is some high-level routing issue between your client and 2 instances.  Compare the output, which should be very similar, to try to deduce whether your ISP is at fault, or some hop along the way.  This often not conclusive, but a good place to start.You should also use 'netstat' to determine whether there is a socket in a wait state from the source address/port from which you were trying to connect (also noting whether your client appears to connect from the same IP and Port every time).  On the instance having the issues, you should use a tool like Microsoft's NetMon to analyze the RDP traffic coming in from your client.  Do you see any packets on TCP port 3389 coming from your source IP when you try to connect?  What is occuring?  Using the same tool on your client, do you evidence of a TCP conversation, or is it going into a black hole?

Using Spot Instance 24/7? Will this work? Is it allowed? Hi all,  Just started seriously considering an EC2 Micro instance for some low traffic web stuff (like my blog, and some mobile games high score apps).  I was reading about Spot Instances, and wondered whether or not it's possible to save some cash by using them, with a fairly high bid. It seems likely that over a year, the average spot price would be below the on-demand price.  So, if I set a bid of slightly higher than the on-demand price, is there any reason my spot instance wouldn't run 24/7, but cost me a lot less?  I understand there are a few things that might cause my instance to be terminated (others bidding higher, resources taken by non-spot instances, spot price increasing), but I can live with a little downtime (or having to boot an on-demand instance) now and then.  Is there a flaw in this plan?  I've seen that some spot prices are already higher than on-demand prices, but in general, this doesn't appear to be the case (and I don't understand how spot instances would be useful if this became the norm).

Linux official ami-827540f6 rebundle problem I try to rebundle the ami-827540f6 to have my own one, and I get errorsI have triedsudo ec2-bundle-vol -d /mnt/ami -k /mnt/pk.pem -c /mnt/cert.pem -u XXX -p cent_os_55_base_2010-09-27I have the following error : sudo: ec2-bundle-vol: command not foundI have tried withsudo ruby /opt/aws/amitools/ec2/lib/ec2/amitools/bundlevol.rb -d /mnt/ami -k /mnt/pk.pem -c /mnt/cert.pem -u XXX -p cent_os_55_base_2010-09-27I have the following error : /opt/aws/amitools/ec2/lib/ec2/amitools/bundlevol.rb:11:in `require': no such file to load -- ec2/amitools/bundle (LoadError)        from /opt/aws/amitools/ec2/lib/ec2/amitools/bundlevol.rb:11What am I doing wrong ?Thanks you very much for your help.Joel

I found a solution to my problem which path and access right related...sudo /usr/local/bin/ec2-bundle-vol -d /mnt/ami -k /home/ec2-user/pk-XXX.pem -c /home/ec2-user/cert-XXX.pem -u XXX -p cent_os_55_base_2010-09-28sudo /usr/local/bin/ec2-bundle-instance -d /mnt/ami -k /home/ec2-user/pk-XXX.pem -c /home/ec2-user/cert-XXX.pem -u XXX -p cent_os_55_base_2010-09-28Using the two previous command I was able to rubundle the AMI as an S3 based instance.I am looking for information on how to have an EBS based instance to be alble to run as micro instance Joel

limits on ebs volumes how can i tell how many more ebs volumes I can create?  I tried to create one and it said i'm out of space.

Hi gamestreamer,As it looks like you're running in to your aggregate EBS volume size limits for a region, you can fill out the following form to request that they be increased:https://aws.amazon.com/contact-us/ebs_volume_limit_request/This will submit your request to the appropriate team for review and processing. If you know an estimated number of volumes you'll need along with how much aggregated space you'll need, you'll want to include these figures in your request. I hope this helps!Best Regards, Scott

Let me know if those help.

The config looks fine, short of those suggestions, which you just tested. Can you provide the output of:drbdadm --version I also noticed that you're using DRBD 8.3, any chance you could upgrade that to 8.3.8.1? What distro are you running on these boxes?
Version: 8.3 *(SRC) I am running Debian on these boxes. Lenny 5.X  (drbdadm --version is not a valid command.)  Message was edited by: 0bfuscated00
Thats telling.  Looks like the userland utilities didn't get installed drbdadm is a part of that package. Install those and that should fix the problem.
So you're telling me that by reinstalling the src, I can flag the userland utils, and re make the src? And it will work...
Version is:   Version: 8.0.14 (api:86)

There are 2 parts to DRBD, the kernel module, of which from what I can tell, you're running 8.3.0 and the DRBD userland utilities.  These versions need to match in order for things to work properly. So you should either install the utils from your 8.3.0 src or download and use the latest 8.3.8.1 src.

You're connected now.  Now run this on the primary: 
drbdadm -- --overwrite-data-of-peer primary r0
where r0 is your resource name. Or if you want to skip the initial sync because they are both blank:
drbdadm -- --clear-bitmap new-current-uuid r0where r0 is your resource name. Once that is done you can promote one of the nodes to primary:drbdadm primary r0Not sure whats going on with this pre stuff... but you get the idea.

Run New Instance in us-west-1 or eu-west-1 .Net SDK I have successfully created a web application using the .Net SDK to provision and manage new instances in the us-east region. However, I can't find a way to specify the availability zone (within us-east) or even the region.I have attempted to change the service URL, which even though the application still works, the resulting instances are still created in the us-east region. When I try to use an AMI from eu or us-west, I get an error stating that the ami does not exist. In the documentation there is a reference to 'endpoint', but I don't see anyplace to specify the endpoint in the SDK. Thanks in advance for any direction to help me figure this out!

Finally found the answer in the documentation. In case there are others stuck on this subject, below is the text (copied from this page: http://developer.amazonwebservices.com/connect/entry.jspa?externalID=3051 )-------->>>>>>

Making Requests to a Different Region

To make the service call to a different region, instantiate the client with the configuration object, and pass the region-specific endpoint. For example:
AmazonEC2 ec2 = AWSClientFactory.CreateAmazonEC2Client(      appConfig["AWSAccessKey"],      appConfig["AWSSecretKey"],      new AmazonEC2Config().WithServiceURL("https://eu-west-1.ec2.amazonaws.com")      ); DescribeInstancesRequest ec2Request = new DescribeInstancesRequest();
See the Developer Guide for each service for a list of region endpoints.

Unreliable Service: Four Failed Instances I've managed to break four instances over the past couple weeks and I have absolutely no idea how. Once the instances fail no connections can be established, Remote Desktop, HTTP and HTTPS connection requests all fail and I am absolutely blind to what is going in. The System Logs report nothing useful and the status of my instance remains as "Running". I've asked for help on these forums in another thread but so far I've been given no useful information.  This last time I tried creating and setting up an instance step by step so I could determine the issue. After making some changes several days ago I double checked that I could establish a remote desktop connection. As it was successful I went ahead and created an AMI from the instance... now it's dead and I can't establish a remote desktop connection. Something about the bundling process broke my instance. The ID is: i-61684e0b  I run a few physical servers in my local area and I have another instance running that I created over a year ago that's running fine. I am not causing these issues. Something is wrong on Amazon's end and I'm tried of trying to figure out what it is. I am seriously considering switching to another provider that can give me better support and doesn't want me to pay them $100 so they can resolve an issue with their system.

I've managed to break four instances over the past couple weeks and I have absolutely no idea how.  I am not causing these issues.  Those seem like contradictory statements.  Sorry you're having trouble but we've been running a number of machines for over a year with only one failure that was Amazon's fault.

The instance I created well over a year ago using a Windows 2003 image is working fine too. But any new instances I create inevitably crash.  What I meant to say is that I am not doing anything that _should_ cause these instances to crash and since I'm blind once it happens there's little I can do to diagnose the problem any further.  I just explained what killed the last instance. Everything was running fine, I bundled the instance and now it's dead. What would you suggest I do now?

Ah, I don't have much (well, any) experience with Windows on EC2, only Linux. Are you using the S3/instance-store AMIs? If so, maybe you could try using an EBS-backed AMI instead. This way you could snapshot it regularly, and even after the crash, then attach that volume elsewhere for a postmortem.
It is EBS and that's exactly what I tried to do and exactly what caused the issue.

I had the same problems as you.  Two things I found that were causing problems was applying the latest service pack for SQL Express 2008 and assigning an SSL certificate to a website.  Both issues took a while to diagnose and someone else posted the solution to the SSL problem.  I agree that these were both not activities that would have cause any problems on a standard windows install but did on EC2.
Yes! I'm assigning an SSL cert to my website. Thank you for the info!

To anyone experiencing the same issue I believe this is the thread jimmy is referring to. I haven't tried it yet but I'm hopeful.   http://developer.amazonwebservices.com/connect/thread.jspa?messageID=168471&#168471

For the record dafaleiting your condescending tone was completely unnecessary and unappreciated. Turns out I was right. I wasn't doing anything wrong:  http://developer.amazonwebservices.com/connect/thread.jspa?messageID=196205&#196205  If you don't have anything constructive to post in the future I'd recommend not posting at all.

Instance became unresponsive, not rebooting, and now hangs trying to stop We have a "t1.micro" instance "i-634a7009" which became unresponsive some time today. When we noticed it, we tried to reboot it. The reboot command took only a couple of seconds to execute, which was suspiciously quick, and as we suspected, the reboot did not make the instance responsive again. We resorted to stopping the instance, and after issuing the stop command, the instance just hangs in the stopping status for about an hour now. It seems a similar issue also had happened to another person who also posted before us. We need to take down and bring the instance back asap. Thanks.

Machines in same zone cannot communicate Right now we're running into an issue with machine communication, and I'm hoping someone can help us out.  We have two Solaris boxes running MySQL and a Windows Server 2008 box running application code.  All three of these boxes are in the same zone, and based on my understanding should be able to communicate. Communication between the Solaris boxes is fine, however the Windows box can't seem to reach the Solaris boxes, be it through a MySQL connection or even a ping.  I was under the impression that if the machines were in the same zone, this would not be an issue, however thatdoes not seem to be true.  For what it's worth, I am able to SSH to the Solaris boxes from the Windows box so I have a temporary solution, however this is not practical as the application grows.  Does have any ideas as to why thesemachines cannot communicate without SSH if they are in the same zone?
Check your security group settings.

Difficulty of finding an EBS based AMI with Java+Tomcat I've just finished setting up a Tomcat server on EC2.  I found remarkably difficult to obtain an appropriate AMI.  I thought I'd describe my experience here, in case it's useful for others and/or someone can suggest a better approach.  First there is the question of whether to use an EBS or S3 based machine image.  I want to use EBS, for two reasons.  First, I can modify the filesystem and expect my changes to survive a machine failure.  Second, http://docs.amazonwebservices.com/AWSEC2/latest/DeveloperGuide/index.html?ComponentsAMIs.html lists a number of benefits for EBS images, such as faster boot time and the ability to switch to a different instance type.  However, there are relatively few EBS-based AMIs available.  Amazon provides ami-84db39ed (fedora-8-i386-v1.14-std) and ami-86db39ef (amazon/fedora-8-x86_64-v1.14-std), but these are based on Fedora 8 which is two and half years old.  They are also very minimalist -- they don't include Java, let alone Tomcat.  Using the AWS console to browse other images seems hopeless, as the console provides virtually no information about the images.  And I haven't found many useful pointers to specific AMIs on the web.  This is compounded by the fact that, for security reasons, I'm very reluctant to use an AMI that's not provided by Amazon.  I found a few threads on converting an S3 AMI to an EBS AMI, e.g.:  http://developer.amazonwebservices.com/connect/thread.jspa?messageID=156552&#156552 http://developer.amazonwebservices.com/connect/thread.jspa?messageID=156323&#156323  But it sounds cumbersome.  And even with S3 AMIs, finding a good starting AMI still seems difficult.  For instance, http://ttlnews.blogspot.com/2009/01/setting-up-amazon-ami-with-java-and.html identifies an AMI with Java, but it is based on "the publicly available Java Web Starter AMI" (http://developer.amazonwebservices.com/connect/entry.jspa?externalID=1993&categoryID=101), which seems to be over two years old (the linked page lists no updates after "2008-01-08: Initial release").  And based on the comments on that blog posting, it seems to have some issues -- e.g. "The 1.7 version of java has issues loading keys from a keystore. This functionality is necessary for configuring tomcat to run with https.  The only solution that I have found for this problem, so far, is to replace java 1.7 with a sun version of the jdk (1.6)."  I finally started with ami-84db39ed and installed Java and Tomcat manually.  It took me several hours of searching to figure out how to install Java -- the web is full of instructions which don't work on Fedora, or are otherwise inapplicable.  Eventually I found http://alwajdi.blogspot.com/2007/12/how-to-install-snns-jdk-in-fedora-8.html, which worked after downloading a JDK RPM from http://download.java.net/jdk6/.  In summary, my question is: how does one identify an AMI which is trustworthy, appropriate to one's task, and reasonably recent?  If anyone is interested, I can write up a HOWTO detailing the process by which I set up an EBS-based EC2 instance with Java and Tomcat, and installed my application on it.

Steve,You can find recent and community tested Ubuntu  AMI's at http://www.alestic.com Eric and the rest of  ec2-ubuntu google group have the great support too.  For converting instance store to EBS AMI,this might be helpful also: http://www.capsunlock.net/2009/12/create-ebs-boot-ami.htmlCheers,Rodney http://www.capsunlock.net

Steve,You said:| In summary, my question is: how does one identify | an AMI which is trustworthy, appropriate to one's| task, and reasonably recent?Very good question!  I agree that the set of existing AMI's is very hard to search.  I'm currently looking for an official Amazon (or otherwise trustworthy) EBS-based CentOS AMI.  How to search?  The best I've seen is to choose "EBS Instances" from the "Viewing" drop down list while choosing an AMI in the "Request Instances Wizard" of the AWS Console, and then click the "Platform" column header to sort by platform, so that Cent OS comes to the top.  That shows 5 of them:   ami-1d10fd74   ami-59739e30   ami-6b608c02   ami-75b8571c   ami-77b8571ebut how do I learn details of each of these to choose among them?  You also said:| If anyone is interested, I can write up a HOWTO| detailing the process by which I set up an EBS-based| EC2 instance with Java and Tomcat, and installed | my application on it.        Yes, please.  Meanwhile, you and others can view thestep-by-step instructions I've written for the various AWS tasks I've accomplished at:    http://bristle.com/Tips/CloudComputing.htm#awsYou asked how to install Java on a Fedora instance.For me, it was easy, using yum to find and install it.Simply:% yum list installed | grep -i java    - To see that Java was not yet installed.% yum list | grep -i java | grep -i -v javadoc    - To see what was available, skipping the javadoc stuff% yum info "*java-1.7*"    - To learn more about those that seemed promising% yum -v install java-1.7.0-icedtea    - To install the Java 1.7 runtime% yum -v install java-1.7.0-icedtea-devel    - To install the Java 1.7 compiler and tools Hope this helps!--Fred Stluka

Rodney -- thanks for the pointers.  I'll check out alestic if/when it's time to move on from the Fedora 8 setup I've managed to get working.  Fred -- I like how you're compiling instructions, that looks like a nice resource.   I can't quite remember why "yum" didn't work out for me.  I think I'd decided that Java 1.7 was too cutting edge for my taste; for instance, see the comment regarding keystore in my initial posting on this thread.  That yum command you supply doesn't list a Java 1.6 package.  I've now published my Java+Tomcat setup instructions here:  http://sites.google.com/site/amistrongeryet/setting-up-java-tomcat-on-ec2  I believe this page should be publicly viewable; if not, let me know.
Steve,Yes, the page is viewable.  Good stuff!  Thanks!--Fred

Was successful creating a live snapshot from my existing vmware(ubuntu) based instance using ec2-bundle-vol command - documentation at http://code.google.com/p/xenia/wiki/VMwareInstall#Amazon_Web_Services

Come across this explanation from http://ja.pastebin.ca/1502048 -B, --block-device-mapping MAPS  Default block-device-mapping scheme to launch the AMI with. This scheme defines how block devices may be exposed to an EC2 instance of this AMI if the instance-type of the instance is entitled to the specified device. The scheme is a comma-separated list of key=value pairs, where each key is a "virtual-name" and each value, the corresponding native device name desired. Possible virtual-names are:- "ami": denotes the root file system device, as seen by the instance.- "root": denotes the root file system device, as seen by the kernel.- "swap": denotes the swap device, if present.- "ephemeralN": denotes Nth ephemeral store; N is a non-negative integer.Note that the contents of the AMI form the root file system. Samples of block-device-mappings are:- "ami=sda1,root=/dev/sda1,ephemeral0=sda2,swap=sda3"- "ami=0,root=/dev/dsk/c0d0s0,ephemeral0=1"

We've added more information about block device mapping to the EC2 documentation. Conceptual information about Amazon EBS-backed AMIs:http://docs.amazonwebservices.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/index.html?Concepts_BootFromEBS.htmlConceptual information about block device mapping:http://docs.amazonwebservices.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/index.html?block-device-mapping-concepts.htmlProcedures for using Amazon EBS-backed AMIs and block device mapping:http://docs.amazonwebservices.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/index.html?Using_BootFromEBS.htmlThank you for your patience as we made this new information available.

Hello AWS customer support team! Aren't you supposed to check this forum from time to time.  A part of our production system lost, thousands of dollars damage from loss of data and downtime, but it looks like basic support == no_support!!!  What happened to our instance? We need to get some critical data out of there!

Hi thereThank you for the forum post. I have looked into your configuration and can confirm that your instance has encountered a file system error. The issue here is that as you have selected an "instance-store" image, there is no way for you to detach your root volume, and attach it to a new instance to run the fsck through to completion.I would recommend that you terminate this instance, and launch a new instance which uses EBS volumes for its' root device. This will allow you to take regular snapshots of your data and configuration, and also in the event of a filesystem problem such as this, you will be able to detach the volume, and attach to another instance to run maintenance. I'm sorry that we can't be of more assistance. For future reference, please post the instance ID of the impacted instance, and we will endeavor to assist you as quickly as possible.Best wishes,

multiple IPs for sites with SSL certs Hi,We're considering moving a number of sites over to a single large EC2 instance. Currently we host several sites and we have multiple SSL certs, each of which has its own IP address.I can't seem to figure out how to assign multiple IPs to an instance (and what I have read leads me to believe it is not easily possible).Is there any solution out there? We don't want to pay for multiple instances just to have additional IPs, but each SSL cert requires a unique IP.Thanks

There is no way to assign more than one IP to an instance, however you can use a multiple domain UCC SSL certificate which can be configured to support up to 100 domains in a single certificate.  Or as another option, you can assign each application it's own SSL port, such as 443, 900, 901, etc... (make sure not to use ports that are already reserved, like 445)  Then deploy a elastic load balancer for each individual site, set the load balancer to answer on port 80 and 443, but then deliver the traffic to the corresponding port you have configured for the SSL for that site in question. example HTTPS 443 on load balancer to HTTPS 900 on the instance.

We don't want to pay for multiple instances just to have additional IPs, but each SSL cert requires a unique IP.  Each SSL doesn't really require a unique IP, the limitation is on the web server itself - it doesn't know what SSL certificate to use unless it has some indication outside the SSL-encrypted stream.  Here's an article explaining this and showing you how to set up an ELB-based workaround, as mentioned above:  http://www.shlomoswidler.com/2009/12/use-elb-to-serve-multiple-ssl-domains.html
The previous post is not accurate, as certain older web browsers do not allow the use of name-based virtual hosts over HTTPS. Most noteworthy, IE6.

I'm sorry you've been having problems getting CentOS 5.5 to boot via PV-GRUB. It seems that you're currently using the kernel-PAE kernel package. EC2 Instances - connectivity I am a newbie, and just can't find the information I am looking for.1) I have noticed that my local and public IP addresses get renewed everytime I stop/start the server. Not only that, but my elastic IP address also gets disassociated when the instance stops. This means I need to reassociated it after startup. Is this always the case? How could the elastic IP always be associated with the instance?2) Because my internal IP's change and because of the environment i want to set up, I need some consistency in either an IP or computer name, hence, I wanted to change my Computer Name. This is done and I have also updated the EC2 config file to persist changes. Problem is now I can't connect to my UNC paths on each instance using IP or computer name (after reboot). It seems they can't see each other anymore. I am using the same security group file.Any help on the above is appreciated.CheersRoy

ukroyster wrote:
1) I have noticed that my local and public IP addresses get renewed everytime I stop/start the server. Not only that, but my elastic IP address also gets disassociated when the instance stops. This means I need to reassociated it after startup. Is this always the case? How could the elastic IP always be associated with the instance?
It can't be associate with an instance that is not running. You can put a script in place on the instance that associates the Elastic IP with itself, and set it up to run when the instance starts up.ukroyster wrote:
2) Because my internal IP's change and because of the environment i want to set up, I need some consistency in either an IP or computer name, hence, I wanted to change my Computer Name. This is done and I have also updated the EC2 config file to persist changes. Problem is now I can't connect to my UNC paths on each instance using IP or computer name (after reboot). It seems they can't see each other anymore. I am using the same security group file.
Instead of computer name (which will only really work if you have a Domain Controller - not necessary), use the DNS name of the Elastic IP in your UNC path. Like this:\\ec2-1-2-3-4.amazonaws.com\SooperSeekritShare\file.txtYou *can* use the actual numerical Elastic IP address here, but that will incur a higher charge for traffic, and increase latency, since that traffic will exit and then re-enter EC2. When you use the DNS name of the Elastic IP from within EC2, it resolves to the private IP address of the associated instance.

Hi !!  I've been looking for scripts solving that issue with the Elastic IP automatic attachment, but I was unable to find any ... Could you provide some hints about how to do that? Or maybe point me to the right tutorial on how to get a windows machine attaching to a particular Elastic IP on startup?  Many thanks and best regards!!  David

You can write some code in the language of your choice - python, ruby, Java - that uses any of the EC2 API libraries for that language to attach the Elastic IP to the current instance. You'll hook up this script to run during the boot sequence - that's something Windows-specific, and someone else may be able to help you with that.  You'll need to know the instance-id of the current instance. This can be retrieved by visiting this URL from within the instance: http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/instance-id
Thanks for all your help guys. My problem is solved now. Web Design Brisbane

SSH to Instance Suddenly Failing with ssh_exchange_identification I have an instance I've created. In the process of troubleshooting, I disconnected the SSH connection (using my private key) I'd started at some point this morning and tried to reconnect. I've managed to resolve this. Beyond checking the console log via AWS, if you can connect to the instance another way:* check the logs (/var/log/messages, /var/log/auth.log, /var/log/daemon.log etc) especially after restarting sshd. * make sure /etc/hosts.deny isn't blocking you* add yourself to /etc/hosts.allow to overide hosts.deny* reconfigure sshd on the server to allow PAM connections instead of requiring the key* up the MaxStarts in the sshd_config file (e.g. make sure you're not maxing out SSHD)

How do add more users to an AWS EC2/S3 account? How do add more users to an AWS EC2/S3 account?I've got one account that all the billing is supposed to go against and then I have several sys admins who will be creating and running instances for it. How then can I manage what each person has access to?Eventually, I want a set of developers to create and build their own systems, but not touch the production servers.

What I've learned is that I can share  my AWS Access Key ID, Secret Access Key,X.509 Certificate, and Private Key pair that I generated with the other users needing access.Has anyone tried this? Does this allow for granting permission to individual users? Or is this giving them complete control?

One account is one account. I hope that isn't overstating things. You can't make sub-accounts. If you share your credentials, they get access to everything you have.There are ACL mechanisms in place for S3 and EC2 because if you need access controls, you create separate accounts and grant permissions as needed.David

If you use RightScale to manage your servers you can create multiple user logins for one account and the web interface keeps audit records of who does what. The developer account is free and supports this.Thorsten - www.rightscale.com
Thorston,Can you limit permissions per user?
you can restrict a user to "view only", and you can restrict a user to only see his/her instances. if you have specific ideas on what you'd like to limtit, I'd be interested in hearing.Thorsten
Has anyone heard anything from Amazon regarding this topic?  We're looking for sub-accounts to assist with usage tracking, not merely ACL, which appears to be unreportable in AWS.

Have you taken a look at the [Beta] Identity & Access Management (IAM) features?"AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) enables you to create multiple Users and manage the permissions for eachof these Users within your AWS Account. A User is an identity (within your AWS Account) with unique security credentials that can be used to access AWS Services. IAM eliminates the need to share passwords or access keys, and makes it easyto enable or disable a User’s access as appropriate. IAMoffers you greater flexibility, control and security when using AWS."
