I can confirm that this doesn't work.I tried to do it with the raw API and get slightly more descriptive errors.http://ec2.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/?Action=ModifyInstanceAttribute&Attribute=blockDeviceMapping&AWSAccessKeyId=MY_KEY_HERE&InstanceId=i-xxxxxxx&SignatureVersion=1&Timestamp=2010-08-30T21%3A02%3A28Z&Value=%2Fdev%2Fsdc%3Dephemeral1&Version=2010-06-15&Signature=AH698xX9FpbJQF%2FNBPXyapiUjtM%3D&(certain values obscured to protect my privacy)results in:InvalidParameterCombinationNo attributes specified.bec35ea6-ed9a-4ae4-a5ab-38955369a796
Is there a correct way to add these ephemeral stores to the instance then?

As far as I can tell there is no way to add ephemeral store to a running instance, even though the documentation claims there is.  Hopefully some AWS employee can take a look at this thread and comment.Meanwhile if you need to make this work right now, you would have to start a new instance.  If your instance is EBS backed you could take a snapshot and not lose any data at least.

Hi,Our documentation for mapping ephemeral storage describes doing so at run time:http://docs.amazonwebservices.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/Using_OverridingAMIBDM.htmland the documentation for what can be modified on a stopped instance does not include ephemeral volume mapping:http://docs.amazonwebservices.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/Using_ChangingAttributesWhileInstanceStopped.htmlTo my knowledge this is not supported, and I suspect that this is the reason that you are seeing this error message.  If you need to add storage to a running instance, I recommend that you provision additional EBS volumes; else you can create an AMI based on your instance, and launch a replacement from that AMI with a new block device mapping that addresses your ephemeral storage:http://docs.amazonwebservices.com/AWSEC2/latest/CommandLineReference/ApiReference-cmd-RunInstances.htmlHope this helps!-Jason

If this isn't supported, perhaps the documentation for the ModifyInstanceAttribute API call could specify that.  Even better would be if the API returned a sensible message. ("Can't add ephemeral storage to an instance after it is created.")http://docs.amazonwebservices.com/AWSEC2/latest/APIReference/ApiReference-query-ModifyInstanceAttribute.htmlIt just says you can modify the blockDeviceMapping.  It doesn't say whether that needs to be done on a running or stopped instance (the correct answer is running - you get a message from the API saying it has to be running if you try to do it when it's stopped).  It doesn't say that it only supports changing EBS mappings.  (If that is even true - I haven't tried adding or removing EBS devices to a running instance with this API call).
Hi J. Drukman,Thanks for the feedback; I've passed your comments to the EC2 Documentation team to see if we can clarify this point better in the future.-Jason

I'm having the same problem, and I don't think this is a matter of documentation.  We're getting:  Server.InternalError: An internal error has occurred  That's not a "this isn't supported" type of error message, no?  Also, there are numerous FAQs on the internet showing this as working.  Given the previous reports of it working, the nature of the error message and the recent nature of these issues, I suspect that this was recently broken.  This is the only affordable way to get an ephemeral swap volume on an EBS-root instance.  That makes this fairly serious IMHO.

Is it necessary to stop EC2 instance to create an AMI? Hi,  I have a Windows EC2 Instance that boots from an EBS volume. The instance has Internet Information Services and SQL Server Express 2008 installed. In the AWS Management Console there's an option that says Create Image (EBS AMI).   If I use the Create Image (EBS AMI) option while the instance is running will I get a corrupted AMI? Or is it safe to use that option when the instance is running?  Also, what is the recommended way to backup Windows EC2 instances? Is it recommended to create a new image (EBS AMI) or is it better to take a snapshot of the EBS volume attached to the instance?  Thanks
If you select the "Create Image (EBS AMI)" option on a running instance, EC2 will reboot the instance in order to make a consistent AMI.

When is a new instance added to loadbalancer as "in service"? Hi,I have a setup where I use elastic load balancing and auto scaling for a web frontend.What is the instance health, as seen by the load balancer, when auto scaling adds a new instance to the load balancer?My concern is that my frontend is quite slow at booting up, so I would like the instance to be "out of service" from the beginning and only get "in service" (and therefore receive requests from the load balancer) whenever the web server is ready.How should I configure the health check to get this behaviour?Best regards,Christian

UNfortunately there is a bug in ELB that it assumes a newly-added instance is healthy until it fails the health check.  The workaround is to configure your health check to happen frequently enough that it minimizes the time the instance is in the load balancing pool before it's ready.
Do you know what the timeframe for this bug being fixed is?

Instead of using autoscaling. Use the Cloudwatch directly and launch instances and add them to the loadbalancer through your 24x7 program till the bug gets fixed.  Aditya Yadav Partner, Aditya Yadav & Associates Author: Amazon Cloud Computing with C#/.Net Author: Amazon Cloud Computing with Java http://adityayadav.com/books.aspx
Any news on this issue? Has the bug been fixed?
Not yet. It's still listed in the ELB Release Notes:  http://developer.amazonwebservices.com/connect/entry.jspa?externalID=3766&categoryID=86

We are happy to report that this bug has been fixed recently. Now when a new instance is added to the load balancer via auto scaling the new instance will start off as "unhealthy" and transition to healthy only on the first successful ping.We will update the ELB release notes shortly.

Subra,  Can you please clarify two things:  when a new instance is added to the load balancer via auto scaling  Does this apply only to instances added via auto-scaling - and instances added to an ELB by the ELB API will still initially show up as Healthy? Or will the instance now show up as UnHealthy at first, regardless of how it was added to the ELB?  and transition to healthy only on the first successful ping  Do you mean "first successful health check"?

> Does this apply only to instances added via auto-scaling - andinstances added to an ELB by the ELB API will still initially show upas Healthy? Or will the instance now show up as UnHealthy at first,regardless of how it was added to the ELB?The latter. Regardless of how the new instance is added, it will show up as unhealthy first, and transition to healthy state on the first successful health check.> Do you mean "first successful health check"?Yes. Thank you for pointing that out.

Doubts about OpenVPN and IPv6 So, I was trying to configure a simple "test" OpenVPN network from a workstation (my, personal) to an instance.Even though I'm just an amateur on this, I was testing this aiming to use an AWS instance as a server to my own business ERP-like software, so I could have just simple workstations connected to the internet, each of them connected directly to the instance, in a multi-client / single server network.As I tried to start the server OpenVPN in the instance, it succeeded, but gave the following message: "Need IPv6 code in mroute_extract_addr_from_packet". I was not able to complete the connection from the workstation (even using the elastic IP).Do anybody know if it's actually possible to run the OpenVPN in an instance on that basis? If it is, how do I avoid the connectivity problems I am having?Thanks!

Thanks, NOBODY!I found my solution on my own. That's not easy to an amateur on IT issues (actually, I'm an insurance broker).Just found out that OpenVPN version 2.2, a beta, suports IPv6 and AWS doesn't. I don't know if that error log asking for IPv6 support would even prevent OpenVPN from working. However, that s*** was as error in my log files and my software wasn't working, so I just had to discard that.Ok, version 2.1 installed, and then I had a lot of TLS Handshake problems. Again, nobody in the whole internet was offering a simple and straight solution, just everybody asking the same question about this. Hmmm... I found out that the problem was just that OpenVPN folks mislead everyboy in their "HowTo"s and Examples. Their client config file simple example, included in their "HowTo" simples setup, has a configuration line that asks for a special kind of server authentication certificate, which a certificate created by their "easy-rsa" solution (also step-by-step in their "HowTo") would fail to comply. That line is "remote-cert-tls server". One solution is to disable that line (just ";" before it). I sugest reading the following:http://www.dd-wrt.com/forum/viewtopic.php?t=52145&sid=b95a2fb57dbb4db386c7c722e8a553c6(where I found that solution)http://www.openvpn.net/index.php/open-source/documentation/manuals/69-openvpn-21.html(That config line is listed in their manual - just in the 2.1 version of manual, not in the others - I don't know why).Other solution, that I couldn't test successfully, is this:http://openvpn.net/archive/openvpn-devel/2006-11/msg00024.htmlI don't know exactly what are these config lines of the second solution about, but they are suggestions (from that guy, not me) to correct the "easy-rsa" bug, so that when you follow the "step-by-step" setup of their "how-to" you would succeed to create a network connection. Message was edited by: ehell45

Ow, and I forgot.Windows Vista Users:OpenVPN Installer will install the software inside the "Program Files" folder. That means that every file change has to be accepted many times in those windows pop-ups. Ok, so?So that OpenVPN works on command lines that do not open those pop-ups. It won't write the log files and easy-rsa won't work there (prompt commands that create new files inside the Program Files folder). I just made all the tests elsewhere.

Volumes not showing up in /dev I've created a new instance of the Amazon Linux AMI and I am attempting to attach one of my EBS volumes as /dev/sdh.     The volume reports as attached in the Management Console, but there is no dev/sdh on the instance.   I thought it might be a timing issue, but it has not shown up in over 20 minutes.Is there another service I must run to recognize new devices?  The Amazon Linux instance is pretty lean.
SOLVED.   I discovered that the device was being listed on the server as /dev/xdh rather than /dev/sdh as I had specified while attaching the volume.  I'm not sure why this is.
Please see http://developer.amazonwebservices.com/connect/thread.jspa?messageID=194798 for discussion on this.

Windows licensing issues After a few months my instance states that "This copy of Windows is not genuine", have followed the procedures published at  http://developer.amazonwebservices.com/connect/message.jspa?messageID=185874#185874   and my instance just complains it cannot access the Key Management Service.  It is at us-east-1 region.  Thanks,  Samuel Castro

Just to note I found the  solution.  The procedure as published were not working as the proposed DNS name were resolving to 174.129.233.152.  From another (linux) instance in the same zone I queried the DNS record and got 10.246.15.111 address. I used that new address and worked like a charm !!  The reason of the whole problem is that we were using DIFFERENT DNS servers, not the AWS provided so we were getting the external address for the license manager instead of the internal one.  Samuel Castro

Micro Ubuntu Stopped Responding Hi,  I'm hoping an Amazon tech can look into this:  I ssh'd into i-8f3108e5 earlier this evening and noticed Ubuntu's *** System restart required *** message, so I ran "sudo reboot"  The instance is reported as "Running" in the AWS Console, but further attempts to reconnect via ssh report "ssh: connect to host ec2-184-73-195-249.compute-1.amazonaws.com port 22: Connection refused"  Also, the "Get System Log" is reporting nothing, just a blank / black screen.

We're seeing the same thing with micro Windows instances.  They create, but nothing appears in the log.  In a few case we've had to destroy then recreate.  Sometimes we see the problem when simply rebooting.

Hi interlinkone Our control plane shows that your instance is stuck in a continuous resurrect/crash cycle (we will try to re-launch your instance until you ec2-terminate it).  It is likely crashing as a result of an upgrade gone bad - assuming you did a upgrade due to the “*** System restart required***” message.  It is very little we can do about this.   If you had valuable data on the instance you could attach the root volume to another instance to copy this off.Hi mogotestYou are likely seeing a different issue. Please look at the beneath thread for an explanation. If you feel that this is not addressing your issue please post the id of an instance that have shown the behavior you are outlining and we will take a closer look.http://developer.amazonwebservices.com/connect/thread.jspa?threadID=51280&start=15&tstart=0 Cheers,Atle Message was edited by: Atle@AWS

I had the same problem, rebooted the linux micro instance and nothing happened, the System log shows that the machine is ok, so i thought it was a network issue, stopping and starting over would fix.  Now my instance is trying to stop but it is stuck.   I created a snapshot of the volume and lanched a new instance, this one i changed the root drive for the volume created from the snapshot and now it's ok.

Hi,  I believe it's related to the following bug in the Ubuntu cloud-init package: https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/cloud-init/+bug/634102  There is a (temporary) fix for the bug on the above website.

HI all,  We found the same workaround and it appears to work: https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/cloud-init/+bug/634102  Running the following:  1)  "$(uname -m)" = "x86_64" ] && ephd=/dev/sdb || ephd=/dev/sda2 2) sudo sed -i.dist "\,${ephd},s,^,#," /etc/fstab  allows us to reboot a Micro Ubuntu 10.04 instance (we're using AMI ami-1234de7b from Canonical)  Thanks!

HELP: problem accessing Amazon EC2 tomcat instance's DNS Hi EC2 gurus,  I'm having trouble accessing an EC2 instance and associated Java webapp running in tomcat via HTTP.  I have read the forums already and I listed what I tried below.  Please see the PROBLEM and BACKGROUND sections for details.  If you need anymore information, please don't hesitate to let me know.  Also, the DNS below has been left running.  Thanks. Bob  PROBLEM: Cannot access published Java webapp at: http://ec2-174-129-69-27.compute-1.amazonaws.com:8080/HelloEC2World/  I am trying to do Java webapp development on EC2 using the latest AWS toolkit for Eclipse.  I have successfully created my EC2 and S3 accounts.  And, I am able to successfully create an EC2 Tomcat server instance - which shows up fine in the AWS management console web app.  I have tried explicitly creating my own Security Group and adding permissions for port 8080, but it won't resolve in either Eclipse's browser of Chrome or IE.  BACKGROUND: I am new to EC2 and the related technologies, so I hope this is just lack of knowledge on my part.   My dev environment is:  * 64-bit Server 2008 R2  64-bit Eclipse Helios 64-bit java JDK

UPDATE: AM I MISSING SOMETHING???  i installed PuTTY on my Server 2008 dev box and connected to the running instance.  I can't seem to find the running tomcat instance, nor anything listening on port 8080 - even though the tomcat configuration in eclipse clearly says it's configured for http on 8080.  So, how can I tell if tomcat is even installed on this Amazon EC2 Tomcat AMI?  UPDATE 2: it's been about 15 years since I've had to use UNIX command line tools.  after running 'find | grep tomcat' I found where tomcat is installed.  Now, I just have to find out how to tell if it's running and how to get access to it via my local browser.  Message was edited by: robertderemer

MORE INFORMATION:  after having flashbacks to my early UNIX days and somehow miraculously remembering how to us VI, I started digging into the tomcat 6 installation, along with the JDK installation.  I'm not sure what the problem is, but it appears that either the tomcat installation, the jdk, or both are not properly installed.  I know this because examining the tomcat logs shows why tomcat isn't running - there are exceptions at startup and the last one is a ClassNotFoundException: org.apache.catalina.core.JreMemoryLeakPreventionListener  ANY SUGGESTIONS?  Do I need to create my own AMI or is there a way to get a new EC2 Tomcat instance to try?  I'd really like to know what the root of the problem is, so I can avoid this in the future.  Thanks in advance!!! Bob

The Ubuntu AMIs are a great starting point.  http://uec-images.ubuntu.com/releases/lucid/release/  After booting and logging in as "ubuntu",  sudo apt-get update sudo apt-get upgrade sudo apt-get install tomcat6  You'll probably need to re-familiarize youself with linux if it's been 15 years. I went through a similar re-learning 2 years ago after not using linux since about 1998. It just takes some time.

Thanks for the suggestion!  I kept reading/learning this morning and am in the process of creating a Server2008 EBS-Backed AMI right now - it was just quicker since I've been doing Windows Server since 3.51.    I will create an Ubuntu EBS-backed AMI once I get this one going, though.  regards, Bob

How to Sync Instances Hi, I want to create more than 1 instances EC2, 1 acts as the base and the other as mirrors..For example, I created 2 instances in Singapore and US, whenever I update the data or the sql database in Singapore, I want my instance in the US to be updated as well..Is this possible? if yes then how?

That depends a lot on what database you want to use, whether the mirrors have to be available for read or write queries, whether you need ACID transactions, etc, etc.  It's not a simple problem, I can tell you that.

I did some R&D and observed that if I use default group and launch US version AMI I am able to login via putty but not able to login with my private group.  I now tried with another AMI of EU region(ami-807540f4 ) and I could ssh with my group too.  Now my problem is I am not able to mount the EBS.  I do not see any drive under /dev/ folder like /dev/sda .. /dev/sdx. I have logged with ec2-user. I am not able to run extfs / mount command too due to drive not available.  When I launched instance one volume (vol-b43ffddd) is automaticaly attached to drive /dev/sda1 but I am not able to mount any folder to /dev/sda1 as it is not available for ec2-user. Need your help for EBS backup in this scenario.   Thanks, Taral Shah

Hi,I got solution to second point. Since this is EBS backed AMI, it  is different from Instance (S3) backed AMI in a way that, (http://docs.amazonwebservices.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/index.html?ComponentsAMIs.html )I should not mount to any folder like instance based AMI (S3 based).Please refer http://www.theserverlabs.com/blog/2010/07/08/ec2-persistence-strategies/ for more information.This AMI survives stop / start and data is persistent here.Now for problem #1 - I found out that what was exact problem of not letting us do telnet.- Yesterday, when I created the image from running instance as per (http://docs.amazonwebservices.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/index.html?ComponentsAMIs.html ) It stopped my running instance for temporary. By the time new instance created and the old instance comes back to life, I found that telnet was not working and by mistake deleted the new instance.I think from there it started problem and not allowing my group to login to old instance.Thanks,Taral Shah

Elastic DNS? Hi,  Do Amazon have plans for elastic DNS?  What I mean is, I have an elastic IP in each region. US East / West / Europe and AP. How would I go about setting a DNS service to return the nearest region's elastic IP?  Many Thanks, Ady

Nothing like this is offered by AWS.  You may want to do a search for "geo dns" or something similar. Either you've got to run your own dns server with this capability or find a DNS provider that can do it (and those providers are usually quite expensive).
You can use Dyn to make this happen. Please review: http://aicache.com/dcc.html  It is based on Anycast technology.   Drop us a note if you need help. support@aicache.com

ELB instance health history I have a hunch that some of my instances under the Elastic Load Balancer goes in and out of the pool at regular intervals. I cannot see any reason for this as fx. the timeout is rather high - so I was looking into finding a way to see the historical events in the ELB/Cloudwatch system that decides if an instance is available to the load balancer.  I've looked at the ELB API but didn't find anything   Anyone?

ELB support for url based stickiness Is there any way to configure the elastic load balancer to route requests based on hashing the url or some query argument in the url?  I want to build a pool of caching servers and don't want to have to add another layer to re-route requests.

ELB does not support URL-based stickiness, only stickiness based on cookies.  For a detailed explanation of this feature, see my article: http://shlomoswidler.com/2010/04/elastic-load-balancing-with-sticky-sessions.html

This can be done with aiCache.  We call it Origin Server Tagging. The Ami is available here: http://developer.amazonwebservices.com/connect/entry.jspa?externalID=2366  You can read the explanation here: http://aicache.com/pdf/adminguide.pdf Page 87 Middle of page.  More details about the general install and config here: http://wiki.aicache.com  We can walk you through the config if you need. -support
elastic ips billing question helloWhen I stop (stop not terminate) an instance with a elastic ip attached, it's billed at: $0.01 per complete hour ? roberto

http and https on one elb? Is it possible to use one ELB instance to serve both http and https requests for a single domain?  I want http://my.server.com and https://my.server.com to go to the same ELB and the same group of back-end instances.  I know how to configure the back ends to serve both http and https requests, I just can't figure out how to handle the ELB side.

Hi,You can add HTTP and HTTPS forwarding port to one ELB when you create from console.On the AWS Management console, create new load balancer, then you can see the Listener Configuration: part. In the part, default Listener is 80 (HTTP) and you can add custom Listener port (HTTPS) to this configuration.If you use command line tools, you can execute like following:elb-create-lb --listener "lb-port=80, instanceport=, protocol=HTTP"  --listener "lb-port=443, instanceport=, protocol=TCP" I hope this helps you.
You can use aiCache to terminate both on the same instance. Details here: http://wiki.aicache.com -support

SMTP port 25 speed throttling? We're operating a mail server cluster in EC2, which is suffering from serious transmission speed degradation over port 25 when connections originate internationally (e.g. from New Zealand or Australia). This is causing severe delays to larger emails, typically with 5-10MB attachments. We urgently need to reassure our customers that no "packet shaping" or "connection throttling" is happening at the Amazon network, since this issue is causing service cancellations, e.g. after someone emails their boss a critical PowerPoint presentation for the Board Meeting in an hour. Which never arrives. We note that a 1MB file takes 45-60 seconds to transmit into an EC2 instance from NZ via port 22 or 80, but takes 4-5 minutes over SMTP. Someone is messing with TCP/IP connection speed, somewhere... not a Good Thing.Please tell us it ain't so...!

I deleted vol-d9c277b0 just now.  Sorry for the inconvenience.

ELB says my working server is unhealthy, please advise? I am trying to add an ELB to my server, but it keeps saying that the server is unhealthy, although it is healthy and accessible. The server is available http://184.72.46.36/ and I set the path to "/". What URL is the ELB actually pinging? And do I need to setup a special security group on the EC2 instance for the ELB? Why isn't the ping working?thanks,-matt  Message was edited by: votizen
Figured it out. The ELB was pinging from an IP address that the instance was block. Seems like AWS should automatically set up this permission for you.

Can not launch any instances. I am a very new customer to EC2.I am trying to Launch a Micro instance in EU West (Ireland) region.I have setup a EC2 key-pair, the private key is in a folder on my computer.I setup a firewall policy while i was doing this the first time.I have tried it with tags and without (for me i will not need any tagging).I even went so far as to RTFM and followed the tutorial (i am not so new to this that i felt i had to read it until i could not get a single instance to launch).So when i get to the final confirmation screen, i press the Launch button, it changes to "working" with the swirling graphic... i never get to another screen it always stays on the same screen and the button just reverts to Launch again after a couple of seconds.I have tried it in FF 3.6.10 and IE 8, same thing in each browser.I have attached a screen-shot of the instance confirmation page... there are no errors and i followed the very simple tutorial and even went so far as making another new pair and another new simple security group just as the tutorial instructed me. I even tried to make a small instance instead of micro as the tutorial told me to, and i chose the AMI that the tutorial instructed me to.I also attached a screeny of my EC2 Console.Any help anyone can give me on this issue would be very valuable.

Hi thereI have not seen this problem before do you have any personal firwalls or popup blockers that may be effecting the operation of your computers browsers. I would also suggest that if you can try another computer at your end to see if you are still having the same issue.

No personal firewalls or blockers.Different computer, same thing.I feel it has something to do with all the security checks and so forth that were done to my account, i can do everything else in the console, i made a bucket and setup cloudfront to serve from that bucket.I have good fast internet and modern computers,
Seeing as i have no active instances, and no old instances... maybe can you un-enroll me from the EC2 system and then i can subscribe again and maybe that might force this error away.

Hi thereI have checked your account and it all looks ok. This is a technical issue so I would not suggest unsubscribe you account as I feel this may cause billing problems further down the line.The AWS client is heavily dependent of Javascript could you make sure that your systems do not have Antivirus or Security suites effecting how your browsers  execute javascript. If you could do all the basic troubling shooting steps clearing browser cache, clearing out cookies and retry loading the client again.Another suggestion I have is that you start Firefox in Safemode which will stop all plugins and addons when you start it up just to see if  this helps.In windows you can just edit your firefox shortcut on the desktop and after the last " add -safe-modeFailing all of this you could try the ElasticFox which is a add-on client to the Firefox browser for EC2.I have launched an instance in EU-West using the Fedora core 8 32 t1.micro image based of the following ami (ami-df1e35ab) with no issues if you want to try it
Well i tried ElasticFox... It did give me some real information, that your website console refused to give me.See attached screen-shot.Also ElasticFox does not support micro instances,

Hi alanjones2010,I looked into your EC2 access and took action to reset the account.  This does not require any further action on your part but should correct the issue of not being able to launch instances.  Can you confirm if you are still unable to launch instances?Best Regards, Michelle

I can now run an instance.I just wish i had not wasted an entire day when your system could simply have displayed me an error.Considering i was in need of a server on the 11th when i came and now it is the 22nd, pretty sad stuff AWS.

Hi,As part of getting your account in order I am also looking into what can be done to improve the messaging displayed in the console when these rare issues occur.Thanks so much for confirming that you are now up and running.  My sincere apologies for any inconvenience caused.Best Regards, Michelle

How to recover ephemeral RAID-0 after reboot I set up RAID-0 on the sdb and sdc ephemeral drives of a large instance as described in the article below. Upon reboot, the /mnt mountpoint is empty and the array created at /dev/md0 is gone.  My understanding is that ephemeral storage is supposed to survive reboot.  Anyone know how such a RAID array can be made to survive reboot or can be easily re-created after reboot?  http://developer.amazonwebservices.com/connect/entry!default.jspa?categoryID=100&externalID=1074&fromSearchPage=true
Hi markalluvial,You'll need to add an entry to '/etc/fstab' see an example of the whole setup:http://alestic.com/2009/06/ec2-ebs-raidThanks, -Philip
Thank you, Philip. I will give this a try today and keep posted.

Philip, I'm optimistic that /etc/fstab entry is the right way to go, but am still having trouble with reboot.  I tried adding an /etc/fstab entry as suggested on a large instance - complete command sequence below.  Upon reboot, I'm unable to ssh into the machine, giving an 'unable to connect on port 22' error, suggesting that perhaps the machine never rebooted correctly. Any additional help would be appreciated. ----  1. unmount /mnt , rm everything from /mnt directory, remove /dev/sdb listing from /etc/fstab  2. use fdisk to create a 400G partition on both /dev/sdb and /dev/sdc as described in: http://developer.amazonwebservices.com/connect/entry!default.jspa?categoryID=100&externalID=1074&fromSearchPage=true  3. mdadm --create /dev/md0 --chunk=256 --level 0 --raid-devices 2 /dev/sdb /dev/sdc  4. blockdev --setra 65536 /dev/md0  5. mkfs.xfs -f /dev/md0  6. add following entry to /etc/fstab /dev/md0                                       /mnt              xfs    defaults        0       0  as described in: http://alestic.com/2009/06/ec2-ebs-raid  7. mount /mnt
You're probably missing the step  mdadm --detail --scan >> /etc/mdadm.conf  as described in the Linux RAID wiki https://raid.wiki.kernel.org/index.php/RAID_setup#Create_and_mount_filesystem
Thanks, dafaleiting. I will try this tomorrow.
dafaleiting, your suggestion worked.  Thanks to you and Philip for helping me out here.

Does Creating an Image from a Running Instance affect the Instance? Hello,My question is, will the process of creating an AMI from my running instance affect my running instance? i.e. will it hang, shutdown, be slow?I've read some threads around creating images from instances, and I read the tutorial here about creating an image from a running instance:http://docs.amazonwebservices.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/index.html?Tutorial_CreateImage.htmlMy concern is that I want to create an AMI from a production system (with a single ebs-volume as its root volume, no additional attached volumes)  so I can recreate that system in the event my current running instance crashed or took poorly to some patches or something. However, I don't want to try to create an AMI if it is going to affect the current instance. Thoughts? The tutorial doesn't specify if it will affect the running instance or not.

When you create an AMI from an running instance, the instance is stopped for sometime and restarted automatically. Not data is lost and the network identifiers are retained, unlike a user triggered reboot.However, if you had any running processes, they have to be restarted. HTH,nalini

RDP  problem Hi,  I am having problem with the RDP connection. I had just created a new  EC2 instance of windows 2008 64 bit (large) and doing the windows updates. After a restart, I am unable connect back the virtual machine with RDP and the Get System Log is empty. Can someone help please. EC2 Instance: i-b142e6f5

Hi jfong2001,I can't test a connection to port 3389 as you have filtered traffic to it with the Ec2 security group the instance is in. If updates you applied enabled, the Windows firewall may be enabled and filtering your connections. You might add a script to your start-up scripts, before applying the updates, that adds a rule to the Windows firewall allowing connections to port 3389 similar to:CMD> netsh firewall add portopening protocol=TCP port=3389 name="RDP (TCP 3389)" mode=ENABLE scope=SUBNET profile=DOMAINSee this article for more: http://www.windowsecurity.com/articles/Customizing-Windows-Firewall.htmlThanks, -Philip

Hi Philip,  I had tried with another new instance. It happen to me again. Here are the procedures which I did.  1. run the windows update and restart the server after the updates (no problem).  2. install applications (web sever....) 3. manually restart machine.           Shut Down Windows -> Shutdown Event Tracker -> Options: Application:Maintenance (Planned)  -> comment: blank. 4. NOT able to connect to the machine with RDP, no HTTP connection on the system.  It seems to me the instance have been fully turn off and the windows OS is not even started.  1. There is not System Log in the management console, fully empty from Get System Log. 2. Tried to reboot from the management console many times. 3. Tried to connect the instance from another working instance with private IP address. 4. Tired to boot with a snapshot volume that I created before the manual restart.  I also had added the windows startup script below before the manual restart.  netsh firewall add portopening protocol=TCP port=3389 name="RDP (TCP 3389)" mode=ENABLE scope=ALL profile=DOMAIN  EC2 Instance: i-ddf75099 ami-3781d072  Regards, Jonathan  Message was edited by: jfong2001

Hi,Sounds like you'll need to understand what update is breaking this for you or whether your script was successful. You should a) turn on your firewall and block port 3389 and restart (before installing anything else) to test your script. And b) stop the instance that you can't connect to and mount the boot EBS volume elsewhere and see if you can find the cause from the Windows system logs.Thanks, -Philip

Hi,  Here are the interesting bit from windows system event log.  Log Name:      System Source:        Microsoft-Windows-Dhcp-Client Date:          9/20/2010 5:31:38 PM Event ID:      1003 Task Category: None Level:         Warning Keywords:      Classic User:          N/A Computer:      ip-0AA056DF Description: The description for Event ID 1003 from source Microsoft-Windows-Dhcp-Client cannot be found. Either the component that raises this event is not installed on your local computer or the installation is corrupted. You can install or repair the component on the local computer. ELB never does health check I've had trouble setting up an ELB in the AWS management console. I have the ELB instance configured to forward 80 to 80, for my 3, active, selected instances. I've specified the health check as HTTP "/index.html" on port 81.  I can visit all of my instances at port 81, /index.html in a browser and get a 200 OK response. However, the load balancer fails all the health checks. Additionally, looking through the web server logs, the ELB *never* runs the health check! It never shows up in the log! When I visit the page, it works fine, but the ELB doesn't seem to anything except silently fail.   It looks like it's setup correctly, what step did I miss? Do I need to add a firewall rule for it? I figured it would be in the default security group....

Hi,All your instances are marked as healthy and I'm getting a 200 for requests to your ELB. I'm guessing that you were needing to add the 10.0.0.0/8 rule to your instances to allow both your configured health check and requests to port 81 of your instances.Thanks, -Philip
Yep, that was my problem -- I pretty quickly realized that it was a security group setting, but *nowhere* did it say that 10.0.0.0/8 was the block to allow.

Hi,You are correct. In our documentation we specify 0.0.0.0/0 as the range to allow connections from (which is the same range your ELB accepts connections from).We don't guarantee that requests will arrive at your instances from ELB IPs in that 10.0.0.0/8 range but for now, as you've probably observed, they do (though again that could change).Thanks, -Philip

Hi Luke,You should verify that your Tomcat is bound to your public interface (0.0.0.0:8080) instead of to your local interface (127.0.0.1:8080).  Depending on the configuration of your /etc/hosts file, this could cause the behavior that you are seeing.  You can check if you are listening on the public interface by running something like:$ netstat -ln |grep 8080You should also consider the possibility of local firewall rules causing external connections to be denied.Regards,-Jason

Unable to invoke group/port specific firewall rule via AWS Hi there, I am currently trying to use the AuthorizeSecurityGroupIngressSample code (as below) to invoke a firewall rule on my instances that allows traffic from a security group on a certain port only. I am running up instances dynamically with this code and so do not wish to use CIDR instead, this is easy to do with the ec2 shell scripts (eg: ec2-authorize targetGroupName -P protocol -p port -o sourcegroupname -u user) but when trying the same with code I receive this error... Caught Exception: The parameter 'ToPort' may not be used in combination with 'SourceSecurityGroupOwnerId' Response Status Code: 400 Error Code: InvalidParameterCombination Error Type: Unknown InvalidParameterCombinationThe parameter 'ToPort' may not be used in combination with 'SourceSecurityGroupOwnerId My code is as follows AmazonEC2 service = new AmazonEC2Client(accessKeyId, secretAccessKey); AuthorizeSecurityGroupIngressRequest request = new AuthorizeSecurityGroupIngressRequest(); request.withGroupName(targetGroupName); request.withSourceSecurityGroupName(sourceGroupName); request.withSourceSecurityGroupOwnerId(OwnerId); request.withIpProtocol(protocol); request.withToPort(port); AuthorizeSecurityGroupIngressResponse response = service.authorizeSecurityGroupIngress(request);
AFAIK, when you authorize a user-group, you can't restrict it by port or protocol.  In other words, if you drop the -P and -p params from your command, it should work.

I don't believe that is in fact the case, I have a number of firewall rules existing that I have created using that script with -P -p and -o -u parameters but am unable to achieve the same effect from my java code directly using the request.withToPort parameter..   Any ideas how this could be done?

Allen is right.  You can enable individual ports and protocols to specific CIDR ranges but if you enable a group, that group has full access to instances in the other group.  There is currently no way to restrict that access by port or protocol.From the EC2 developer guide:
The access rules define source based access either for named security groups or for IP addresses (i.e., CIDR-based rules). For CIDR-based rules, you can also specify the protocol and port range (or ICMP type/code).
Mitch

Thanks Allen and Mitch for your responses and I appreciate your patience on this.  Given this functionality is working from the shell prompt (i.e. I have a number of current group and port specific firewall rules in place) do we believe that the scripts are not functioning correctly by allowing this capability ?
could you post the output of ec2-describe-group that shows a security group with one of these rules?

I think you are mistaken.  The API simply does not support port-specific rules for groups.  Regardless of what you may think is currently working, you cannot restrict a group rule by specific ports.Mitch

Hi there Mitch / Allen,   Thanks again for your help here. As requested please see the results of my ec2-describe-group which shows the security group Apache-InternallyControlled where 144XXXX is my user name. As you can see below the rules i have created (with -P -p -o -u parameters on my shell script) allow traffic on port TCP:443 (HTTPS) from my OpenVPN Group and TCP:5666 (Nagios monitoring port) from my Nagios Management group.   GROUP	144XXXX	Apache-InternallyControlled	The Controlled Zone of the Apache Reverse Proxy group PERMISSION	144XXXX	Apache-InternallyControlled	ALLOWS	tcp	443	443	FROM	USER	144XXXX	GRPNAME	OpenVPN-Controlled PERMISSION	144XXXX	Apache-InternallyControlled	ALLOWS	tcp	5666	5666	FROM	USER	144XXXX	GRPNAME	Nagios-Management   These rules are definitely active as these systems are currently going through integration testing and passing test cases. Could the API have been updated recently to support this, or is it supported by some other functionality perhaps?

Well, either Amazon has changed this recently and neglected to announce it or update any of the documentation or there is a bug in the command line tools.Have you confirmed that these rules are actually in effect between instances in the two groups?  Can you, in fact, access instances in Apache-InternallyControlled on ports other than 443 and 5666 from instances in the other two groups?It would be great if this were actually working.  It's a feature I have asked for a number of times.  It just seems strange that it would appear suddenly without comment from AWS.Mitch

I'm not sure which but I have definitely used this functionality and the firewall is in place so no you cannot access instances in Apache-InternallyControlled on ports other than 443 and 5666 with our current setup.   I am unable to setup these rules using the Elastifox GUI or with web service calls but for some reason the command prompt allows them...
This would be the appropriate time for AWS to chime in 8^)Mitch
I'd still love to get an answer from AWS on this one.Mitch

Hi Mitch,The confusion here is caused by a subtle difference between the SOAP and Query API's for the AuthorizeSecurityGroupIngress request. While the SOAP API does allow for specific port ranges to be specified when authorizing a user/group pair permission, the Query API does not.See the following paragraph on the AuthorizeSecurityGroupIngress Query API reference (http://docs.amazonwebservices.com/AWSEC2/2009-03-01/DeveloperGuide/index.html?ApiReference-Query-AuthorizeSecurityGroupIngress.html):
When authorizing a user/group pair permission, GroupName, SourceSecurityGroupName and SourceSecurityGroupOwnerId must be specified. When authorizing a CIDR IP permission, GroupName, IpProtocol, FromPort, ToPort and CidrIp must be specified. Mixing these two types of parameters is not allowed.
Since the command-line tools make use of the SOAP API, it is possible to specify  a port range when authorizing a user/group pair permission. Changing your application to use SOAP instead of Query, will also resolve your problem.We are currently working on resolving this inconsistency and will provide further feedback once it has been corrected.Regards,Dave
Thanks.  I did not know that, having never used the SOAP interface.  Consistency between the two API's would certainly be a good thing.  Keep us posted on that.Mitch
We'd also appreciate a prompt resolution of this discrepancy...Thorsten - CTO RightScale

Elasticwulf vs. MPI Hi, What's the main difference between elasticwulf vs MPI vs beowulf? Which one is more suitable for HPC?Thanks,Henry

Hi, their are just different beasts like sweet and tasty:   - MPI is a standardized API to write concurrent programs in multi-processing environment;   - Beowulf is a way to build such environments;   - Elasticwulf is an utility to master Beowulf environment in Amazon EC2 and run MPI programs here (just as an example)

How do you distinguish EC2 instances??? We are using our EC2 instances to a lot of test development so each developer brings up their own instance to work with.  These instances are interspersed with actual production and staging instances.  Is there any way to add a description or name or something to an instance?  I know there is that "User Data" field when you create the new instance, but I don't see where that is actually used.  Having to remember that your instance is ad67dfc2 as opposed to bfa391fc is really lame.

A few points:a) Generally, I recommend that you do *NOT* intersperse prod/dev/test instances amongst each other.  What we do is that we have different AWS accounts (all billed to the same card using consolidated billing) for each -- so that the test account fires up only test instances, the prod account has only prod instances, etc etc.We learned this the hard way when we accidentally killed a prod instance when we wanted to kill a test instance b) Where do you want the annotation to be visible?  If you add it to the "user data" field  when you launch an instance it is visible IN the instance ONLY by accessing the http://169.254.169.254/ url from the instance in question.   If you want the data to be visible in your desktops, etc etc then I'd recommend doing one of the following:1) define a separate keypair one each for dev, test, stage.  Launch each type of instance with its own key pair.  The keypair then serves as the annotation that youa re looking for.2) if you want something more sophisticated then creating tags and storing it in a db when you launch the instance may be what you're looking for.We use approach 2) in our solution.- Bill

Bill's advice is good.  One other possible approach to distinguishing instances is by using do-nothing "tag" security groups:  http://www.shlomoswidler.com/2009/06/tagging-ec2-instances-using-security_30.html
You could also use Rain Toolkit:http://www.logicstyle.com/raintoolkit.htmlIt solves this among other problems.
Agree with Bill. You can also check this might help: http://www.capsunlock.net/2010/05/five-easy-steps-to-tag-ec2-instance-using-mr-awsome.html
I use the empty-security-group method of tagging instances that Shlomo pointed out. I like it because it doesn't rely on a secondary db/store, and it's been super-reliable.

Just wanted to let you know that we have added the ability to  tag EC2 resources- tags consist of a case sensitive key/value pair, are stored in the cloud and can be created, edited, and deleted through both the APIs and the AWS management console.Abhinav
Cool. Long time coming, but I'm glad to see this.

Amazon please help: Query syntax for blockDeviceMapping This thread has gone over a week without an answer.  In case the title was misleading I've reposted.  Please forgive me, but I don't see any progress and you are the only ones who can answer this accurately.http://developer.amazonwebservices.com/connect/message.jspa?messageID=160647#160647Amazon,There are no docs in the easily searchable world describing how to encode changes to blockDeviceMapping using the Query api.  I've tried turning on debug on the CLI tools, but since they use SOAP, it doesn't help solve the issue.  By searching code of open source amazon tools, it seems no-one knows this.Today, jclouds and other tools using the query api are unable to take full advantage of the EBS backed instances.  We don't know how to specify single or multiple changes to blockDeviceMapping, and are left to guessing this and also guessing how to encode them.  This causes unnecessary poor experience and also wastes our time considerably.  A blog on "how we figured out ec2 via brute force http probing" would be a further waste of resources.I'm sure this is just an oversight, and you want us to use the Query api and your EBS features.  I'm moreover sure you don't want people left with poor experiences.A hand here would really help and empower us and by extension your ecosystem.  Please help answer this question and/or update the docs so jclouds and other apis can finish amazon support.Regards,Adrianfounder jcloudshttp://code.google.com/p/jclouds
Should we switch to SOAP for this function?  or is there a supported way of invoking ModifyInstanceAttribute blockDeviceMapping using the query api?

We're actively working on getting updated documentation published. Hopefully this can unblock you until then:For ModifyInstanceAttributes:(N is a counter starting at 1, in the same manner as other APIs such as DescribeInstances)BlockDeviceMapping.N.DeviceName = <devicename>BlockDeviceMapping.N.Ebs.VolumeId = vol-XXXXXXBlockDeviceMapping.N.Ebs.DeleteOnTermination = <bool>So for example to cause a stopped EBS-backed instance's root volume from being destroyed on termination, your query arguments would be:"Action" => "ModifyInstanceAttribute""InstanceId" => "i-...""BlockDeviceMapping.1.DeviceName" => "/dev/sda1""BlockDeviceMapping.1.Ebs.VolumeId" => "vol-...""BlockDeviceMapping.1.Ebs.DeleteOnTermination" => "false"Note: The volume ID is mandatory.For RunInstances:The same method applies, except you provide snapshots instead of volumes:BlockDeviceMapping.N.DeviceName = <devicename>BlockDeviceMapping.N.VirtualName = <virtual name>BlockDeviceMapping.N.Ebs.SnapshotId = vol-XXXXXXBlockDeviceMapping.N.Ebs.DeleteOnTermination = <bool>Example 1, two volumes created from snapshots:"Action" => "RunInstances""ImageId" => "ami-b232d0db""MinCount" => "1""MaxCount" => "1""KeyName" => "my-keypair""InstanceType" => "m1.small""BlockDeviceMapping.1.DeviceName" => "/dev/sdm""BlockDeviceMapping.1.Ebs.SnapshotId" => "snap-...""BlockDeviceMapping.2.DeviceName" => "/dev/sdn""BlockDeviceMapping.2.Ebs.SnapshotId" => "snap-..."Example 2, one volume created from snapshot, one fresh volume, the fresh volume is not to be deleted on termination:"Action" => "RunInstances""ImageId" => "ami-b232d0db""MinCount" => "1""MaxCount" => "1""KeyName" => "my-keypair""InstanceType" => "m1.small""BlockDeviceMapping.1.DeviceName" => "/dev/sdc""BlockDeviceMapping.1.Ebs.SnapshotId" => "snap-...""BlockDeviceMapping.2.DeviceName" => "/dev/sdd""BlockDeviceMapping.2.Ebs.VolumeSize" => "20""BlockDeviceMapping.2.Ebs.DeleteOnTermination" => "false"We'll update this thread again when the API docs are updated.Thanks,ChristianH@AWS
looks like the right info, Christian.I'll integrate this and ping back if I run into any hitches.Thanks!-Adrian

Moving existing launched instance from North America (East) to Singapore Is it possible to move an instance from North America (East) to Singapore?  A customer of ours has requested this
Hi Amazon,  Could you please respond to this?  I'm okay if the answer is no, just please let me know so I can come up with alternate arrangements.  Cheers, CVertex
maybe this would be of help https://cloudyscripts.com/you can run from your own instance - read the faq 9.

Hi cvertex,This question actually entails two answers:1) For EBS-backed instances, it's possible to migrate Linux AMI's to another region, but isn't a supported or built-in process from us (though, I know other customers have done this before). Windows AMI migration to another region is not a supported process.2) For instance-store backed instances, you can use the ec2-migrate-image command to perform the migration. Just ensure that the AKI and ARI (if an ARI is in use) that your current AMI uses are available in the target region (primarily a Linux step). You can see more about the ec2-migrate-image command here:http://docs.amazonwebservices.com/AWSEC2/latest/CommandLineReference/ApiReference-cmd-MigrateImage.htmlThat being said, a running instance can't be migrated to another region. You'd have to create an AMI from the instance before doing the migration. I hope this steers you in the right direction.Best Regards,Scott

Promiscuos Mode networking Hello all,Is it possible to use tools like Application Discovery Manager (http://www.vmware.com/products/application-discovery-manager/) or Pion (www.atomiclabs.com) in EC2?I.e. any service that requires a SPAN port / promiscuous mode networking across multiple hosts? The security guide would appear to imply not, but I wonder if there are any work arounds? cheers,Steve

Hi Refering to the Amazon Web Services: Overview of Security Processes please find the following extract. it states that this is not supported.Packet sniffing by other tenants:       It is not possible for a virtual instance running in promiscuous mode to       receive or “sniff” traffic that is intended for a different virtual     instance.  While customers can place       their interfaces into promiscuous mode, the hypervisor will not deliver       any traffic to them that is not addressed to them.  This includes two virtual instancesthat       are owned by the same customer, even if they are located on the same       physical host.  Attacks such as ARP       cache poisoningdo not work within EC2.        While Amazon EC2 does provide ample protection against one customer       inadvertently or maliciously attempting to view another’s data, as a       standard practice customers should encrypt sensitive traffic.The full document can be found at the following linkhttp://developer.amazonwebservices.com/connect/entry.jspa?externalID=1697
Thanks Jason.I cross-posted this in the Private Cloud forum too - do you know if this limitation still applies in the Private Cloud beta?

Hi Thomas,The drop in the traceroute that you see on the third from last hop is normal behaviour, it won't stop your ssh traffic reaching your instance.. Elastic Fox is just a convenient tool for creating a connection. On a Windows instance it will attempt to create a remote desktop connection. If you firewall doesn't allow outgoing remote desktop connections then you're a bit stuck.To install the service used by logmein or gotomypc then clearly you need a connection to the instance in the first place. The details of installation I don't know, they will be on the service's web site.I can't see any alternative to getting around the firewall at least once, for example you might be able to create an EBS based image from home with the remote access service installed, and then use it from work.You might be able to get command line access to a Windows instance via ssh, in theory, but I doubt you can install these facilities except via a web browser running on the instance and, anyway, odds are if your firewall blocks remote desktop it will block ssh too.

Configuring SSL with an ELB I have a web app that I deploy by creating several EC2 instances and putting them under an Elastic Load Balancer. Things run very well. I now have a requirement to also provide HTTPS access to this application, so that you can access it through either http://www.url.com OR https://www.url.com. I'm trying to understand what changes need to be made to my configuration, and think I've covered it all:I'll configure my EC2 AMI to have an SSL certificate so that it can be accessed securely. My certificate is self-signed, so there are no security or licensing issues to worry about. And yes, I understand SSL very well, and using a self-signed cert for this application is completely reasonable. I'll create a new Security Group which maps 80->80 and 443->443 and use this for each EC2 instance. Finally, when I create my ELB I'll create listeners for 80->80 and 443->443.Is that it? Am I missing something, or is this all I need to do to get this to work?

You'll need two ELB listeners: one HTTP listener for port 80 and one TCP listener for port 443.  I don't understand your comment:  I'll create a new Security Group which maps 80->80 and 443->443 and use this for each EC2 instance.  What mapping are you talking about with security groups? Security groups for these instances will need to have ports 80 and 443 (or whatever backend ports you choose to use) open to 0.0.0.0/0.

You're right, there is no mapping in security groups. Wrote that early in the morning and was looking at the security group configuration and saw 2 columns. I thought it was a mapping instead of a from/to for listing ports. Sorry for the confusion.I wanted to verify that I thought out all of the pieces - configure cert on AMI, open port in Security Group, and open listener in ELB. Sounds like that's all I need.
I asked about this before and go no answer - what if I want to use signed SSL certs? What domain do they get issued to?
The domain of the site that will be serving SSL.
So that would be, for example, service.mydomain.com rather than mydomain-main-195385353.us-east-1.elb.amazonaws.com?

Fedora 13 pv-grub snapshot and ami I hope someone else will find benefit from this info.  I was intrigued to read about pv-grub and was interested to get fedora 13 working on it.  Except for one little trick that was very hard to find, it was pretty easy.  But missing that trick, I spent a lot of time goofing around.Fedora 13's recent kernels (I'm using 2.6.34.6-54) include xsave disabled so they work out of the box.  The trick (found elsewhere in these forums) is that the drives are no longer enumerated /dev/sd?.  They are /dev/xvd?.  Still use sd? for the ami registration but use xvd? in fstab and menu.lst.I've created a snapshot following these guidelines (http://www.ioncannon.net/system-administration/894/fedora-12-bootable-root-ebs-on-ec2/).  Turns out many of the extra steps associated with MAKEDEV are due to fc12/13 having broken udev with an fc8 kernel.  So the steps can be abbreviated and much cleaner with pv-grub.  (more justification to get off of fc8 kernel)My snapshot is x86_64, ext4, under 1G, and tries to setup swap on /dev/xvdb1.  You can find it here: snap-7634021d.  Also, here is an AMI that boots a 15G root partition, resizes and attaches a device for swap:  ami-8a3cc9e3.Of course you probably want to make your own snapshot for security purposes.  Between the FC12 guidelines and this example, you can probably figure it out.  Note that I was only able to make an ext4 partition by booting into a recent kernel (I made an ext4 fc13 from an interim fc13 partition).Davek

Identifying Instances Hello,I'm very new to the EC2 world and I was wondering if there's a way to annotate or comment instances.  It seems that after setting up a couple of different instances it's difficult to track the specific nature of each one.Thanks!

Hello, dogor97:There are a few ways:a) If you want the nature of the instance to be visible on the client, you could use the tag feature of ElasticFox (a plug in to Firefox).  You could store the tags associated with your instances when you launch instances with Elastic Fox.  The downside is that the tag is available only in that browser -- and not anywhere else.  So if others in your team want to see this,  you're out of luck.b) You could use the technique of creating dummy security groups -- named appropriately.  See http://www.shlomoswidler.com/2009/06/tagging-ec2-instances-using-security_30.html  (shlomo is an expert on aws/ec2 and you should bookmark him).  The advantage is that the "tag" is now available on the client and on the instance itself.c) You could roll your own solution -- storing things in a db, etc etc.- Bill

You can also use third-party tools such as ylastic, which allow you to tag instances and other resources. The disadvantage is that these tags are only visible within the specific third-party tool. Just like ElasticFox.
Hi Guys,Thanks for the ideas!  I've tried the three suggestions with success so now it's a matter of figuring out what will work better in the long run.Thanks!

Just a clarification to my post above:  ylastic's tags are like ElasticFox in that they're not visible if you use any other client to manage your EC2 deployment.  But - unlike ElasticFox - ylastic's tags ARE visible in all ylastic connections no matter what browser or device client you're connecting from.
Thanks for the clarification!

New addition to APIs -- Launch metadata (+ what's the reason for <reason>?) One thing that I'm looking to do is specify an arbitrary piece of metadata with my runInstances call.  However, this is not metadata that is important to the running instance -- it's important to me outside of the cloud.  For instance, I have 2 applications (smurf, and bongo) -- each has a web tier.  Each of those web tiers uses the same AMI, but I use different security groups, access keys, and instance sizes.  I'd like a way to group a set of instances together by arbitrary metadata.  I'd like to tag a running instance with 'bongo' or 'smurf', without intruding on the metadata that gets passed to the instance.  This way, I can just query the list of instances by the metadata and know how large of a cluster I have allocated for each purpose.  Is there a good location to store this information?    I noticed that the DescribeInstances now returns a <reason/> tag within the instanceSet/items. What's the reason for <reason/>?   Could it be used for this purpose?  -- Jon

You want specify metadata that is included with the results of ec2-describe-instances?  Will this metadata have only a finite number of valid values, and if so, how many different valid values will you have for this metadata?
I think the Reason element in the response is used to tell you the reason the instance was shutdown (e.g. User Action, etc.).We use SimpleDB to store metadata about all of our instances.  Mitch

Yes, I'd like this metadata to be returned via ec2din.  The metadata will have an infinite # of valid values, but likely I'll only use a few to tag it with its purpose.  I suppose I could deal with this data locally.  Just start the instance and save the returned instance-ids off into a DB.  The problem is that the full operation is not transactional, and I don't want to have instances lying around that I can't account for.  -- Jon

For a finite # of values, you could use the key name, i.e., create a key for each role, then launch the instance with the appropriate key.  The key name is returned with ec2-describe-instances.  Another option would be to create a different AMI for each role, since the AMI ID is also returned with ec2-describe-instances.

That sounds like a good short-term solution, but it would be good to disassociate meaningful metadata (key, security group, instance size, etc.) from stuff that should be opaque to AWS.    I'd still push for them to adopt some concept that gives this ability.

You can associate user metadata (see the -d and -f parameters to ec2-run-instances), but AFAIK, this metadata is not returned by ec2-describe-instances, it can only be read by the instance.  See "Retrieving User Data" at http://docs.amazonwebservices.com/AWSEC2/2008-02-01/DeveloperGuide/AESDG-chapter-instancedata.html

Instead of using key names you could use security group names. The groupd can be empty, thus be a no-op functionally. Since you can associate many groups with an instance you have a lot of flexibility, like putting an instance into the "app server", "java", "primary", "production" groups...Thorsten
That's perfect.  Great idea!  -- Jon
That would be a better solution.  I take it the security group associations are returned by ec2-describe-instances?  If so, that's missing from the Developer Guide...

Hi,We’d strongly recommend against using security groups for this as it is not their intended purpose, i.e. they were not intended to function as meta-data tagging for instances. In the near future we plan to limit the number of security groups an instance can belong to. The limit would still be reasonable and would not impinge on current usage patterns, but it might affect the use of security groups for arbitrary meta-data tagging.Regards,Ben

How to share an EBS snapshot among multiple EC2 accounts? Hi,  In my organization, we use one EC2 keypair for day-to-day development and testing purposes, and a separate keypair for production. We do this to reduce the likelihood of someone accidentally taking down our production servers.  One step of our continuous integration story is a multi-hour database import and analysis job. Once the job is done, we snapshot the EBS volume that the data is stored to. Then, in day-to-day development tasks, we just create a new volume from that snapshot rather than redoing the full import.  So far, so good. However, I can't figure out how to share that snapshot (stored with the dev EC2 keypair) with the production environment (using the production keypair). For other S3 objects (such as our AMIs), we've been successful by granting the production keypair access to the appropriate objects. But since the EBS snapshots seem to be stored in non-user-visible S3 space, we can't do that for our snapshots.  Does anyone have any suggestions (other than manually snapshotting back to S3 on our own) for how to deal with this?  Or, does anyone have any tips about how we could use a single EC2 account for dev and production, but somehow set up a flag to keep the production instances safe from accidental deletion?  Thanks,  -Patrick

High %idle on EC2 instances despite high load. I like to fully-load our compute hardware to reduce wasted CPU time, and on typical in-house hardware this is fairly easy: load the machine with as many runnable threads as there are cores, and idle time will go to zero.  Here is an example app:  public class Looper {     public static void main(String[] args)     {         while (true) { new java.util.Random().nextBytes(new byte[4096]); }     } }  On our in-house, 8-core hardware, I can run 8 of these and idle time (as reported by mpstat and top) goes to zero. I can even add a 9th, 10th, etc process, and idle time stays very close to zero.  On EC2 (c1.xlarge instances), however, idle time is much higher than I'd expect. At 8 processes, idle time hovers around %1, and with 9, 10, etc processes, it can increase to 2%-3% or higher. With more complicated programs (not the example above), idle time can be even higher than that.  Can anyone explain this? This is with very recent Amazon kernels, and does not include stolen CPU time, which I would expect to see on EC2. Is this a problem with EC2 in particular, or is it general to Xen? Are there known workarounds?

I assume (and hope) what you mean is that you like to see 0% idle on your instances because they're doing useful work, and not that you run extra threads on your machines just to drive down idle time to 0%?  That particular load may be a problem, since Random() depends on entropy which is a bit more scarce on virtualized boxes. I find "burnP6" to be tried-and-true tool for generating CPU load.

Yes, that's correct, doing useful work.  I'm not just trying to load the machine for the sake of load.  The implementation of Random() doesn't require any entropy from the system, so I don't think that explains it.  Regardless, I also see similar behavior with a simple Bash loop:     while (true); do i=$i+1; done  Though in that case it is less pronounced.  Message was edited by: Patrick Linehan

I wonder about your memory utilization, and whether your instances are paging at all. You probably have a different ratio of processor resources to memory on the virts. Are you running out of RAM and pageing a little bit?

Newbie AMI related questions Hi chaps,I've a couple of questions relating to AMIs which I can't find addressed in the online documentation, and which I'd be grateful for any answers.1) When I create my own AMI and upload it with ec2-upload-bundle, will I be charged for its storage while it's in existence? This would imply that everyone who provides public images is doing it out of a sense of altruism, which I find slightly hard to believe.2) If I want to update a particular image, e.g. due to kernel and package patches, do I have to upload a whole new image (with a new identifier) each time, or can I just substitute the old for the new? I can see why such substitution would be frowned upon (mainly for reasons of version control).Thanks for any helpful answers.

1) Yes, the storage costs are on the uploader.  However, AMIs are compressed before uploading, so you only pay for what you use.  Also, it is using S3 storage, so the costs are pretty small (even an AMI at the 10GB max size would only cost $1.50-$1.65 per month).  2) No, you cannot change an image and keep the same ami-id.  When you register a manifest, EC2 appears to log the checksum of the manifest.  Any changes and the AMI will not launch.

Need to open a port for TCPS... please suggest urgent!!!! HI all,    I have need to open  a port 2482 for tcps in the security group. Please tell me how do i need to do this. Should I do it under https ??  This port is used to set up ssl for my oracle database server.  Thanks, Shashi

Are you using the Web-console, or the command line tools?  Assuming you are using the Web console:  Log in. Select your territory (US-EAST, for example). Select Security Groups. Select the security group you want to modify. Scroll to the bottom of the data. Choose "Custom".  TCP.  Source port range 0-65535.  Destination port range 2482-2482.  IP address of your choosing.  (If you specify a single IP address, be sure to use /32 , and not the default /0 ).  SAVE.

Amazon EC2 Vs. Windows Azure for .net Applications? Hello,   We're a small team develop social applications with Microsoft .net Framework, and we're looking for a hosting service + NoSql Database in the cloud for our applications.   Our primary requirements are high performance & Scalability, and C#.net Support of course.   As a general question- what are the technological advantages of Amazon EC2 as a cloud hosting service, compared to Windows Azure?   Why sould I, as a .net developers, choose the amazon EC2 as a cloud service, instead of windows azure?   More questions:  1. What is included in the service?  2. How do I control my machines? Web Service? RDP? I didn't fully understand this issue.  3. .net support- do amazon support .net 4.0 and MVC 2?  4. Upgrading & Windows Updates - Who is responsible to upgrade the system (for example a new .net framework or even new version of OS)?   I'll glad if you can attach any useful information regarding the amazon vs. azure, and amazon NoSql Databases vs. Azure Tables.   Thanks a lot and have a great week!  Lidan.

Amazon AWS/EC2 is different to Azure. Amazon is "infrastructure as a service" and Azure is (currently at least) "platform as a service".With AWS you fully manage your virtual servers, it is up to you to install and maintain whatever you need on that including things like virus scanning, windows updates, asp.net security updates etc etc. In AWS you can set up a windows server for example and you do what you want with it.In Azure you don't have a virtual server as such, you just deploy your application to windows azure or make use of sql azure etc. You dont worry about windows updates etc but you don't have the same level of flexibility either.One thing I don't like about azure is that you can only have one asp.net application per web role which makes it costly. I prefer Amazon AWS myself although you should expect that bot amazon and microsoft will change what they offer so you need to keep up with the changes e.g. I believe Microsoft will be offering complete virtual servers in a few months.

Changing EC2 load balancer configuration We have an ec2 load balancer that has been configured to forward all requests that come to port 80 to  port 8080 of three instances. Now we want to configure the same load balancer to foward requests that come to 443 to all these instances .Through the CLI i did this :elb-create-lb <lbname> --availability-zones us-east-1a --listener "protocol=tcp, lb-port=443, instance-port=443" --listener "protocol=http, lb-port=80, instance-port=8080"and it gave me an errorelb-create-lb:  Service error: Load Balancer named <lbname> already exists and it is configured with different parameters.  AWSRequestId:c89fe9cf-c236-11df-bbb2-3fc02f67aad6what am i doing wrong?

You're not doing anything wrong.  Unfortunately you can't modify the configuration of an ELB after it is created. You need to create a new ELB with the desired configuration. This has the unfortunate consequence of requiring a change to your DNS CNAME entry to point to the new ELB's DNS name.

Hi mydrew,Apologies for not wording my earlier response sufficiently clearly.  Your underlying infrastructure is healthy; your instance is failing to boot and become reachable over the network as a result of configuration problems inside the instance.  We cannot restore your instance to a running state on your behalf; you will almost certainly need to launch a replacement instance from your most recent AMI and restore your data from your most recent backups.  Running a Windows update shouldn't generally cause a problem under most circumstances, but it is always prudent to bundle before making significant changes.  In this particular case, you have noted that you had just finished making registry changes, which is most likely the cause of the instance failure.You are correct that the AMI bundling process documentation isn't very clear about the D: drive being excluded.  We will review the relevant user guide pages to make sure that information is clearly reflected.-Jason

Why doesn't new Instance come back up after software reboot? (repeatable) I have been able to duplicate this behavior twice.  Step 1. Create a new micro instance of ami-10f3a255 ( west coast, Alestic Ubuntu 10.04 32 bit ). Step 2. SSH into instance.   Step 3. Issue reboot command:  sudo reboot Step 4. Wait forever....  The instance container seems to reboot, but the OS doesn't appearing to come up.  (My wild guesses:  kernel panic, fsck of doom, ran out of memory during fsck, AMI not compatible with micro size, other?????)  Anybody from AWS want to hit that console ( i-b39d39f7 ) and see what the problem is?  Thanks, Lance Rushing

Figured it out.  See https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/cloud-init/+bug/634102  Nutshell, the ubuntu 10.04 ec2 images expect /dev/sda2 (32 bit) or /dev/sdb (64 bit) to be there during boot.  But /dev/sda2 doesn't exist for micro instances.  Fix: after first boot of instance run this command to comment out the line in /etc/fstab:  [ "$(uname -m)" = "x86_64" ] && ephd=/dev/sdb || ephd=/dev/sda2 sudo sed -i.dist "\,${ephd},s,^,#," /etc/fstab  Enjoy, Lance

Been a while since I've used windows, but most ftp clients have a "sftp" mode where you can just provide the ssh credentials for the server and it will let you move files like you would with ftp.  Not sure which clients support the .pem file authentication that ec2 uses.
Try winscp: http://winscp.net/eng/index.php

Can I delete the snapshot after launching an EBS-backed AMI? Hi all,I've just created a new EBS-backed AMI from an existing EBS-backed AMI (one of the public Ubuntu ones). During creation, a snapshot was created. I am now using the following resources:1 running instance1 EBS volume1 snapshotCan I safely delete this snapshot now that the volume has been created? Is there any purpose to it other than providing some backup for the EBS volume?Thanks,James

Hi,The AMI has the snapshot related to it. Deleting the snapshot will break your AMI. When an instance of the AMI is launched a volume is created from the snapshot. If you're never going to launch the AMI again or you're going to de-register it, you could delete the snapshot.Thanks, -Philip

Noob question re Amazon Linux API Hi folks,I'm trying to grasp how this all holds together.I have booted a 64 bit micro instance of Amazon Linux from EBS.I now wish to install some stuff onto this, confiigure the system to my liking etc.  I would then like to shut down the instance and later start it back up again, with all my changes intact.How do I do that?  My understanding is that since I booted from a public Amazon EBS AMI, when I shut down by instance, all my changes are lost.Is this correct?  Am I off track? What is the "right" way to boot Amazon Linux and have all my changes remain?ThanksAndrew

If you use an EBS-backed image you can "stop" it rather than "terminate" it. While it's stopped the EBS volume and the data on it remains but you are not billed for instance time (though you are billed for the volume itself, which is pretty cheap). You can then start it at any time and your data and configuration will still be there.  See the documentation for more detail.

Can you stop an EBS backed instance that is also a spot instance? Hi,I am trying to stop my EBS backed instance. It is an official ubuntu lucid ebs-boot ami. It is also a spot instance. When I go to the ec2 console, the "stop" action under "Instance Actions" for that instance is greyed out. I have googled and read what I can find under EBS backed and spot instances and I do not see any official documentation that states you cannot stop an EBS backed, spot instance. I have found other posters here that had similar problems, but there are other posters that make it sound like they can stop EBS backed, spot instances.Anybody know the official position?Thanks.
The command line tools fairly definitively answer your question:$ ec2-stop-instances i-a73105cdClient.UnsupportedOperation: The instance 'i-a73105cd' is a spot instance and may not be stopped.

Hi ampient,You can terminate a spot instance, but not stop it. You could probably preserve the EBS volume by setting delete-on-terminate to false via the API, but I have not tried that with a spot instance. Best regards,Mario
Thanks. That is a shame you can not do both.

Hi Mario,Thanks. I will try to set the flag and see what happens. What happens to an instance if with the default value? Is it automatically deleted? Or does it still hang around in a zombie state until it is deleted?Best,ampient

If this is running on t1.micro, then there is a known problem with Ubuntu 10.04 rebooting on that instance type.  See the bug report for the fix:  https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/cloud-init/+bug/634102  -- Eric Hammond http://alestic.com
These are type m1.small but they are ubuntu 10.04.

I checked your volume, and you should have got the error message like following when you made the AMI,"Client.BundleInstanceLimitExceeded:Another bundling request is currently outstanding for the instance"Please read this discussion about this errorhttp://developer.amazonwebservices.com/connect/message.jspa?messageID=169063I think you have already terminated your instance in trouble, so all things I can recommend you is to create new instance and remake your AMI after deleting your failed AMI.I hope this helps you.Nobuko

Thanks Nobuko.  I ended up doing two things and it appears to have solved my problem (I haven't run into the error since I made the changes so far anyway):1) I switched to a newer ubuntu base AMI2) I switched from using the "typica" java api to the java aws api
