If so, can you please point me, where to start.  Your help is appreciated, Thank you very much,  Boris

You might want to use an EBS-backed AMI and just "stop" the instance rather than "terminate" it. This way your data stays intact and you're not paying for a running instance when you don't need it (but you will pay for the EBS volume, which is pretty cheap).

How to make EBS based AMI static? I've gone through the process of making my own AMI based on one of the Alestic ones. It boots and works well.But every time it boots it creates a new volume to run on. How do I make it so that it re-uses the snapshot one? I don't want multiple volumes all over the place. I just want one machine that remembers it's state and will boot when I want.There must be some attribute that tells it to instantiate a new volume each time. I'd like to disable that and use the the same one over and over. I must be missing something basic because this makes no sense to me...Thanks for helping.

Hi,Each instance launched from your EBS-backed AMI will create a new volume.  For one thing you would not want multiple instances all using the same EBS root volume; also attaching an EBS volume to more than one instance at a time is not supported.If you are only running one instance, you may want to consider stopping and starting that instance, instead of terminating it and launching replacements.  You might want to review this User Guide page:http://docs.amazonwebservices.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/Tutorial_Launch_Stop_Start.htmlI still recommend that you keep an up-to-date AMI for launching a replacement if that becomes necessary, and/or snapshot your volumes to preserve restore points.Hope this helps!-Jason

If you are using EBS based amis then you can use stop and stop to maintain the current EBS. When you stop the server it stops running (and you don't pay any hourly rate anymore) but the EBS is maintained. Neill Turnerhttp://www.elastdream.com

How to store web content to be used in multiple windows AWI's Hello,I am new to AWS so if this has already been discussed with resolution then please let me know where I can find the information.I am using windows IIS and have web content that I would like to be able to use in multiple instances.  SO basically I thought perhaps I could use the S3 bucket to store the static web content and then when I provision new windows servers I could somehow upload it or point the IIS settings back to this saved web content.  The goal is to have a way to take content and then spin up X number of windows instances and use them as a load balanced solution.  SO during a weekend sale we can spin up 50 windows web servers to handle the traffic automatically and then once the sale is complete we can then roll back the instances.  Is this possible to do in windows instances...this way when we terminate instances we dont lose the content and eventually can use it again for the next sale.  Or can we somehow clone a golden instance and then deploy multiple copies of it ( I would think this might be an issue because of the changes made in the OS during the windows deployment process ( server name changes, SID, etc...)  ANy help or guidance would be greatly appreciated

Typically you want to put your static content in S3 and then use Amazon Cloudfront to distribute it for you. Then your IIS server does not need to handle static content. You just have to update the URLs of your static contact to the S3 locations.  You still may need to do autoscaling of your applications as well. See http://www.elastdream.com/search/label/Load%20Balancing%20and%20Auto%20Scaling  Neill Turnerhttp://www.elastdream.com.

Possible to "cap" EC2/S3? (budgeting) Hi,A friend and I have started to look @ EC2 / S3 for a project, however since it is just that, a project @ the moment, we would like to know if it's possible to "cap" an instance so that we don't go over our budget on both EC2 and storage on S3.Thanks.- Jon
I am not aware of any way to set a fixed limit on how much you want to spend on EC2. You could post it as a feature request in this forum, though

Correct, there is no way to cap usage now, but in requesting this feature, think about what you'd like to happen when the money runs out. Should the instance terminate? You may have lost data, but that's pretty much something you'd have to code around. Would you like warnings when things are "close" ? That way, you could do a controlled shutdown (or simply scale back your usage to allow critical things to continue running).David

I've always thought the more useful cap would be on S3 bandwidth. EC2 instance hours can't be started by anyone other than the person who's paying for it, so if you don't want to pay too much for EC2 time just don't start any more instances. Bandwidth controls in or out of EC2 is a "might be nice" feature, but mostly possible to manage inside of the EC2 instance, especially outgoing traffic. If you know you only want to send a gigabyte a day, your webserver can respond however it wants when it hits that limit. Getting a notification from Amazon when your instance is apporaching 1 gigabyte might be nice, since it's Amazon's definition of a gigabyte that counts for billing, not what your app thinks is a gigabyte.With public data in S3 there's nothing active that can be monitoring traffic. If you post a  video of your cat doing something cute, and a link gets posted to Slashdot and suddenly everyone wants to look at it you have no recourse other than hopefully noticing before it gets too out of hand. It's nice that S3 can handle the load, but maybe you don't want it too

disappeared data! After a stop and then start (not terminate!!) Instance EBS m1.small on CentOS-5.4, Disk 140GB S3, which was mounted to "/mnt", was clean and my data disappeared. What happens and where my data? How i can get them back? And please, give me a link to docs on this case. Thanks.<!--EndFragment-->

Your data is permanently gone.  The 140GB drive is an ephemeral volume and doesn't persist across stops or terminates.  http://docs.amazonwebservices.com/AWSEC2/latest/DeveloperGuide/index.html?instance-storage-concepts.html

These are Amazon answers in the User Guide API Version 2010-06-15 (Instances and AMIs Information FAQ of Technical FAQ) confirm that the possibility to stop your service (Instance) is the norm AWS Amazon EC2 - Pay only for what you use ...What are the differences between stopping and terminating an instance?The instance will first perform a normal shutdown in both cases. If the instance was stopped, it will then transition to a stopped state, all of its Amazon EBS volumes will remain attached, and it can then be started again at a later time. If the instance was terminated, attached Amazon EBS volumes will be deleted where the associated deleteOnTermination instance attribute is set to true. The instance itself will also be deleted, and the instance cannot be started again at a later date ... How does stopping and starting an instance effect how it is charged?You will not be charged for additional instance hours while the instance is in a stopped state. A full instance hour will be charged for every transition from a stopped state to a running state, even if this happens multiple times within a single hour. If the instance type was changed while the instance was stopped, you will be charged at the new instance type’s rate once the instance has been started. All of the associated Amazon EBS usage of your instance, including root device usage, will be charged at the typical Amazon EBS prices. At the same time as the disappearance of the data, we received an email from Amazon Web Services EC2 team:Dear EC2 Customer, You recently reached a limit on the volume of email you were able to send out of SMTP port 25 on your instance:Instance ID: i-17d4a560* IP Address: 46.51.131.204* Start date: 2010-09-15 11:50 +0000 This IP Address: 46.51.131.204 We never used for i-17d4a560. This letter is in time coincided with the loss of information on the Instance Storage of Instance ID: i-17d4a560 at Stop / Start. Before that there were no such cases Message was edited by: oleksandrp

Any time you stop an instance, the ephemeral volumes are lost.  If you instead store your data on EBS volumes, then your data will persist across stop-start.  The email limit message is unrelated to the loss of data.  If you plan on sending email from your instance, fill out this form:  https://aws-portal.amazon.com/gp/aws/html-forms-controller/contactus/ec2-email-limit-rdns-request

1. So, does it mean that the words "Pay only for what you use..." are not actual for S3 data storage technology? Thus, we need to refuse totally from S3 and use EBS?2. Why was assigned another IP address for our Instance?3. I want to mention one more time: all the data was storing during one month after stop/start Instance meanwhile we were worked with the system. Is this a regularity or an accidental event?

1. So, does it mean that the words "Pay only for what you use..." are not actual for S3 data storage technology? Thus, we need to refuse totally from S3 and use EBS?  "Pay only for what you use" is referring to the EC2 CPU and memory resources.  They mean that you don't pay the houly EC2 rate when your instance is terminated or stopped.  2. Why was assigned another IP address for our Instance?  Every time you stop and start your instance, it gets a new IP address.  If you want to keep the same address, then you will have to associate an Elastic IP address to your instance after each start.  3. I want to mention one more time: all the data was storing during one month after stop/start Instance meanwhile we were worked with the system. Is this a regularity or an accidental event?  They only way that your data would have persisted across stop-start is if it was on an EBS volume instead of an ephemeral volume.  If your data is on an ephemeral volume, it will be lost every time you stop your instance.  If you want to persist your data, you should store it on an EBS volume.

If not, how to be, when the number of instances will be increased? Each time we must associate an IP address for our instance?  Message was edited by: oleksandrp
You could automate assigning elastic IPs if each instance has a startup script that assigns an elastic IP to itself.
Do you mean a script for web-interface or a script, which will be located in OS and will work on every system startup?
I mean an OS init script.

Windows Server 2008 IIS Manager Hello,I'm using a Getting Started on Microsoft Windows Server 2008 and i can't configure the  IIS Manager in order to connect to the default website on the instance.I want to connect through Firefox to the website on the EC2 instance (inetpub\wwwroot).Sorry for being a noob.Thanks in advance.

Troubleshooting steps:  1.  Is the website configured correctly on the server?  Log into the server via an RDP client (terminal server) and open Internet Explorer and try to browse to http://localhost.  If the website does not come up then you have a configuration problem on the server.  Steps to resolve are EXACTLY THE SAME as if you had the server running locally in your own data center on physical hardware.  2.  If step #1 was successful try browsing from your local computer to the SAME IP address or DNS entry that you used to connect to terminal server.  If you cannot connect, then you probably have a firewall problem and you need to make sure you have HTTP configured in your EC2 instances Security Group.  3.  If step #2 was happy then try browsing to the site with whatever the public DNS name is for the site (assuming this is probably different than the address you used in step #2).  If this fails then you have a DNS and/or EC2 elastic IP issue.  Luck-

Unable to mount volume created from snapshot Hi all,I started out by creating an EBS volume. I attached it to a running instance and was able to mount the volume on my instance. I moved some data onto the mounted volume. I then unmounted the volume from my instance and then detached the volume from my instance. From here, I then created a snapshot of the detached volume.After this I then create a volume from my snapshot and attached the created volume to my running instance. Note that the instance was never terminated. When i try to mount that newly attached volume (mount /dev/sdg /mnt/myvol) I get the following error:mount: you must specify the filesystem typeI then tried to specify the filesystem type using: mount -t ext3 /dev/sdg /mnt/bbgvol and I get the following error:mount: wrong fs type, bad option, bad superblock on /dev/sdg,       missing codepage or helper program, or other error       In some cases useful info is found in syslog - try       dmesg | tail  or soRunning the suggested dmesg command yields the following: sdg: unknown partition tablehfs: unable to find HFS+ superblockVFS: Can't find ext3 filesystem on dev sdg.I am using AWS Management Console for Creating and attaching the volume as well as creating the snapshots.Any ideas why this would be happening? I'm I missing a critical step?Thanks all.

In between attaching the (newly created) volume to the instance and mounting it, you must have formatted it. If you hadn't formatted it you wouldn't have been able to put files on it.  Can you look back in your command history to see how you formatted it? It would be some kind of command involving "mkfs". That is the type of filesystem you created on the EBS volume, and that is what you'd need to specify for the mount command to succeed again.  If you didn't format it then you probably make a mistake and only _thought_ you were saving the data to the EBS volume, but it was actually not being used, and instead being written to the original instance's drives. You can verify this by checking the content of /mnt/myvol on the original instance - if it still contains the contents then that is what happened.  You can avoid this problem by changing the permissions of the mount point to "400". That will prevent you from writing to the mount directory when nothing is actually mounted there.

Oh sorry about that. I forgot to mention the formatting part of the step. Here's the command that I used to format the volume:yes | mkfs -t ext3 /dev/sdgI was able to verify that after unmounting the volume, that the volume was no longer visible from the mount point.Any thoughts?

I think I figured out the problem. I had deleted the actual volume and was trying to create a volume from a snapshot which inherently doesn't contain all the blocks to reconstruct the volume. From what I just understood, the snapshot only contains what has changed in the volume from which it was created. I think I'm good to go.

Just a quickie ..I found this thread when I came across the same problem, the actual fix ismount -t ext3 /dev/sdg1 /mnt/bbgvolI think .. he was trying to mount /dev/sdg instead of /dev/sdg1 or 2 or 3 etc.Thread is a couple of months olf, sorry for bringing it back up, but as I said, it came up on a search where I was looking to fix the same problem

Hi Carlos,  I'm sorry for my unclarity. My blogpost has much of the answers you request and provides some screenshots but I'll clarify for myself here.  At this moment, we have a free demo application running on https://qloudwatch.com. At the moment, it provides cost information on your running instances. The demo app is only a week old so we haven't had time yet to implement reserved instances and all other costs metrics since we have a need for the information it currently provides in our own business and are very curious about what information other people find most important.  We've chosen to group instances into project so you can group instances from your AWS account into projects you share with other users or create budgets in te future. We've created the possibility to share projects with other users so you can even add EC2 instances from different accounts into one project so you can for example share costs or work with different internal company cards.  Users have to provide their AWS credentials so the application can automatically grab a list of instances you haven't added to any projects yet. The credentials also make sure the state of an instance is updated every 30 minutes so an instance gets terminated in Qloudwatch when you terminate it trough the API or AWS management console. You also get an e-mail for every instance you launched that isn't added to a project yet, so you never forget to add any instances to projects (even if they only run for 1 hour).  Currently we use the Amazon prices and just time calculation for cost estimates. We've not yet added importing the usage reports or implementing CloudWatch in the application but this is something I am looking at at this moment. Enabling EC2 CloudWatch is quite expensive in my opinion but it sure is the most accurate way of measuring instance statistics. So I will honestly say that our current method is definately not 100% accurate or fail proof. But it's a start that is helping us with budgeting and billing our project. I'm really open to suggestions if you would want to upload the usage reports, run some kind of agent on your instances or would like to use CloudWatch for getting more accurate stats.  We have no concrete plans on how to run this application commercially. We've discussed this somewhat internally (having a free account with 2 projects and for bigger accounts have a monthly fee or something) but this project started out from our own need and I'm really curious about if it would be useful to other people. We ARE planning to launch it as a payed app in the future if enough people provide feedback on what they want but we're really open about our intentions and like to improve budgets and costs for AWS users first, and then think about what we could get from it commercially.  I've provided more info in my post at my personal blog: http://shapingclouds.com/2010/01/04/a-problem-and-a-solution-with-aws-no-segregation-of-instances-and-no-budgets/  Carlos, I hope I've provided enough information for a discussion here now and love to know your feedback.  Oh, by the way. The AWS credentials are of course encrypted in our database so they can't be read if the database somehow would get corrupted or "stolen". Also, the demo is secured with a verified class 1 SSL certificate.   Message was edited by: Michiel Sikkes

Amazon charges $80 per device you send them.  More details on this page: http://aws.amazon.com/importexport/

Yes, you are responsible for purchasing your storage device.  The $80 fee covers the costs associated with handling your package/device and includes domestic return shipping costs via UPS ground in the US and An Post Express Post in Ireland.-Chesley

I finally got a bare-bones openSUSE 10.2 system built and running.It's been a very difficult multi-stage bootstrap exercise but I now have the max 10GB root filesystem, can use yast to install more software on it, and use ec2-bundle-vol to save back the image to S3 for the next round of bootstrapping.It's still too early for this AMI to mark it as shareable but I can share with you some rough notes and   'gotchas', not all covered in forums to date as far as I can tell.- I would have liked to completely script the build along the lines of the excellent debian and redhat build scripts already made public, but this involved AutoYast and every time I started with it I ended up waking up in a gutter somewhere.  Alternative was to use Yast's "Install into Directory" feature, after creating a 1GB loopback file sys.  Needed to keep the image absolutely minimal.. uploading images from long distance was a serious constraint.. But no matter how many things you de-select in yast, the installer insists on installing a ton of stuff you don't need just so as to ensure there won't be room for the stuff you do need.  I just tried to keep it under the 1GB, but as you'll see below, this caused a lot of pain.. go for about 3GB and just don't plan to ec2-upload it from Sydney.- Do pretty well all the non-distro-specific things that are in Paul Morris' "self-bundling AMI" post for Debian.  - In addition:  note that EC2 will bring up the sys in runlevel 4.  The reason nobody has been getting a login prompt is because suse's /etc/inittab has runlevel 4 commented out!  Just remove that comment.  While there, comment out ttys 2-6 as noted in other posts.- Use chkconfig to add sshd and network services to runlevel 4.    - See my recent post in this forum (titled ec2-bundle-vol error 141) for code showing fix to "MAKEDEV" lines in ruby script as applied to suse and recommended by others.- ec2-bundle-image will now produce something that can be uploaded and will start.  The problem is that the 1GB root file system is so full that you can do very little with it.  You can't even start configuring yast.. point it to a suse repos and it will load tons of metadata into /var/adm.  This is enough to fill and break the root file sys.- In one unrepeatable session on the new instance, I removed a lot of fluff that I used to consider valuable, such as /usr/share/doc, locales etc.   I also temporarily moved /usr/share and some other big areas to /mnt and set up symbolic links pointing to them.  This was all so that I could free up enough space to start configuring yast so I could install ruby so I could use the AMI bundling tools to re-write what I had so far into a 10BG image (after restoring the moved folders).  Don't forget to once again do the "MAKEDEV" edits mentioned above.  If any of you manage a clean, scripted build, presumably auto-yast driven, that will be superior if only because it will be repeatable, but if none of us can produce that then I will try to tidy up my image and make it public.  But for now the good news is, it can be done!

Thank you for the update.  I look forward to a LAMP SuSE that will support our application.  The run level 4 was a new twist for me.  Good info!!!Could you some how pass me a pointer to this image?I will send back feed back.......emg@EdwardMGoldberg.com
I've cleaned it up and submitted a public image Edward, see new listing in Public Images ami-50fc1939.Hope you find it useful, yes I am indeed interested in any feedback you might have.regardsfrank
I will take a peek.I use RightScale.com for my launch.  Do you support the ssh keys that they use?If not how do I log into the ec2 IP?  Some users have special ways.....emg@EdwardMGoldberg.com

If you launch the image naming your own public key as described in the tutorials, this image that I have published does the "right thing" in that at start up it grabs your public key from a pre-defined local ip number via wget.    See the scripts that others have published eg the rightscale scripts.  They all show this technique and it works for openSUSE too.I haven't tried to test this against anything other than the keypair that I generated for myself, but I do expect it to work ok for you.  Please let me know if problems, otherwise the public ami is no good for anybody!In fact, if any AWS staff are monitoring this forum, can you confirm that the image I published can be started and logged on to and has followed recommended practices as advertised?  thanks.. frank

Great work,  this is a very good start.  Yes I have a number of comments:1)  Turn off login by password.  The only access sould be by SSH preloaded key,  both at install and later.  As it is now you can add users with YAST and they have access with a weak password.2) mysql:  The /etc/my.cnf has the port 3306 open to the world.  This is open inside the EC2 local area net even when the internet ports are closed.  The default should be no network access.  Then you can use a localhost ssh port tunnel later to get all of the access that you need.  Use the -L 3306:localhost:3306 option with only local ports open later.  For the default setup only local access allowed.  When the passwords are in place it would be up to the users to open up more access.3) The /etc/motd needs to cover the important points about the image.  Feel free to use up the whole screen.  End the message with "Edit /etc/motd" to remove this rant....4) The /srv/www/htdocs was very nice.  Is this your project?5) You have xeyes and xclock in the image but no xterm?  I did an ssh -Y ... and the X interface works well.   But no xterm?  Any reason?5) yast2 worked well.  How to you want to interface the distro DVD-Image?  Should I just upload a Distro?6) I need to learn more about the Image Save stuff where to I start?  Is this the best solution?  What about the file systems that rsync to S3 in the background?7) Do you live in AUS?  The Image is in that time zone.One again great work.  I will keep following and one day I hope to add to this project.  I need a "real" 10.2 for my project soon.  This has been a good start.  You have saved me a week or more work.  The next beer is on me!! (aus?).Edward M. Goldberg.....
No news from you for a while.  How are you doing?I have made lots of progress thank's to you on the SuSE 10.2 project.Drop by and say hi some day.  Lets talk about the news.....Edward M. Goldberg

memcache security group setup help request I've created 2 security groups, named 'web' and 'memcache'.  Through the AWS Management console I've added 'web' security group to 'memcache' security group and vice-versa.  I've verified that the memcached is not bound to 127.0.0.1, e.g. no "-l 127.0.0.1"  My web application cannot access the memcache server...  "[15-Sep-2010 23:54:50] PHP Notice:  MemcachePool::get(): Server x.x.x.x (tcp 11211, udp 0) failed with: Connection timed out (110) in mymemcachecode.php on line 1234"  When I add the webserver IP, i.e. x.x.x.x/32 to the memcache security group, I can access memcached just fine.  I do not want to have to add every webserver IP to the memcache security group.  What steps do I need to do in order to have webserver security group be able to access the memcache security group on port 11211?  Thanks.

Hi realjnoss,If you are reluctant to add every IP address of your instances that belong to 'web' group, then you can simply use your security group name instead of source IP addresses in your rule of 'memcache' group. By doing this, all the instances in 'web' group can access the instances in 'memcache' group through port 11211.This can be done via AWS Management Console, but if you find CLI is handy for you, there is a good example to build a typical three-layered security in the example section of the following URL:http://docs.amazonwebservices.com/AWSEC2/latest/DeveloperGuide/using-network-security.htmlHope this helps.

Thank you for your reply.  I did mention that I added each security group to each other, e.g. added 'web' to 'memcache' and added 'memcache' to 'web,' but that did not seem to work.   It was not until I actually added the IP for port 11211 to the 'memcache' group that the memcache server was visible to the web server.  I've read the docs at the link,   http://docs.amazonwebservices.com/AWSEC2/latest/DeveloperGuide/index.html?using-network-security.html, but that did not give me any insight as to why I cannot connect to the memcache server.  Has anyone had success setting up memcache in a separate security group?  If so, what steps did you take?  And, did you have to add the IP for every VM?  Do the instances have to be in the same zone?  Thanks.

I figured out that I need to use the DNS name for my elastic IP rather than the IP itself.  This, then, resolves to the internal IP which the security groups recognize.  See this article...  http://alestic.com/2009/06/ec2-elastic-ip-internal  I hope this helps others out there with similar setups.
